PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Plant Variety Rights
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes.
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bjelke-Petersen (from 14 citizens), Kilgariff (from two citizens) and Sibraa (from 15 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Wynyard Airport, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Tasmania shows:
(a) We are shocked and disappointed at the Federal Government's decision not to upgrade the Wynyard Airport.
(b) This decision will inevitably lead to downgrading and closure of the Wynyard Airport.
(c) Closure of Wynyard Airport will cause grave hardship and inconvenience to the people of the North West and West Coast regions of Tasmania.
(d) We urge the Federal Government to immediately reverse this disastrous decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Protest to the proposed change to the Oath of Allegiance in which recognition of God and the Queen would be deleted
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should-
Request that the Oath of Allegiance remain unchanged.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Canberra: Proposed Casino
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

That the Government has announced that a gambling casino will be included in the planned new convention centre in Canberra without consulting the people of the ACT. In addition, the Government was aware that Casino proposals for the ACT were defeated in 1977, 1979 and 1981 after the then Government of the day received strong local community protest and objections from people in many parts of Australia.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should-
Delay any finalisation of the matter by Parliament pending the holding of a referendum in the ACT to determine the views of Canberra people on the issue.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of local governments in Australia shows that
General revenue grants to local government under personal income tax sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83,
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent,
The increase in grants to State government over the same period was 11.8 per cent,
Increased demands are being made on local government authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g. Community Employment Program,
The Labor party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in general revenue grants to local government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to local government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. We deplore the unprincipled and self-interested attacks being orchestrated by minority sects and groups against the policies and person of the Commonwealth Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the Hon. Senator Susan Ryan.
2. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

3. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

4. We call upon the Federal Government however to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own special programs and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

5. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned programme of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United States Military and Intelligence Bases in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(a) U.S. military and intelligence bases which continue to operate on Australian soil pose a threat to our safety;
(b) The installations which transmit messages to and from nuclear armed submarines operate with little or no Australian supervision;
(c) These bases make us extremely vulnerable to attack and a prime target in the event of war.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will, as a matter of urgency, commence negotiations for removal of the bases in the interests of the Australian people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Jack Evans) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to collective agreements regulating the terms and conditions of employment of employees of corporations, and for purposes connected therewith.
Bill presented, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Industrial relations has grown over the past three decades to be of crucial importance, both within Australia and in other industrialised nations. For a host of economic and social reasons, it will continue to become increasingly important. Australia is on the verge of becoming the poor relation of Asia and of becoming a loser on the economic ladder of the world. Whether or not this happens will be the result of many differing factors: Not the least being the way in which we conduct our industrial relations. It is essential that we legislate now to provide safety valves for a system which is under massive pressures.

A vital part of the current debate is discussion of the practice of collective bargaining. It has been debated by the academic and industrial communities for several decades. Much has been written and much has been said, but there has been little action.

While some forms of collective bargaining already exist, there is no institutional mechanism for collective bargaining. It is also unlikely that such a mechanism would be able to develop without legislative action by the Australian Parliament.

Collective bargaining already exists in Australia: Some forms of collective bargaining, particularly above-award bargaining, are commonplace. These agreements, however, would seem to be unenforceable at common law. If, however, some of the terms and conditions of such agreements are incorporated into individual contracts of employment, then those items could be enforced in the courts by individual employees.

There are today legal and procedural difficulties impeding the effective enforcement of agreements that may be legally enforceable. For example, the doctrine of privity of contract, the restrictions on the granting of specific performance of employment contracts, the problems in determining the quantum of damages and the problems associated with particular provisions contained in the various State trade union Acts all act as effective impediments.

Formal collective agreements reached through informal collective bargaining often relate to matters which could never be incorporated in either federal awards or in certified agreements. Agreements often cover matters such as the payment of health insurance for employees and their families, and consultation over the implementation and effects of technological change and various other ' managerial prerogatives' which have been held by the High Court to be beyond the jurisdiction of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

Lastly, the lack of legal framework for collective bargaining has led to the threat or use of industrial action. There exists the situation where agreements are under stress during different phases of the economic cycle. In time of recession, trade unions are often reluctant to exercise industrial muscle in order to prevent the erosion of hard won gains which were achieved through informal collective bargaining. Conversely, in times of economic growth and expansion, employers may find that trade unions are reluctant to abide by concluded collective agreements. They may be forced to make concessions in order to prevent industrial unrest.

Consequently, the only way of stabilizing collective bargaining is to institutionalise it through legislation. Collective bargaining already exists! This Bill will make agreements enforceable at law and will have a normative effect where and only where, they are entered into voluntarily!
This Bill seeks to overcome four major defects in our systems of compulsory conciliation and arbitration.

Firstly, as the Australian Parliament's power to enact conciliation and arbitration laws is limited to the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes, extending beyond the limits of any one State, it is impossible for there to be a single national mechanism of compulsory conciliation and arbitration. Employers and trade unions are both faced with a multiplicity of Federal and State labour laws, which are more complex and legalistic than are the labour laws of comparable federations such as Canada and the United States of America.

Secondly, Federal and State awards prescribe minimum wage rates and work rules, parties are free to engage in above-award bargaining which is unenforceable at law, and which inevitably leads to instability.

Thirdly, the Australian arbitral tribunals, by their very nature, operate the most centralised labour relations mechanism of all the western industrial democracies, with the exception of Austria. This centralisation prevents the establishment of mature negotiating skills at the work place.

Finally, the limited scope of the industrial power in our Constitution together with the limited scope of the State labour relations laws, inhibits the development of formal industrial relations practices in relation to such matters as consultation between trade unions and employers over the introduction and the implementation of technological changes, redundancy schemes and other management prerogatives.

This Bill is not designed to replace the mechanisms of conciliation and arbitration, but rather to institutionalise collective bargaining so that it operates in tandem with these mechanisms. This Bill acknowledges the major two characteristics of Australian industrial relations: A well developed union structure and the mechanisms of compulsory conciliation and arbitration.

This Bill will provide a legal framework whereby any Federal or State trade union will be able, if it so wishes, to voluntarily enter into negotiations with a corporate employer, and conclude a binding collective agreement on behalf of its members who are employed by that employer. Where a corporate employer employs members of more than one trade union, provision is made to facilitate negotiations between the employer and a chief negotiating association of employees, as the representative of the various trade unions who have members employed by the corporate employer. This mechanism cuts across the grid of Federal and State arbitration laws, minimises demarcation disputes, and of most importance, promotes the growth of mature negotiating skills at the work plant.

It is a voluntary mechanism which neither disrupts nor impinges upon Federal or State arbitral laws. Under this proposal, if trade unions and a corporate employer voluntarily conclude a binding collective agreement, then during the life of the collective agreement the various Federal and State arbitral tribunals will be deprived of jurisdiction (other than with respect to demarcation disputes) to settle any labour relations differences between such trade unions and that corporate employer.

Once a collective agreement is signed, both parties will be expected to comply with it. Consequently, if during the duration of such a collective agreement, wage rates in a relevant award were increased, such an increase would not automatically flow on to employees under such a collective agreement.

The contents of agreements concluded under this proposal would not necessarily be limited to the traditional range of industrial matters which are found in most Federal and State awards. Such agreements could include a wide range of terms and conditions of employment, and could embrace matters specifically relating to trade union and employer relations, such as technological change, redundancy arrangements and job security schemes. To enhance the making of such broad agreements, provision is made for the disclosure of information by the parties at the negotiating stage.

The voluntary nature of this proposal is enhanced by the absence of punitive measures. However, there are provisions to ensure that parties conform to collective agreements which they have voluntarily entered into, and to deprive them from the benefits of this proposal should they fail to comply. If a party to a collective agreement, whether the employer or a trade union, breaches a collective agreement, other than in a matter relating to safety, health or the welfare of employees, then any of the other parties has the automatic right to immediately terminate the collective agreement. The proposal will require every collective agreement to contain a grievance procedure which must be availed of at first instance, to settle any differences which may arise between the parties . After the completion of such a procedure, the parties then have the option of gaining an interpretation of the agreement from the court.

A collective agreement will be a civil contract between the parties. Parties will have recourse to the Federal Court to ensure compliance by other parties. They will be able to sue other recalcitrant parties and to obtain orders requiring the other parties to abide by the agreed terms and conditions of an agreement.

This is the crux of this Bill: That collective agreements should be enforceable at law. This Bill provides a legal framework which will not impinge upon the Federal or State mechanisms of compulsory arbitration. In addition, it takes into account the trade union structure in Australia. In comparable federations such as Canada and the United States where collective bargaining is common, it is possible to operate mechanisms where a single trade union is the exclusive bargaining agent for every employee in a bargaining unit. However, in Australia trade unions are registered under the various conciliation and arbitration statutes and trade union acts. Consequently a system of collective bargaining must recognise this structure and must allow multi-union bargaining within each enterprise. This Bill does this by providing a framework which utilises the existing trade union structure at both Federal and State levels.
By providing a legal framework for voluntary collective bargaining, this Bill acknowledges the realities of Australian industrial life:
Firstly, that collective bargaining already exists and is being extensively practised.
Secondly, that collective bargaining often relates to matters which can never be incorporated in either Federal or State awards.

Thirdly, as the Australian economy recovers, it is likely that trade unions with a significant bargaining power will seek to engage in informal collective bargaining for wage rates and allowances over and above those provided for by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It is crucial to the accord, that should such bargaining occur, that it happens within the framework of a legal mechanism and as a result does not provide pace-setter conditions for all those union members who are not parties to the bargain.

This Bill will be a safety valve for the incomes accord. Over the next several years, it will be necessary for a legal framework such as this to exist if the accord is to be successful. The accord is a delicate balance of forces and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will not be able to maintain that balance without a safety valve such as this Bill. Without a legal framework such as this, the accord is destined to be open to a gradual erosion over the course of time. If the accord is to be successful in the long-term, then this Bill is vital in ensuring that success.
The Australian Democrats are introducing this Bill in the expectation that it will stimulate a considered response not only from this chamber but from within industry and the trade union movement.

The Australian Democrats are not presenting this Bill with a closed mind. It has evolved after discussion and consultation with many people. In particular, it has benefited from the advice and assistance of Graham Smith, lecturer in law at Riverina College of Advanced Education, and Ronald McCallum, senior lecturer in law at Monash University. A Bill such as this will promote consensus within industry, and it is fitting that its final form should be the result of consensus within this chamber. I therefore implore senators to carefully consider this Bill, to discuss it with those involved in industry and the trade unions, before returning to the Committee stage debate.

We will be happy to consider amendments and improvements which are proposed during the Committee stage. If Australia is to avoid becoming a third rate industrial nation, then our industrial relations systems need to adapt and change to reflect the current realities of life. The Collective Agreements ( Corporations) Bill will advance Australia one step nearer to the goal of economic progress in a sound industrial relations environment.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 December 1983, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I talked about the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983 as it pertains to nursing homes. I suggested that the proposed changes in this legislation are in line with the Government's policy of encouraging and assisting elderly people if they make the decision to live out their lives in their homes or in halfway accommodation, for example, in hostels, rather than giving them only one option; that is full nursing home care. Yesterday I referred to the dramatic increase in nursing home appropriations between 1976-77 and 1982-83 for institutional care compared with a much smaller growth in appropriations for assistance for people who do not go into nursing homes. I think we need to be careful not to suggest that cost containment is the only reason for the amendments in the legislation relating to nursing homes. Sometimes it may not be a matter of cost savings but of this Government preferring what is most appropriate and desirable for people, particularly as they become older and may need assistance with ordinary every day living. As I said yesterday, nursing home care is an exercise in overkill when people need assistance only with getting leaves out of gutters or changing light bulbs. Many old people are not sick; they just need assistance to continue living in their homes. If that is their preference this Government is prepared to make money available and introduce legislation to enable that to happen.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, I think we need to consider the assessment teams. In many places in this country they already exist and there are assessment teams which are in the process of being established. There has been some very stern criticism of the assessment teams by and large by the Opposition which preambles its criticism with comments such as: 'We do not really know what they are'. If the Opposition is to criticise things with strong words such as: 'They will coerce patients.', it needs to have a better understanding of what it is frightened about. The assessment teams do not coerce people at all. They are a grouping together of people who have an interest in and a professional understanding of the needs of elderly people. Instead of regarding elderly people as only a medical problem or only a problem of home management, assessment teams will try to bring together expertise in those areas to meet with the elderly person and his or her family or relatives to try to decide what is the best and most appropriate care for that person. The assessment team may well decide that some appropriate domiciliary assistance is what a person needs, rather than nursing home care. I suspect that the Opposition criticises this as being some kind of instrument of coercion-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Hill

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a fear.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sentor CROWLEY-I will address myself to the Opposition's fear as distinct from its criticism. I think that the nature of the fear is that there will be a coercion to keep people out of nursing homes rather than to coerce them into homes. At least, as I understand it, that is how the Opposition's criticism has been running. I cannot imagine that coercion would be applied by the assessment teams to put people into nursing homes, when the seeming thrust of the proposal for changes is to encourage people to stay at home. So I presume that the fear is about a coercion to keep people out of nursing homes if they want to go into them. But as I say, I am not clear at all why people would regard this as some kind of coercion.

In fact, the assessment team will serve a number of purposes. First of all, it will help people and their relatives determine the appropriate form of care. That is really quite a difficult assessment. As I said earlier, it may well be that some frail aged people need nothing more than assistance around the home. It is impossible for an elderly person to change a light bulb when it blows out. Such people need some kind of handyman assistance or a fit and friendly neighbour. Not everybody who is elderly has access to that kind of assistance. The assessment team will address problems seemingly as trite as that. But problems as small as that can make a critical difference to whether people stay on in their own home.

The assessment team will also decide whether a person needs podiatrist care- that specialty has changed its name recently-or whether a person needs some assistance with small housework, if you can call it that, as distinct from the larger maintenance involved in home care. Much of the social or domestic arrangements will also be part of the consideration of the assessment team. As well, the assessment team will address itself to the need for physiotherapy, the need for exercises and perhaps even the need for treatment for loneliness. That is, a visitor may call. It may also address basic medical problems. A frail heart does not necessarily require a person to be in hospital. Most elderly people who have frail hearts live out their lives in the community.

I guess that the thrust of the amendments is to try to assist people with the best kind of appreciation of what will make their lives most manageable in regard to where they choose to live. I also appreciate that some elderly people are not really able to make that choice. It may depend on relatives and wise assistance from relatives. I think that the assessment teams will be a buffer against relatives requiring elderly folk to be incarcerated in institutions, as has sometimes been the situation, and 'forgotten to death', as is sometimes said , or maintained at home so that relatives can collect a fostering allowance, a nursing home allowance or a home care allowance. The assessment team will provide that kind of care and buffer. As well as that, the assessment team will help guide people through the extensive network of assistance programs in the community. I do not know how many people in this chamber claim to know them all. I have certainly dealt with them for some time but still would like to be master of them all. So many bits and pieces of community facilities and assistance are available. The assessment team will also help elderly people cope with those services, to choose those that are most appropriate and most accessible.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many assessment teams are envisaged?

—I will come to that in a moment. Finally, the assessment teams will also give us very important data, if you like, particularly data that will help us identify gaps in the provision of care for elderly people. I do not believe that we can put a hard figure on the number of assessment teams there will be. The efficiency of those already in existence is being assessed and evaluated. More are in the process of being established. Mostly the intention is to establish them in conjunction with what community facilities or services exist, but in some places they may well operate, for instance in rural areas, out of a community hospital or a regional based hospital. They will work very closely with the patient's general practitioner and/or specialists, as is necessary. As I have said, the specialists may include social work specialists, hygienists, podiatrists, and so on, as is necessary rather than as are listed. Again, the number of assessment teams will increase according to and in response to need over the next 12 to 18 months, by which time I think that the Government will be better placed to decide whether that is sufficient or whether more are needed, and the gaps that I mentioned earlier will be becoming clearer; that is, not only the gaps in services but gaps where assessment teams may be needed.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal thrust of the assessment team and the changes in the nursing home legislation is about ensuring this Government's commitment to the care, but particularly the appropriate care, of patients and their support where, as much as possible and as much as is reasonable, it is needed to help people to live their lives according to choices that they make rather than choices or decsions that are made for them. That is what the Bill is about. It is a most appropriate set of amendments. Unlike the Opposition, I have no fears about the consequences of this Bill and the amendments contained therein. I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Legislation Amendment Bill ( No. 2) 1983 is, in the main, a fairly non-contentious Bill. It amends a number of Acts, and generally it does so for the better. The amendments contained in this Bill cover the Health Insurance Act 1973, the National Health Act 1953, the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974, and the Medical Research Endowment Act 1937. One of the tidying up amendments is an amendment concerning referral procedures relating to cleft lip or cleft palate conditions. The problems faced by patients suffering from these two conditions were first brought to my attention a couple of years ago when my long-suffering orthodontist was trying to straighten my teeth, which is no mean feat when they belong to someone in her mid-thirties. He pointed out that the requirement that patients certified as having one of these conditions be formally referred for treatment before service is rendered to them by an accredited dental practitioner before Commonwealth medical benefits could be attracted was an impediment to achieving the best form of treatment. He informed me that at the time a child is born and is diagnosed as having one of these conditions, speed is of the essence; and that particularly with babies born in the country the procedures that were laid down until recently have been an impediment, since the best time to operate on such children is within 24 hours of their birth. So it pleases me that the Government has reacted to the fact that experience has shown that the referral procedure is unnecessarily obstructive and has acted to ameliorate it.

SPEECH.PARA: The major changes contained within this Bill are those involving amendments aimed at improving care of the aged, both in nursing homes and out of them; or rather, they are aimed at extending the range of options for aged care. Many of us in the community have been agitating for this for a long time. People's inclination to institutionalise the elderly or other disabled people has come under considerable fire in recent years as community opinion and expert opinion has moved away from the concept of institutionalised care towards the idea of home-based and day care, and with very good reason. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) said in his second reading speech:
While Australia overall has very adequate provision of nursing home accommodation, its community care and domiciliary services are underdeveloped as are its facilities for hostel care.

There are few people in the community, including those who run or are otherwise involved with nursing homes, who would disagree with the Minister's comment. Indeed, anyone who has read the Hansard record of public hearings held by the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes or who has attended any of the public hearings of that Committee will be aware of the fact that many nursing home proprietors and matrons have been critical of past practices and funding criteria. I am referring to the sort of thing that gives an additional benefit for extended care patients but seems to direct that funding at inappropriate patients on the grounds that extended care patients tend to be defined as those who are bed or chair fast and no allowance is made for the incredible amount of staff, time and care that is required, for instance , in relation to a patient suffering from senile dementia, a wanderer, a patient who is incontinent or who is in some other way a 'burden' on the staff but is not bed or chair fast. It has been pointed out too that there are many inappropriate admissions. People are being placed into nursing homes when really all they need is some sort of short term care that could adequately be provided for them in their own homes if the funds were made available for extended domiciliary care or if facilities were available for day care.

What we need in Australia as far as the care of the aged is concerned-as I have already mentioned this should be extended to care of those people who are disabled at whatever age-is the most flexible system possible, one which caters for the needs of the people concerned, offers the maximum amount of independence and dignity to the elderly, is not price restrictive and is readily accessible as well as administratively viable. If this sounds a tall order I can only say that in fact it is a tall order. It is probably the reason why a great deal of talk has gone on about the need to diversify and extend care of the aged in recent years. But very little action has taken place in the past.

I commend the Government for its action in this regard and I wish it well. There is certainly no place for politics, I believe, when it comes to an area such as this. I was pleased to hear, in speeches made prior to mine both here and in another place, that all parties represented in this Federal Parliament at the moment favour the direction in which this legislation appears to be moving, although I was a little saddened to read one or two slightly churlish comments from the Opposition spokesman in another place in this regard. I will not repeat them at this stage. I think he could have been a little more accommodating and a little more hopeful that the direction in which the Government is moving will bring the results that we all want.

Amendments to the Medical Research Endowment Act are to be applauded in general by all parties represented in this place. These are aimed at bringing management of the fund into line with modern auditing and accounting practices. The second reading speech of the Minister for Health states:

The current position is that the fund, and bequests to it, are maintained in Commonwealth Trading Bank accounts separate from the public account, administered by the Minister for Health, and subject to annual audit by the Commonwealth Auditor-General in accordance with the Act. However, in view of the magnitude of the Government's appropriation to the fund, it is considered appropriate to bring it within the public account and the concomitant audit and accounting provisions.

There certainly will be no argument from me or my Party, as there was none from the Opposition parties, on this matter. One of the matters of concern in this Bill, however, at least as far as some sections of the community are concerned, relates to clause 53 of this omnibus Bill. Clause 53 repeals section 91 of the National Health Act. This clause, in repealing that section of the National Health Act, effectively removes the restrictions applying to a number of friendly society pharmacies in South Australia and Queensland-restrictions which previously prevented them from supplying pharmaceutical benefits to all members of the public regardless of whether they were members of the friendly society.

Considerable concern has been expressed to me, and I believe to other senators and also to members of another place, by the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and individual pharmacists about the effect that the repeal of section 91 of the National Health Act will have. Although the Bill apparently affects only eight pharmacies, three of which are in Queensland and five of which are in South Australia, some very real fears are held that this will disadvantage other pharmacists, specifically in the short term those who have a business in the same district as those eight friendly society pharmacies, and in the long run could eventually lead to a worse problem if State governments allow a proliferation of friendly society pharmacies beyond present numbers. Of course, that is something over which the Federal Government has no control, despite comments by the Opposition's spokesman on health in another place. At this stage I will refer to just one of the more detailed letters that I received from a pharmacist in South Australia. It reads:
Dear Senator Haines,
I protest most strongly at the inclusion of clause 53 in the Health Legislation Amendment Bill and request that it be deleted from the Bill.
My protest is based on a number of factors:-
1. there is no public demand for it.

2. the dispensaries concerned appear to offer some financial advantage in shop purchases to members by offering a discount, but the question is a discount on what? Very often the discounted price is higher than the going rate in the market place.

3. in South Australia, prescription benefits on non-N.H.S. prescriptions are available to the public through all Guild pharmacies to members of Mutual Health Medicine Benefits Fund and now Mutual Health/N.H.S.A. Ancillary Benefits.
He then sets out a comparison on prescriptions for a particular drug which I will not go into at the moment. The letter continues:

4. service provided. I can only speak for myself but I know other Guild pharmacies offer similar services. Very free access to the pharmacist for discussion on medication-health insurance and other allied subjects, e.g. social services, nutrition, childhood illnesses etc. Willingness to come out in the middle of the night for urgent medication-not often these days-but I suggest you try that one on with F.S.M.A.
Free delivery services to anyone but particularly to the aged and infirm-or mothers housebound with sick children. I suggest you try that one on too.
5. by freeing the F.S.M.A. dispensaries from present restrictions, the number of pharmacies will be increased despite the Health Department's claims of too many at present.
6. unfair competition because of taxation advantages will decrease profitability of small businesses and therefore decrease employment opportunities.
Does the present Government support small business? So far I have not seen any evidence of that support.

In the past F.S.M.A. has had the opportunity to open as many pharmacies as they wished-on a restricted franchise to service their own members but have not taken advantage of that opportunity and have never pioneered a new area as have so many Guild members, including myself . . . Service is a word unknown to them. In the light of the foregoing, I can see no public benefit in that portion of the legislation and therefore repeat my request to withdraw it.

I am not in any position to make a comment on the accuracy of any or all of the assertions contained in that letter. Nevertheless, they have been repeated in various forms in letters and telegrams that I have received from other pharmacists so I believe that they should at least be given some consideration. The Opposition spokesperson on health said in his speech in another place on the second reading:

I can understand the concern of community pharmacists in areas close to these eight dispensaries, as there would be a fear of loss of business. However normal businesses compete successfully with co-operatives in a number of areas of the economy, and it is therefore difficult to justify imposing trading restrictions on co-operatives in this particular area.
The Opposition spokesman continued:

Nonetheless I would like to warn the Government that the Opposition would vigorously oppose any further action by the Government to extend any special privileges to pharmacy co-operatives that would enable them to compete unfairly with independent private enterprise pharmacies.

That is very fine sounding, but I fail to see how the Federal Opposition can do anything to prevent action being taken by a State government, for instance, to increase the number of friendly society outlets if the mood takes it and if the parliamentary numbers in that State allow it. Furthermore, I suspect that the happy competition between businesses and co-operatives to which he refers does not have to cope with the tax and other concessions friendly society pharmacists have and which the other pharmacists do not have. I wonder whether, perhaps, this whole thing is not a back door method for rather unfairly increasing competition between some pharmacies and others and, hence, reducing the total number of pharmacies in Australia. That is a commitment which, as far as I understand it, is shared by both political parties. My major criticism of the Bill does not, however, lie in that direction. It is a criticism which centres around what appears to be some fairly innocuous clauses, namely clause 2 (10) and the clauses referred to therein, that is, clauses 35 (1) and 62 (1). Clause 2 (10) states:
Sub-sections 35 (1) and 62 (1) shall be deemed to have come into operation on 1 January 1975.
The explanatory memorandum, in relation to clause 35 (1), states:

This provision ensures that an approval-in-principle is (and was) effective regardless of whether the applicant is (or was) informed under either Act. It is intended to validate past administrative practice.

It is intended to validate past administrative practice. I have been unable to find anywhere, either in the speeches during the second reading debate or in the explanatory memorandum, any reference at all to what practices are being validated and why they need to be made valid retrospectively to 1975. I have spoken privately to the Minister about this. He assured me, also privately, that there is nothing sinister about the retrospective validation and that it relates to procedures operating under one clause because of some misnumbering in an Act somewhere. I am prepared to accept that this is what the Minister has been told, although when I spoke to him we were rather rushed as it was on a day when the Senate bells were ringing fairly continually and he did not have the opportuntity then to give me any detail about what is involved in this retrospective validation back to 1975. I would, of course, appreciate it if the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) who represents the Minister for Health could give me some more detailed explanation of just exactly what is involved.

I am concerned about this not because I suspect anything sinister, underhand or illegal is going on in this validation, but because of a matter that was recently taken up with the Minister for Health by my colleague Senator Macklin who had drawn to his attention a practice known as the pay under scheme. This scheme works roughly this way: A patient is serviced by a medical practitioner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Attended.

—A patient attended a medical practitioner for treatment. Because the treatment provided was not readily benefited under an item number, it was paid out under the item which came closest to that service. This practice leaves the way open to a number of fairly serious problems. Either a medical treatment is entitled to a medical benefit or it is not. If it is not a benefit should not be paid out under some other schedule item. Having been made aware of this classic piece of 'yes ministerism', Senator Macklin put the following questions on the Notice Paper on 21 September 1983:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Is the Department now paying benefits to doctors not covered by item numbers as was suggested in evidence provided to the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts that there had been a number of changes to the medical benefit schedule; if so:
(a) is this practice accepted in the Central Office;
(b) is this practice known as the 'pay-under' item number; and
(c) has there been any objections to this practice from health insurance funds.
(7) Has any advice been received by the Department from the Deputy Crown Solicitor in relationship to the legality of this operation; if so:
(a) has any recommendation been made to lay charges against senior public servants in relation to this matter; and
(b) has the Minister for Health been informed of such advice; if so, what action has the Minister taken.

After repeated requests for an answer, we were forced to resort to the semi- serious threat of holding up passage of clause 2 (10) of this Bill until we got an answer. Late on the day we made that threat the following response was received:

Since the inception of the medical benefits scheme in 1953, it has been the practice that, where a patient receives a legitimate medical service not covered by a specific item in the Medical Benefits Schedule, the payment of benefit under the most appropriate existing item will be authorised by the Department.
The answer to Senator Macklin's question as to whether this practice was known as the pay under item number was yes. The answer went on to say:
The Department is not aware of any objections to 'pay under' items from health insurance funds . . .
In giving advice on another matter, the Deputy Crown Solicitor in Perth referred to earlier advice by the Attorney-General's Department on the legality of 'pay under' items.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Perth?

—I will refrain, Senator Cook, from making any comments at all about the reliability or otherwise of that sort of advice. The answer to Senator Macklin's question about whether any recommendations had or had not been made to lay charges against senior public servants in relation to this matter was no. In response to his question in regard to whether the Minister for Health had been informed of such advice, the answer was:

SPEECH.PARA: Yes. I approved a mechanism for paying benefits for legitimate medical services not specifically listed in the Medical Benefits Schedule so that patients receiving such services are not financially disadvantaged. After consultation with the Attorney-General's Department, appropriate changes to the Medical Benefits Schedule were introduced on 1 November 1983.

I presume that was done via a regulation. At no stage did that answer say whether in fact the practice was or was not illegal, and, if it was not illegal, why there was need for appropriate changes to be made to the MBS and, if it was illegal, why action was not taken. Senator Macklin will be taking up this matter in more detail during the Committee stage of this Bill, but I want to draw it to the attention of the Minister for Social Security now so that he and/or his advisers can prepare themselves for whatever onslaught Senator Macklin has up his sleeve. Neither he nor I find this answer particularly satisfactory. It was a half-hearted response which certainly did not tackle the spirit of the questions raised by Senator Macklin and, given the precedent set by this, I certainly would like an on the record explanation of the clauses that I have referred to and the reasons for there having to be validation of previous action retrospectively to 1975.

In the main, however, I repeat that this Bill covers a number of areas which have been of concern to me, other members of other political parties, members of the community generally and professionals involved in health care, particularly the care of the aged, for some time. It goes some considerable way towards meeting the concerns of people such as those I have mentioned relating to appropriate and adequate care of the aged and of some medical treatments, and the Government is to be commended for this. I hope that it takes further steps in the very near future to bring some other aspects of our health care system into the twentieth century. I suggest, as a start, having a look at some other items that could be made rebatable; for instance, the accommodation charges for parents of hospitalised children. But in the main this Bill is fairly non- contentious. It heads off in the right direction and I join the Opposition and members of the Government in wishing it well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators who have taken part in this debate on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983 and who are not so far-despite Senator Haines's warnings-delaying the Bill untowardly. I will deal first with the problems raised by Senator Haines, as I think she raised more problems than any other honourable senator, in the hope of answering them now rather than in the Committee stage. I will deal first with the problem she raised concerning the retrospective provisions of the Bill, provisions which, I note, honourable senators were alerted to in the Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 14 in November, when the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills drew attention to the fact that there is retrospective operation of clauses 35 (1), 62 (1) and 61 (1) of the Bill. I think the explanation is as Senator Haines outlined it. These are largely technical changes. They correct drafting errors in sections 4 (3) and 5 (2) of the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974. These provisions refer to difficulties which have arisen because there were incorrectly cited sub-sections in that legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The references concerned do not properly identify the correct provisions in the legislation under which applications are made, or the provisions empowering the permanent head of the Department to refuse applications. Clauses 35 (1) and 61 ( 1) correctly identify the provisions relating to refusal of applications as sections 40AA (3) of the National Health Act and 4 (3) of the Nursing Homes Assistance Act. Section 5 (2) of the Nursing Homes Assistance Act amended section 40AA of the National Health Act by reference. Clause 35 (1) of this Bill would insert in the National Health Act with the necessary corrections what is currently provided by reference in section 5 (2) of the Nursing Homes Assistance Act. It is not surprising that this sort of thing happens in complicated legislation such as this, particularly in the number of amendments we have had over the years. The section referred to, 5 (2), would therefore no longer be required and would subsequently be repealed by the relevant sub-clause in this Bill.

I believe that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) has assured concerned members of the Parliament and members of the public that the proposed amendments will not affect in any way undertakings given by the Department of Health to proprietors or intending proprietors of nursing homes that applications for approval of premises as approved nursing homes would not be refused, subject of course to the other requirements of the legislation. So these amendments will correct technical drafting errors in the legislative provisions relating to what are termed approvals in principle of nursing homes for the purposes of Commonwealth benefits. They correct simple errors of citation and would certainly not trespass on any of the personal rights or liberties of any person in a retrospective way. It is also worth pointing out I think that the provisions which would be affected by the amendments in question will in fact be superseded by the new approvals-in-principle provisions in this Bill. These will be brought into effect by proclamation as soon as the proposed principles governing approvals-in-principle have been prepared and promulgated. That means that there is a guarantee that the retrospective provisions in fact will not affect the civil liberties or actions of anyone in the past and that in the future the new approvals-in-principle will cover it.

Senator Haines raised the matter of the friendly societies and the friendly society pharmacies. In doing so she quite correctly read the letters of representation she has had from individual pharmacists and in fact the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, which became quite exercised about this matter after the legislation had been through the House of Representatives. First of all let me say that it is my advice, my belief and, I think, my knowledge that in fact the previous Government's changes to the taxation provisions as they affect friendly society pharmacies have resulted in there being no unfair competition, as far as taxation is concerned, between those friendly society pharmacies and community pharmacies or privately owned pharmacies. I believe they are now equal. I believe if the Pharmacy Guild has examples of what it believes are unfair tax advantages with the friendly societies, it should make a case to the Government about that. To my knowledge it has not.

Senator Haines also raised the question that first of all this may be a back door way of increasing the number of friendly society pharmacies, and secondly a back door way, by unfair competition, of cutting down the number of pharmacies, which we all accept will inevitably happen in this country. I think that flies in the face of what has happened, quite apart from the fact that the registration, licensing or otherwise of friendly society pharmacies or other pharmacies is a State matter. In the past the maximum number of full approvals under the existing legislation of friendly society pharmacies has been considerably higher than the number of friendly society pharmacies which operate now. In fact apart from in the States of Queensland and South Australia the number of friendly society pharmacies in more than recent times, in the last 10 or 20 years, has dropped away. They have not increased. Under the existing legislation, and under the previous legislation before the tax changes were made , when they actually had an advantage, still the number of friendly society pharmacies decreased. I will give some examples of the number of full approvals under the existing legislation. For New South Wales it was 16, the current approvals are three; in Victoria it was 65, the current approvals, as at 6 December 1983, were 32; in Western Australia, the maximum number was 10 but there is now only one; in Tasmania there were three and there are still three, now; and similarly in Queensland and South Australia the numbers have not changed. So this legislation and the changes made to this legislation are not a back door way of allowing the friendly society pharmacies to boom in any way. In fact the changes sensibly correct an anomaly which exists in the legislation.

Senator Haines also raised the matter of the problems of pay under items under the medical benefits system and how she and her colleague Senator Macklin have received unsatisfactory answers to this matter. I have been plaintively sitting here for the last four or five sessions of Question Time waiting for a question on this matter so I could give a very detailed and erudite answer, but no one asked me any questions on the matter. Perhaps I can take this opportunity to give everyone a little lecture on this problem and I may head off the onslaught that Senator Haines said we were going to get from Senator Macklin during the Committee stage.

First of all, there is a matter of background. As Senator Haines said, where a medical procedure is not covered by a specific item in the medical benefits schedule, it has been long-standing departmental practice to advise the doctor of the nearest appropriate item number and benefits will be paid under that item .

TALK.START.PARA: —But why? Why not just come up with another item number?

—Just a minute; just calm down. We will go step by step or the honourable senator might get me confused. In a strictly legal sense, a prosecution for medical fraud, a charge that the doctor did not provide the services described by the item number, could in fact have been laid. A possible prosecution for fraud in Western Australia had to be dropped because of the use of the pay under item. In a strictly legal sense--
—Is that because the doctor was doing it, instead of the bureaucrat?

—Yes. In a strictly legal sense, because the doctor is using an item number which does not properly describe the services rendered, it could be considered as fraud. This case and the potential case brought to the Department' s attention the distinction between pay under, which is the sanctioned use of an inappropriate item where there is only a small difference between the actual service rendered and that described by the schedule item, and 'fraud', which is the unsanctioned use of an inappropriate item number where there is a substantial difference between the actual service rendered and that described by the schedule item.
—It is a matter of judgment, is it, at the borderline?

—It is, as it so often is. Advice was then received, as would be expected, from the Attorney-General's Department on 7 March 1983 that pay under was not in accordance with the provisions of the National Health Act. This led to the Crown Solicitor in Western Australia advising the Department not to proceed with a particular case of fraud. A remedy was found, as Senator Haines suggested, through the insertion of a specific item in the schedule to be used where a procedure is not adequately described by a particular schedule item. The Medical Benefits Advisory Committee then determines an appropriate schedule fee for the procedure to allow the benefits to be paid.

SPEECH.PARA: From my reading of this matter, I think what in fact has happened is that the loose pay under procedure operated perfectly happily for years until two things happened. Firstly, the lawyers got wind of it and, as so often happens, declared it illegal.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they cannot declare it illegal when it was not illegal-only governments can do that.

—Well, in the strict legal sense it was illegal. The second thing that happened was, of course, that the procedure interfered with the prosecution of fraud cases. A solution was found through the insertion of this specific item in the schedule to overcome that difficulty. Pay under, although technically illegal, was not improper and was not untoward. The pay under item was used as a means of paying benefits for legitimate medical services which were just not covered by the list of scheduled fees. This situation will occur as it always has occurred from time to time. Pay under, I suppose, was an administrative response to a definite need and it had been used by governments for many years. It may be bad administrative practice as it led to the payment of benefits outside the National Health Act. However, in fact, it covered a need which I suggest is always going to exist when a fee for service payment system of this type exists.

SPEECH.PARA: When the legal advice was received early this year, the Department of Health had a remedy in place within six months. One can only regret that poor administrative practice contributed to the dropping of a potential case of fraud . However, the Government is determined to make an all out effort against fraud. Therefore, it was important to make this correction. I believe that the result will be satisfactory until the lawyers find something wrong with it too.

Senator Hill, who also spoke on the legislation, was concerned about the implications of the Government's view that the overall level of supply of nursing home beds in Australia was in fact adequate. He expressed reservations about how geriatric units will operate in practice in view of the often stated belief that one in five nursing home patients do not require nursing home care. Senator Crowley also spoke about the importance of assessment teams in this area . I think we all have a very real concern that we do not want elderly people unnecessarily in nursing homes, first of all, because it is inappropriate for old people who are not in need of the sort of attention that is and should be delivered in nursing homes and, secondly, because nursing homes are by far the most expensive form of accommodation for the aged or the frail aged.

The Government's fundamental position is that the needs of aged people should be assessed by people skilled in carrying out such assessments and that they should be then guided to available services that best meet their needs. I want to impress on the Senate and the Parliament in general that that does not mean we believe that a group of technocrats, particularly medical technocrats, should make all the decisions on what is appropriate for frail aged people or should try to slot people into little boxes. We certainly need a better system than exists now because in some areas the number of people who are in nursing homes but who do not require nursing home care is considerably more than one in five. In fact it has been the practice in the past, particularly in the times when nursing homes were booming in this community in the post-war years, in the 1950s and 1960s, and when social changes were occurring wherever people were not keeping their elderly parents and relatives at home with them, that some unscrupulous people quite selectively picked only the fittest and best people to go into their nursing homes and therefore received the greatest benefit for the least outlay. I think the assessment units have that first function; they can direct people to the appropriate level of care. They can make sure that the community is providing a proper balance of care and they can assist also in identifying where there are gaps in service provisions. One of the things that bedevil welfare planning in this country is the lack of proper data, the lack of any idea of just what is going on and who should be where.

At present there is an imbalance in the provision of government resources for aged care services. We believe that the nursing home sector receives a disproportionate support relative, for instance, to hostels and certainly relative to community services. There is a need to redress that imbalance if our aged people are to receive the care most appropriate to their needs. In most cases that care should be given in their own homes and certainly in their own community. This does not mean for a minute that there are not areas where additional nursing home accommodation is needed and will be approved. Of course there will be a continuing need for additional nursing home accommodation as the aged population increases.

Senator Hill expressed his concern at the Government's failure to, as he called it, approve more nursing home accommodation and he spoke about how this was affecting communities that had raised money, et cetera. I suspect that he has a misconception and does not realise the difference between the approvals in principle which, at the moment, are given by the Department of Health and the approvals for funding, the capital funding approvals, which at the moment-I repeat 'at the moment'-are given by the Department of Social Security. Certainly since this Government has been in office, the Department of Health has not given any further approvals in principle. Certainly the Minister for Health has announced that additional staff will be provided to process applications for approvals in principle for additional nursing home accommodation. We have deferred further applications for approvals in principle since March 1983. The Minister is anxious that, in areas where additional accommodation is needed, the new procedures for granting approvals in principle provided in this Bill will be put into effect as quickly as practicable and we are seeking staff to do that.

But approvals for funding, for those who have already received approvals in principle, are going on as normal. Last year the Government, from memory, approved a batch in November for funding for the year ahead, as has been normal procedure in recent years and it approved another batch in February. I had harsh things to say about a couple as they were approved in the period between the time the election was called and the time the election was held, which I question. At the moment I have before me another set of recommendations which will go to Cabinet for approval of funding of such homes in the next Budget, 12 months ahead, to give people the opportunity to get cracking if they have the funds available now. It is important to realise that those differences occur. It is important to realise that there is a difference between the two departments which make the approvals. That difference will not last very long as we are about to establish an office of aged care so that the various functions of caring for the frail aged which are at the moment split between the Department of Social Security and the Department of Health will be put together. I think then we will get a more satisfactory situation and, under those circumstances, people will not be confused by the difference between approvals in principle and the functions of the two departments. I thank the Senate for its expedition of this legislation. I am sure it will improve our health scheme. As I have said so many times in the past, it is not the last change we will have to make to make it satisfactory.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address myself to clause 2 basically in which certain operations which were raised by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills are made retrospective to 1 January 1975 and 13 December 1974 respectively. The issue which has already been canvassed and replied to by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) seems to me to be of more concern than to be simply brushed under the table as his reply seemed to suggest. The knowledge of the illegality of the pay under system seems to go back quite some time. Indeed, the relevant legislation, the Health Insurance Act 1973, makes it an offence to present an incorrect account to the Com- monwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spent some considerable time to try to get from the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) information preceding the advent of this Government. The earliest documentation I have been able to get is a memorandum from the Attorney-General' s Department dated 7 March 1983. To the question: 'Are the pay under arrangements described above authorised by the Act'? the answer is no. Reference is made to the memoranda which have been sent I presume under the designation of the Director-General of the Department of Health, on this whole affair. I believe that under the previous Government-possibly under both governments previous to this Government, the Whitlam Government, and the Fraser Government- considerable medical fraud may have resulted directly out of the decision of various members of the Public Service that what the Parliament had done was not correct and it was far better to do it some other way. This is not the only instance where we are likely to find this but in this instance there is serious concern.

As I understand it, basically what happens now is that the pay under item could really leave open the entire field of fraud and overservicing, particularly its detection. Section 129 (3) of the Health Insurance Act makes it possible for a practitioner to argue that she or he could not reasonably have been expected to know that what she or he did was an offence under the legislation. The Minister referred to this matter. As I understand the way the legislation has worked, it is a defence for a practitioner to argue that the word of a departmental officer approving the use of an incorrect item number is a sufficient excuse. If that were the case, it is extremely difficult for the Federal Police, the health insurance fund personnel, the Crown Solicitor or anybody else actually to discover what is going on. The Minister referred to a memorandum from the Deputy Crown Solicitor on 21 September involving a case which could have had fairly wide ramifications-not a small amount of money-and which was really frustrated by the fact that what the doctor said he was doing was already being done by people within the Department.

I question whether the illegality of this activity was not known to senior members of the Department earlier than 7 March. It is almost impossible to accept that that was the case. If it was, it suggests gross incompetence that they did not know that this was occurring or that the Commonwealth was being defrauded of moneys by this method. It is all very well to say, as the Minister has said, that it was an administrative necessity to do it this way. There may be all sorts of administrative necessities, but an administrative necessity which actually turns out to be illegal is not an administrative necessity at all . An illegality in these circumstances which is against the intent of the Parliament could have been reorganised in many other ways. It could have been addressed and solved simply by bringing to the Parliament a legislative amendment, as was suggested by the Attorney-General's Department quite a long time ago, or by actually scheduling numbers for which items could be paid. It seems that the Department, as part of its excuse in the past, has suggested a rather interesting notion of what 'relates to' means in the definition of ' professional service' in section 3 (1) of the Act. The idea that 'relates to' could in fact cover so much is knocked on the head by the Attorney-General's Department saying that it is in the sense of being covered by or corresponding to a particular item in the Act. It is not sufficient in the opinion of the Attorney-General's Department for a service to be merely compatible with an item in the table.

I am quite sure that the Parliament had no intention of simply allowing anybody to come up with items which he felt were compatible with the Act. Rather, the Parliament intended that items raised specifically by this Parliament should be able to be paid-services rendered by medical practitioners to their clients and claimed for specifically under those items, with no legal claim possible for those which fell outside the table. That has now been belatedly accepted, at least by this Government. I do not want to be too harsh on the current Government. After all, it has moved with what one might consider great rapidity on this matter; it has taken only six months. The previous Government did nothing at all in seven years. It is almost impossible to get into this and actually to find out what went on, yet I expect that it has been known for a great period. It may have been the avenue by which a great deal of medical fraud was committed on the revenue. At least there is that possibility. We do not know what has occurred because it is impossible to get hold of information. We are unaware of what has gone on. I do not believe it can be brushed aside quite so easily. It is a serious matter. It ought to be dealt with as a serious matter.

I do not like this type of legislation which, in the case I am referring to and in the case of the legislation before us, seeks simply by retrospective provisions to fix up some administrative practices. I believe that this type of legislation should never come before this House. If we condone or play down the seriousness of these types of activities on the part of the bureaucracy the Parliament is not carrying out its duty. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts, of course, has undertaken a thorough investigation into this matter. I am not satisfied that the information supplied to that Committee was necessarily always accurate. I do not intend to put this matter aside. I believe that it ought to have been dealt with much more frankly than it has been.

The answers to questions which I have had on notice for some time were expertly drawn; I must admit that. They failed to answer any of the intent of my questions but answered technically every question I put to the Minister. That is a game that a couple of people can play. I certainly will be pursuing the matter . I believe that we need a full and frank disclosure of when first the pay under item was acknowledged by any senior member of the Department of Health to be illegal, who in the Department of Health knew that it was illegal, who condoned the continual operation of the pay-under system with the knowledge that it was illegal, and who failed to respond to either the previous or the current Minister for Health about the illegality of that activity?

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say that a claim should not have been made at all?

—I am not talking about the medical practitioners. I have no knowledge about the medical practitioners because it is not possible to know what the medical practitioners were doing. Indeed, I have just suggested that they probably had a very good reason and a very good escape clause for doing what they were doing. The Act allows them to do that. If the bureaucracy allowed them to claim under a particular item or suggested that they do so, a practitioner cannot be held at fault.
—If an inadequacy is discovered in the schedule, surely the answer is to correct that anomaly.

—Any inadequacy in the Schedule could easily have been fixed up. The suggestion by the Attorney-General's Department was to do so by legislative amendment, which is a relatively painless operation. I do not believe that this House, when confronted with the problems that were said to be of administrative necessity, would have failed to pass such an amendment. I refer to the fact that the situation has been allowed to continue for so long and that something which was known to be illegal was still being done. That is what I am objecting to.
—But if you say the doctors were entitled to make a claim, how could it be illegal?

—It was illegal activity on the part of the bureaucracy. They were paying under items under which they were not entitled to pay. This has been accepted; it has been the case, but I do not believe that a full understanding of that illegal activity has been given to this Parliament.
—Is it illegal?

—I am sorry; I will read the question and answer again. To the question 'Are the pay under arrangements described above authorised by the Act?' , the Attorney-General's answer was 'No'. They are not authorised by the Act. It is a plain and simple answer. The problem as I see it is that it is very difficult for either committees of this Parliament or members of the Parliament itself, if we have such tremendous problems wading through the type of material we get back when we place questions on notice, to fulfil the duties that are imposed on us. We should get full, frank and detailed answers to the types of questions that are raised and the answers ought to be provided much more quickly than in this case, where the material requested was with the Department. I have now been able to get hold of that material, but not in a simple way. The fobbing off and the chasing around that go on in these matters are extraordinary.

SPEECH.PARA: If a mistake is made I think it will be readily owned up to. I do not think anybody in this Parliament is interested in going on a witch hunt. I think we want to make sure in future, if any activity undertaken on behalf of anybody in the bureaucracy is discovered to be illegal, that prompt action is taken and that we do not wait for years to find out about it, and then find out only by the actions of a committee of this Parliament, such as the operations in terms of medical fraud of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts which turned up this type of problem. It seems to me that there is an obligation on the bureaucracy and on governments to act and to act rapidly in relation to any such matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister for Social Security) (11.16)-I shall attempt to answer Senator Macklin again, ignoring the fact that the matter he raised has nothing to do with this legislation and is not mentioned in the legislation at all, but he still deserves a further answer. I really cannot help thinking that he is making a bit much of this matter. First of all, changes have been made because it was pointed out that the administrative practice of paying under was illegal.
—Was that known only on 7 March this year?

—My information and knowledge is that that was known on 7 March this year. Senator Macklin may have some knowledge that people knew it was illegal before that. It was, as I said when I mentioned it previously, an administrative response by people in the Department of Health-admittedly, it was technically illegal-to a situation of definite need.
