I point out to Senator Macklin that if we have a system of fee for service whereby fees are paid to doctors or anybody else for a multitude of technical procedures laid down by the Parliament, and those technical procedures do not cover all the things that the doctors or the other technicians do, it is inevitable that there-
—Some administrative response is needed.

—There has to be some administrative response to what happens. I will take the next step. Certainly the administrative response was bad administrative practice, certainly it was technically illegal, and certainly in one case it was partly responsible for dropping a case of fraud against a doctor . When that was pointed out to the Government and to the Department the situation was changed and a new item was put in the schedule. That is what happened. Nobody is questioning those facts. I do not think we can be more frank than that. I do not think anyone in the previous Government would have had any worries, once that matter was drawn to their attention, about pointing out that the reason for the practice was to fulfil a need. Maybe it was not a good thing. Sure, technically it did not follow the extact intent of the legislation put forward by the Parliament, but the real intent of the previous legislation was to ensure that doctors and patients were refunded money for all those various items on the schedule.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Schedule was not complete and if the Department in its wisdom could not, as it cannot, cover every item, there was a need for some practice whereby people-not only doctors but also patients-could be covered under that schedule. The problem is that Senator Macklin sees a great evil conspiracy between members of the Departmen of Health and doctors. I do not know why else-

TALK.START.PARA: —Because it took so long to get the answer back.

—I do not see why else he cannot accept the fact that what we said is true. An administrative practice was brought up to cover a need. The practice was not good; the practice was illegal. It had unfortunate results, and as soon as that was pointed out to this Government it was changed. What more can we do?
—I have accepted that.
—I do not know what the honourable senator has not accepted, other than the fact that answers took a long time to come back.
—What I have not accepted is that 7 March was the first time anybody knew about it.

—I will find out. The question is whether the Department knew that the practice was illegal, whether it had an opinion from the Attorney- General's Department or any- one else before 7 March. I will certainly find that out.
—Not an opinion; that they knew about it. It is in writing. I just have not a copy yet.
—That they knew the practice was illegal?
—Yes.

—But I put it that there are practices that are illegal and practices that are 'illegal', in inverted commas. For heaven's sake, one can say : 'Look, the practice that was followed to correct that need was wrong and inefficient'. That is fair enough. I believe that it has now been corrected.
—I take it that there was no element of fraud involved in this practice?

—The practice was, in fact, to cover that situation. I believe that there is no suggestion, even from Senator Macklin, that although the practice may have been inappropriate, it was improper, given that it was trying to cover a definite need. The senator seems to think that the new procedures should have been introduced much earlier. He may be right or wrong, but it is drawing a long bow then to look for a conspiracy between officers of the Department of Health and doctors who were indulging in fraud before that. I think that he needs more evidence before he comes forward with that sort of suggestion. I just remind him of the old saying around this place, that if you have a choice between a conspiracy and a muck-up you can bet your life it is a muck-up every time. That is probably what happened here.
—I wish to use the opportunity afforded by the wide-ranging debate and questioning that has been allowed on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) to raise a query.

—Order! Before the honourable senator goes any further, I say that this is a 56-page Bill and I was unable to determine whether Senator Macklin was out of order. It was suggested that his remarks were not relevant. If I think that the honourable senator is becoming wide-ranging, I will ask him to inform me of the clause of the Bill to which he is referring.

—As a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts who was involved in the inquiry into medical fraud and over-servicing, I support the protection of the revenue from unjustifiable claims on the part of a very small proportion of very unscrupulous medical practitioners, but I ask that some sensitivity be shown in the selection of the doctors investigated. I have in mind doctors who may never have been counselled, may never have been challenged, may never have been fined. I hope there will be a positive response to my question of the Minister. I ask: Has there been a direction by the Department of Health that investigators go unannounced and uninvited into doctors' surgeries and waiting rooms, armed with a stop watch, and time the duration of patients' consultations with doctors?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do know of suggestions of behaviour on the part of investigators such as Senator Watson referred to. My personal view of people who, in conducting inquiries, indulge in that sort of nonsense-sitting people in waiting rooms armed with stop watches and indulging in indiscriminate questioning of patients-is that it is disturbing . It has been brought to my attention and I am in the process of finding out just what has gone on. I brought it up yesterday. I know of cases such as have been referred to by Dr Watson-I mean Senator Watson-but I have Sherlock Holmes working on it and we will see what happens.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983 (No. 4)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 November 1983, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill (No. 4) which is now before the Senate represents the third attempt to pass measures extending the bottom of the harbour legislation. It is anticipated raising under the provisions of this Bill an additional $40m, $20m of which would be received this year. As well, the Bill provides an escape clause for public company shareholders who received no benefit and were not involved in the management of the company. That clause is included at a cost to revenue of about $5m.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is opposed to this Bill with one exception, to which I will refer later. The Opposition is consistent in this approach to the legislation because it took these steps when legislation of this kind was introduced last year, in May and a few weeks ago, and we have the same view now. At the time the 1982 legislation was going through there were attempts to include amendments to which the then Government objected. Our view is quite consistent. I state quite shortly that the sole objective of the 1982 legislation was the recoupment of unpaid company tax, without penalty or discrimination, from those who had derived a financial benefit from its non-payment. It was fundamental to that legislation that if one did not benefit from the tax evasion one did not receive an assessment for taxation to be paid.

According to the explanatory memorandum circulated with this legislation, the Bill seeks to repeat some provisions from earlier legislation which ensure that liability for recoupment tax will not be escaped by reason of an ultimately unsuccessful post-sale or pre-sale tax avoidance scheme. It authorises the Commissioner of Taxation to name in his annual report persons who fail to pay an assessed recoupment tax liability in respect of unpaid company tax. It purports to remove the text which requires that an arrangement which rendered a company unable to pay its tax must be identified before a recoupment tax liability can be established. It also provides relief from liability to vendors recoupment tax in certain anomalous public company cases. It varies the evidentiary provision to ensure the constitutional validity of the 1982 legislation and it corrects some minor technical defects.

To make the position of the Opposition quite clear on this legislation, the Opposition will oppose all of the measures with the exception of one clause and we will seek to amend that clause. The clause we will be able to support provides relief from liability in certain public company cases. Our amendment will have the effect of seeking to apply that relief also to private company cases. We believe that the provisions now before us again are unnecessary, that they are discriminatory and that they are penal provisions. Of course, they are to be applied retrospectively, which has been our objection to the legislation in the form we have received it from the present Government on previous occasions.

The matter brought forward in this legislation with regard to the evidentiary nature of the certificate of the Commissioner of Taxation we believe is not timely. This matter has been litigated before the High Court of Australia and the normal practice of the Parliament is not to anticipate court decisions. All parties would need to consider the situation if the High Court decided against the validity of the existing legislation. We believe that that is a consideration to be made some time in the future; it is not one to be made in relation to the Bill that is before us at present.

It ought to be said that the tax avoidance industry was dead by the time the present Government came into office. The tax avoidance industry was affected by the new Part IVA, the general anti-avoidance provision, which was put into the Income Tax Assessment Act in May 1982. Tax avoidance was also affected by the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act which was passed in 1980. It was those actions of the former Government and not the 1982 recoupment legislation that had the effect of stopping the tax avoidance industry in this country. The 1982 recoupment legislation was limited to the recoupment of about $600m of evaded company tax which was left unpaid as a result of arrangements which were the target of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. The provision which we are able to support does ameliorate to some extent the legislation that was passed in 1982 by providing that some partial matters may come before the Commissioner of Taxation. Perhaps we can speak more about that matter at the Committee stage.

I refer briefly to section 6 (18) of the legislation, which was a matter of some public discussion quite recently when the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, made public the dispensation under this section. It ought to be said that in the opinion of the former Treasurer and certainly of the Opposition that was a proper use of the legislation. It was the intention of the legislation. However, hundreds of other public company shareholders must be in the same position as the Minister to whom I referred. They would expect to receive the same treatment and I would expect that the Commissioner would apply the same treatment to them. These dispensations made under the 1982 legislation do not stem from some action by the present Government. They extend from the legislation that was passed in 1982. That was the proper use and the intent of our recoupment legislation.

It has been said each time the recoupment legislation has been brought forward that the rejection of its retrospective effects would force a rise in taxation levies of one kind or another. I think those claims have been dealt with on each occasion that the legislation has been before us. Rejection of the legislation that is before the Senate today would, according to the Minister's statement, cost about $60m in revenue if all the collections that were expected to be made did eventuate. That sort of reduction in collections has not worried the present Government in other cases, even in the present Budget. The changes that were made by the Government to its legislation cost revenue between $80m and $90m. At that time the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, said: 'What is $ 80m or $90m in a Budget of this size? It is nothing in the overall totality of things. It has no impact at all on the Government's economic strategy'. In 1981, when we were dealing with the sales tax legislation, Senator Gareth Evans, Senator Button and Senator Walsh all said: 'What is $135m in the overall collection of revenue in a Budget of something like $45 billion?' To place any emphasis on a collection of some $20m this year or $60m under the legislation means that it cannot be regarded as of serious financial consequence to the Government. Rather, it needs to be seen as legislation implementing objectives of the Government to collect revenue to that extent.

On a number of occasions the Opposition has stated its opposition to the retrospective application of the Government's unpaid company tax legislation. We are consistent in those views, as I have already expressed. Our views on the various provisions within this legislation are well known and well stated. They have been recorded on a number of occasions. We have consistently felt the need to oppose this legislation. When dealing with this legislation at the Committee stage we will move an amendment which will have the effect of extending the amelioration provision to private companies. To simplify the Committee stage, I indicate that all other provisions will be opposed by us.

I hope that this Bill can be dealt with at this stage of the sittings of the Senate in a fairly speedy manner. If it is expected that we need to consider every clause during the Committee stage, so be it as far as the Opposition is concerned. But I state in as brief a manner as I am able that the provisions that have previously been opposed by us will consistently be opposed by us. On this occasion, because we wish to move an amendment during the Committee stage, the Bill will be given a second reading. But that does not indicate our support for any of the provisions other than the one I have mentioned, to which we will move the amendment that has been circulated in my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has spoken at yet another stage of this long saga of frustration and hindrance by the Opposition of measures which are absolutely essential to the carrying out of the mandate bestowed on the Labor Government on 5 March to deal with tax avoidance and evasion and its consequences within our society. On that day earlier this year the people of Australia elected a government with the will and the integrity to carry through an assault on tax avoidance. But time and time again- the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 (No. 4) is the third such Bill this year-the Opposition has spoken, sometimes accompanied by one or two Australian Democrats although not all by any means, in order to frustrate and impede the passage of legislation to deal with what is coloquially known as the bottom of the harbour scheme and its consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps that is a symbol of the general laxity of the administration of the tax laws under the former Government, which has led, as I say, to the situation which we are trying to attack, with the mandate of the Australian people. If the Opposition continually fails to acknowledge that mandate perhaps later next year we will have to go to the people and seek to have that mandate renewed. I think that debates such as this, and opposition such as we are experiencing today, will come back to haunt the Opposition. Not only do we have the mandate of the people generally but, as I am sure my colleague Senator Peter Cook from Western Australia will elaborate on, the accord with the unions in February this year also acknowledged that part of the understanding between the Labor Government and the representatives of organised workers throughout Australia embraced the notion that an assault on tax avoidance and evasion would take place using all the legislative and administrative measures open to us. In April, the National Economic Summit Conference was held. Once again I will read from the communique of that Conference:

All parties believe that there is a special obligation in the current environment to ensure that artificial tax avoidance and tax evasion is removed, including in the cash economy, and for the further development of a general understanding to this effect.
It goes on:
The Summit agrees that action should be taken to improve the equity and efficiency of the Australian taxation system.

Indeed, we see these paragraphs flowing backwards and forwards between each other. One objective cannot be achieved without the other. We cannot have an equitable taxation system without an assault on tax avoidance and evasion. This Bill is part of that assault by this Government.

The fact is that the Bill is only a very modified, modest version of proposals that have been brought into this chamber from time to time this year. This Bill deals only with measures to strengthen and improve the recovery of evaded company tax. To that extent, as I say, it is a much more modest Bill. It will raise only a certain amount of revenue, in the tens of millions of dollars rather than hundreds of millions. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, in relation to that, says: 'You have forgone revenue in relation to other Budget announcements, and therefore, why can you not do it here? It is only a question of $20m this financial year and $60m overall'. The modifications made to certain Budget announcements which did have a cost to revenue were made in order to achieve equity, in order not to disrupt industry, with all the consequent ramifications for employment, when it was found that particular figuring led to very dire impacts and consequences. In other words, the forgoing of revenue in those instances was in order to achieve equity in the impact of the taxation system. Therefore, there is no analogy. This Bill is required in order to achieve equity within the taxation system, and yet the Opposition, as I say, refuses to countenance these measures.

These measures are necessary because of the situtation that was displayed to the Australian people, in particular late last year. The ordinary honest Australian taxpayer, whether as an individual under the pay as your earn system or as a small firm or enterprise which took ethical legal and accounting advice, was really made out to be a mug, to be someone who was rather foolish in paying his proper contribution to the revenues of the Government so that it could carry out the programs for which it was elected. I say this in relation to a Liberal government or a Labor government. It is entitled to a fair contribution from every Australian person and enterprise in order to carry out its programs. Rather, we saw the perverting of the best legal and accounting brains in this country to serve the selfish ends of certain individuals, so that, as Professor Mathews, Australia's leading academic commentator on our taxation system was led to say, at a seminar at the Australian National University, the payment of taxes by the rich in Australia had become discretionary, and it was a matter of their judgment as to whether they felt that they might make some contribution to Australia's revenues for the purposes of government; whereas the ordinary taxpayer had to bear a greater burden than would otherwise have been the case.

Time and again the taxation burden on ordinary Australians or Australian enterprises was greater than it would otherwise have been. Alternatively, Australian governments had to borrow more abroad or from the Australian people, and thereby increase the deficit, the debt to which we all have to contribute in the end in order to pay it off, or the programs of Australian governments had to be curtailed, frustrated, done away with, modified or not even put into place because of a lack of revenue. The programs of the democratically elected Government have been distorted and twisted in response to the very selfish perverting of the best legal and accounting brains in Australia to the selfish ends of the tax avoiders and evaders.

As a government, we came into office with a very clear mandate, endorsed by the National Economic Summit Conference, to bring that to an end. The aiding and abetting of and the conniving at tax avoidance and evasion which were features of the previous Government are continuing with the continued opposition to tax reform today. When the Opposition was in government, that opposition to reform was well exemplified in the maladministration by the previous Attorney-General in relation to the activities of the Crown Solicitor's Division, which was brought to the light of day by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The failure of those now opposite was not only in relation to the legislative program; the administration program was particularly shackled by the refusal to provide the Commissioner of Taxation with those sinews of war which he required to go into battle on behalf of the people. We have not only brought in legislation to deal with that but we have provided those sinews of war and we are winning the battle even though we are occasionally hindered and frustrated by the sort of opposition that has been evidenced in the chamber today.

Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle once again raised the question of retrospectivity in general as a reason for not supporting this measure. Once again one must come into this chamber and say that whilst it is true that Australia is heir to a long tradition in the common law, deriving from English legal principles and the manner in which the Westminster system has operated in relation to retrospective laws, even that tradition has acknowledged that in relation to the taxation law, revenue law, one has to adopt a standard that is different from that adopted in relation to criminal or penal legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Still a minority view.

—It is not a minority view. It was taken into the tax legislation of the United Kingdom and was approved by the Master of the Rolls, Lord Greene, in 1946 in a key judgment-the Master of the Rolls, as you will know, Mr Acting Deputy President, is the custodian of the common law tradition in England-in which, in 1946, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the Section--
in the United Kingdom legislation-

has to some extent a retrospective effect again appears to us of no importance when it is realised that the legislation is a move in a long and fiercely- contested battle with individuals who well understand the rigour of the contest.

Surely that is what we have here, a contest between, as I said, those using legal and accounting devices to evade taxation and the just demands of the Australian Govenment for a contribution to revenue. Indeed, the Australian Financial Review in a comment on the rejection of a similar Bill earlier this year by the Opposition-the Australian Financial Review is not the most radical journal in Australia's political or financial life; in fact I would say that it is far from trendy-stated:

. . . non-retrospectivity of the tax law is by no stretch of the imagination an absolute moral or political value . . . Clearly, retrospectivity is more a serious issue with respect to criminal law than with respect to income tax law.

That is precisely the stand that we, in Government, take. The Australian Financial Review acknowledged that, in relation to this whole matter of the tax system, considerations of equity and fairness between taxpayers are of a greater value than the absolute importance attached to retrospectivity by the Opposition . In particular, I emphasise that no penal consequences are attached to persons by this legislation. No criminal stigma is attached to those against whom this legislation will operate.

In relation to the Bill itself to which I know you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would wish me to return in order to keep within Standing Orders and to be relevant, it is also the case that, within this legislation, anomalies relief is granted. This Bill makes sensible and sensitive concessions to those who might otherwise find themselves subject to the law. Indeed, a provision is to be inserted which will enable full or partial relief to be granted in cases where relief is not available under the existing law. This will particularly assist people in cases where their recoupment tax liability was traced through an interest in a public company, that is, where they are well removed from the actions giving rise to the recoupment tax liability in question. That is the technical expression. But the point I wish to make is that this Government is not about harassing people or unnecessarily subjecting them to undue hardship which is out of all proportion to society's interest in obtaining evaded money by virtue of this recoupment law. It was never intended to be harsh and oppressive. I know that this particular provision has general support in the community and even has support in the minds of some back benchers on the opposition benches.

This provision, in other words, will relieve the taxpayer of liabilty in some situations. In other situations, of course, where a liability is not properly attached to the taxpayer but where, nevertheless, dire hardship would follow if the Commissioner of Taxation kept his demand in place, of course, section 265 of the Income Tax Act is available which will enable a taxpayer to be released from liability where it is demonstrated to an absolutely independent arbiter- independent of government-that hardship will be such that, if the liability is pressed to its absolute conclusion, the impact will be such that, as I say, society's interests will in no way be advanced by pressing that particular tax liability. In relation to that matter, an excellent provision is contained in the Bill which should have the support of the chamber.

There are other changes. For example, it is proposed to reinsert in the recoupment tax legislation a provision removed by the previous Government which authorised the Commissioner of Taxation to report to this Parliament the names of persons who fail to meet their liability for vendors or promoters recoupment tax. The Commissioner is already empowered in his annual report to the Parliament to give details of names of those who have evaded or avoided their liability in a culpable way. We are merely extending that provision. I believe it is an important provision because public notoriety or scorn is an effective weapon in society's armoury to secure allegiance and adherence to the law. I well remember as a child reading about Robin Hood and so on, and about the stocks in the villages. I do not believe that being put in the stocks in the village square was so much a punishment as a public humiliation. People were exposed to public ridicule and contempt. I think this is a somewhat similar situation where the people ought to be pilloried and exposed to the public because what they are doing is not merely a matter of private negotiation between them as taxpayers and the Commissioner of Taxation; it has public consequences. It has social consequences for the carrying out of the programs of the democratically elected Government of Australia. As I have indicated, if these people do not pay their proper tax liability, other ordinary, decent Australians, will have to pay higher taxes or the deficit will have to be increased or the programs of government will have to be curtailed or distorted. In those ways as I said the evasion of taxation has public and social consequences, and the public or social naming of these people is part of the battle to bring them to a clearer sense of social responsibility. After all, the American War of Independence was fought on the slogan: 'No taxation without representation'. Some in our Australian society would go further and perhaps say : 'No representation without taxation'. What I am trying to do is at least to link the social and democratic responsibilities of these tax evaders with the simple question of their contribution to revenue.

I think I have exposed to the chamber most of the desirable features of this Bill. As I have said, I believe it carries through the mandate which was given to the Australian Labor Party, led so ably and popularly, dare I say, by Bob Hawke. This mandate to rid Australia of the distortions and the unfairness within our tax system is a mandate which we will robustly and with integrity pursue. The fact that Opposition members wish to continue to aid, abet and connive in relation to the tax evasion practices of some within the community will, I believe, come back to haunt them if we need to renew that mandate late next year. The political consequences of their frustration of this legislation today will indeed come back to haunt them. Nevertheless, in speaking to the Australian Democrats, who I know do not take an absolute view on these matters but who are open to the persuasion of reasonable arguments such as have fallen from my lips, I ask them, on behalf of the Australian people, to support this Bill which deserves the commendation of the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing yet again a Bill relating to unpaid company tax. The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 (No. 4) is a hybrid Bill which has arisen out of the history of previous Bills that we have had in this area. As I understand the processes that we are likely to go through with this Bill, we will have a Committee stage, unlike with the previous Bills, and therefore it would be appropriate at that time to make more detailed comments in relation to particular clauses. At this stage I simply want to reiterate briefly the points that I have made previously on behalf of myself, Senator Chipp and Senator Haines in terms of our opposition , which I must acknowledge is now a dwindling opposition in the Senate and in the House of Representatives. I think now, out of 180-odd people, we are down to nine who oppose the imposition of penalties retrospectively.
—Consistently.
—That is a consistent stance that we have taken. We took it to both of the previous Bills of the Labor Government and we took it to the Liberal Party's Bill.
—Are you taking it to this one?

—We are taking it to this one. Indeed, if one wishes to look at the Act, the proposal to omit section 3 (12) and the various other amendments that are likely to be made or sought to be made to section 5 of the principal Act has a clear retrospective penal effect. I will spell out where that would occur. In clause 3, for example, the redefinition of the promoters' recoupment tax and the vendors' recoupment tax provides for additional tax for failure to supply information to the Commissioner of Taxation. The principal Act does not permit the Commissioner to impose additional tax on a recoupment taxpayer under section 226. This new additional tax will be included in applicable recoupment tax assessments when they commence to issue. The penalty relates to the failure to give adequate information since the commencement of the principal Act in December 1982. Clearly there is a retrospective element in the inclusion of this proposed penalty.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there are some other aspects to which I take objection and to which, in fact, I will raise those objections as we go along. Two principal elements are left in the Bill. There is an attempt to omit section 3 (12) from the principal Act and there is the intention on behalf of the Government to seek some type of amelioration of problems for public companies. both of these have difficulties. I will take the first element and concentrate purely on that. We are now confronted with the situation that certain taxpayers will find themselves in an anomalous position. Basically, I believe we are confronted with a travesty of justice. This retrospective law will apply only to a limited period. That limited period is circumscribed by the principal Act which this Bill amends and the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980. I believe that is the crux of the problem. The principal Act which this Bill amends contains relieving provisions relating to pre-sales and post-sales that have been entered into with a reasonable expectation. The current situation, of course, is that we are not quite sure whether that section will have an adverse effect. During the election campaign in March this year a leaked memorandum from the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation suggested that the section may cause considerable problems. Doubtless, the Government will be able to tell us a bit more clearly what the problems are when we discuss that section. However, it is a bit difficult to know.

TALK.START.PARA: —What action is that?
—The fact that we are going to omit section 3 (12).
—Are you referring to the pre-sales tax avoidance situation?

—Yes. I have been able to ascertain since that time that, as it has not been applied, it is very difficult to know what might happen. I believe the Government is banking on possibly 300 or 400 cases being caught up under this provision.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that if anybody reads section 3 (12) he will be struck by how difficult it would be in court to do very much with it. I suggest that if somebody actually succeeded in court under section 3 (12) nobody in this chamber would believe that he ought to pay the tax. I suggest to Senator Tate that he read section 3 (12) and, from his own previous knowledge of the law as a lawyer, imagine mounting a case to the courts on that provision and try to work out what he would need by way of backing. If he is interested I can give him an example of a case. I have all the documents in relation to a case that I believe may very well be one which would succeed under this provision. These documents reveal that the company has real live directors and shareholders. It has a professional registered office. The affairs of the company have, at all times both prior to and subsequent to the sale of shares in the company, been conducted in accordance with the income tax legislation and the companies code. The company still exists and continues to compy with all relevant laws. I have the annual returns which are copies of the financial statements. If it is suggested that there may have been fraud, I point out that the present directors and shareholders have co-operated 100 per cent with the Australian Taxation Office, even to the extent of providing a separate office, copying facilities and access to all relevant files to senior taxation investigators over a period of more than 12 months. There is no mention of the company being dumped, and I am glad that Senator Tate did not actually use that term because we are not talking about that. It is a nice shorthand term but it does not refer to the types of companies and situations with which this Bill is really concerned. It is really concerned with real companies, real directors and shareholders, in real situations of trade.

Unfortunately the media have used another shorthand term for these provisions, having called them innocence clauses. They are not innocence clauses; they were inserted in the principal Act for a variety of reasons and I do not intend to try to rehearse what might or might not have been in the minds of the various people concerned. However, if one looks at these provisions on an objective basis one will see that they make the standard of liability to tax under the principal Act the same as the standard of liability under the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act of 1980. That seems to me to be a reasonable reason for their inclusion. I have heard all sorts of other reasons as to why they might have been included; other honourable senators might allude to those. I just do not know, but on the objective basis on which I stand in relation to these provisions, I believe that the concurrence between the principal Act to which this Bill is an amendment and the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act of 1980 is a reasonable basis for their inclusion.

The Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act applies to certain tax evasion practices entered into after 3 December 1980. The operation of the recoupment tax legislation is restricted to the period 1 January 1972 to 3 December 1980. Both of those dates are inclusive. The second reading speech of the Minister at the time stated that one of the main tax evasion practices that the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act was directed towards was the stripping of companies of their assets before tax was due and payable. The legislation also related to tax which became due and payable on previously derived income. Therefore, a person is now guilty of an offence under that Act if he enters into an arrangement or transaction for the purpose of securing that the company will be unable to likely to be unable to pay income tax that is payable. Therefore, we have that offence of entering into those arrangements to secure the company's inability, basically, to pay future income tax.

The relieving provisions of section 3 (12), which are the core reason for this amending Bill, only apply where, after the target company has been sold to a promoter, the company entered into a scheme which, though ultimately found to be unsuccessful, could at the time be thought to have been effective in its tax reduction purpose. However, the relieving provisions do not apply where a scheme was connected with an arrangement that rendered the company not liable to pay its tax. That is an important point. So section 3 (12) of the principal Act was inserted to ensure that a vendor-shareholder did not suffer liabilities under the principal Act of a standard harsher than those that applied and still apply under the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. It seems that that meshing together of liabilities, as it were, is appropriate; that persons ought not have significantly different penalties applied to them under similar Acts. But what the Government is proposing to do-that is, to remove these relieving sections in relation to those individuals-will provide for an infinitely greater tax impost for an identical transaction. That, I believe, is a bad principle of law.

There are other difficulties with the Act but I believe that if the Government were able to secure the passage of this particular clause of the Bill, then it may be quite amenable in relation to others-for example, the reporting of the Commissioner of Taxation to Parliament and so on. Essentially, the money we are concerned about under this Bill has been estimated at approximately $40m. With a take-back, as it were, of approximately $5m, on the Government's estimates, by certain individuals who might find relief under the anomalies clause, we are looking at $35m in terms of this exercise.

The overall proposition, I believe, must be and has to be seen as relatively simple. We are yet again attempting to perpetuate something in terms of legislation that I believe is unacceptable as a matter of principle. I do not accept, for whatever purpose, that we can declare a person guilty by legislation of a crime that he did not commit. That proposition is able to be supported because we are declaring people guilty yet again by legislative form without the ability for them to have recourse to the courts. Indeed, the principal provisions of the Bill seek to remove one of the relieving appeals to the courts . We are declaring them guilty of a crime they did not commit on the basis that what we are doing is engaging in retrospective legislation. At the time that they engaged in these activities there was no law which prevented them from doing so. As I have said on every other occasion, I do not defend the government of the day for its inactivity in relation to those provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you sanction it.

—I do not agree with the inactivity and I do not sanction that inactivity. I believe there was gross inactivity and negligence on the part of previous governments, including the Whitlam Government, because this inactivity goes back to 1972. Knowledge of what was going on was readily available within the community. Senator Tate, for the Government, has upheld the proposition that we knew what was going on in the community, and still no action was taken by the Parliament to correct it. I believe that what we seek to do now is to violate another principle in order to fix up inactivity by the Parliament. The fault lay here and not with those people who took advantage of the laws as they then existed. A person is entitled to take advantage of the law to minimise his tax. Any individual in the community takes that advantage. The honourable senator who interjected previously, I imagine, does the same in his tax return.
—I pay all my due taxes.

—What Senator Cook does and what everybody in the community does is to make claims which are permissible under the law to relieve themselves of certain taxes that they have already paid. They seek to get a refund. The only way that they will get a refund, presumably, is to make claims under the law. They are legitimate and lawful claims. What these people were doing, and it is acknowledged by the Government that they were doing it, was making legitimate and lawful claims. I despise the morality of it, but the point is that under the law they were entitled to do so and they did. We now propose to say: 'We will change history'. I suppose that in 1984 we will rewrite the history books. Those people were not guilty of an unlawful act. If they were, there would be no need for this piece of legislation since the Commissioner has all the powers he needs to prosecute them through the courts. The Commissioner is still able to do that today if anything that those people did was in any way illegal. The Commissioner has the power to prosecute offences committed since 1972 and he still has that power.

SPEECH.PARA: It is acknowledged, therefore, by the Government that there was no illegal activity. Upon that basis I will not be a party to prosecuting someone, and I will not give my vote to prosecute someone, who is not guilty of a crime; nor will I declare them, by legislative form, guilty of something they did not do. I want to make it very clear that I have urged constantly, even before I came into this House, that the laws ought to be changed to stop people doing what they were doing, and that is on the record going back a long way. Yet the inactivity on the part of this Parliament to come to grips with those problems, as was exemplified by the activities of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth, I think is well known within the community. I readily acknowledge that the Government has won the public relations exercise on this, but I do not believe that can in any way relieve me from what I consider to be a duty to oppose those principal sections of this Act which seek retrospectively to impose yet again a penal sanction on people for what was at the time a legal action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: -We are discussing the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 (No. 4). In other words it is the third time that we have been discussing bottom of the harbour legislation because this legislation seeks to enact laws to prevent bottom of the harbour and other-
—It does nothing of the sort. Have a look at it. It has got nothing to do with those companies.

—I have had a look at the legislation, Senator. This is a question dealing with tax avoidance and tax evasion and it seems to me that every time we have put forward legislation of this character to this chamber we have met objections from the Opposition, from some Australian Democrats and from Senator Harradine. This has meant that in equity, honest, decent Australians who pay their taxes and meet their obligations are not recognised as having a right to ensure that those who avoid and evade their obligations or do not meet them and who do not pay their taxes should be made to pay them.

SPEECH.PARA: On the simple question of equity, which is a matter I will come to in a moment, I want to argue with the points that have been put up until now, but in terms of what we have brought forth this time it is indeed much more innocuous legislation than that introduced on the last two occasions. It is estimated that the legislation we have before us today will collect only $40m in a full year, whereas it was estimated that our original legislation would have collected over $270m. Therefore, because our original legislation has been defeated we do not necessarily regard this as the ideal expression of the type of legislation a Labor government would want to enact, nor is it the type of legislation for which we have a mandate. I say to my friends among the Democrats that if they have as a slogan 'Keep the bastards honest' they ought to recognise that we have a mandate to enact the original legislation put to the House of Representatives and in this chamber earlier this year, and they ought to help us to be kept honest by supporting that legislation because they cannot sustain the slogan ' Keep the bastards honest' when they prevent us implementing our mandate, but that is an argument which I will come to in a moment.

The Government has been thwarted on previous occasions and it has been thwarted by the Liberal Party, by the National Party of Australia, by three of the Democrats and by Senator Harradine. One could perhaps understand the reluctance of the Liberal Party and the National Party in dealing with any tax avoidance legislation. Last year when the Fraser Government put forward the first piece of tax avoidance legislation it was met by major outcries and division within the Liberal Party, most notably the Western Australian Branch of the Liberal Party which repudiated the Federal Party and described Malcolm Fraser, whom many people would regard as the most right wing and authoritarian Prime Minister Australia has seen, as being left wing. But one can understand how the Liberal Party tears itself apart over tax avoidance. That is clear if one looks at the record. Therefore, the most critical arguments in this debate cannot be directed across the Senate to the Opposition. Rather, we must take into account the position taken in previous debates by the Australian Democrats and the sole independent in this chamber, Senator Harradine. On past performances it is likely this legislation will be defeated. If that happens, I think the Australian community is entitled to ask why.

The Government has based this legislation on many important grounds. Fundamentally, one of the most important questions of concern to this Government is that there be equity in tax laws and that it be seen. There needs to be equity in general conduct on the economic front if we are to bring Australia from the depths of economic recession to the prosperity that is rightly the entitlement of all Australians. Let me take the first area. Most Australians have always paid their tax because as wage and salary earners the tax is removed from their pay packets before they get them. There is no question of avoidance, evasion or participation in sophisticated schemes to minimise tax on their part. Wage and salary earners pay and have always paid their tax. By comparison, only a small percentage of people engage in manipulation-those engaged in buying and selling companies and in the business area-and the large-scale avoidance and evasion that has occurred. These are matters of common understanding between everyone in this chamber. Therefore, as a matter of equity, the rights of all who pay tax honestly have to be stood against the rights of the minority who do not pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —The largest area of tax evasion is the cash economy.

—The largest area is not the cash economy. The Government has moved to do something in this significant area. The largest loss to government revenue is caused by people who manipulate other areas. To make the point as forcefully as I can in this argument, I want to point to the dimensions of the problem in terms of the rights of the majority. There was a 110 per cent increase in pay as you earn taxes collected between 1975-76 and 1981-82. In the same period, the wages and salaries of this group of taxpayers increased by 72 per cent. Between 1975-76 and 1981-82 taxes paid by the non-PAYE bracket-people involved in business, property and all the rest-increased by 56 per cent and incomes increased by 94 per cent. Therefore, over that period PAYE incomes increased by 72 per cent but PAYE taxpayers paid 110 per cent more tax; non-PAYE incomes increased by 94 per cent but non-PAYE taxpayers paid 56 per cent more tax. I think those figures have to be recited so that the point can be made as to where the tax burden falls in this country. That burden falls on people who do not have the escape routes that others claim and seek. I believe that this legislation seeks to protect and support their rights.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1975-76 PAYE taxpayers contributed 76 per cent of all taxes collected in Australia. In 1981-82 they contributed 82 per cent. Therefore, in terms of a pie chart the wedge representing non-PAYE contributions over that period has fallen from 24 per cent to 18 per cent. I think those points have to be clearly put on the record as inequity underpins the perceptions of the community at large in terms of what is fair and honest. Those who pay the burden are entitled to see that those who do not, or who in some senses avoid it, are made to meet their obligations. If they are not and if we allow the statute book to remain as it is without the legislation being in place to protect the majority, the majority will wreak electoral redress for that. They may have an earlier opportunity than perhaps would be comfortable for some of my friends on the other side of the chamber. I turn now to the equity question.

TALK.START.PARA: —You campaigned on this in March.

—Yes, we did campaign on this in March. I will come a little later on to the quality of our mandate on this issue. The quality of our mandate and our obligations to discharge that mandate to the community are very important arguments in this whole issue. But let me not be diverted from making the points I want to make about equity because they are fundamental to a perception by the community of what is at stake here. If we go to the national accounts released last Friday we see in those accounts that, for the 12 months up to September, the total wage and salary bill fell by one per cent. We see that the gross operating surpluses of companies for that 12 months up to September rose by 37 per cent and the gross operating surpluses for other enterprises rose by 20 per cent. In other words, in the last 12 months there has been a massive redistribution away from wages and salaries to profit. That comment is not a comment original to me. If one wants to read the Age of last Friday one will see that that is also the comment of Ken Davidson, the economics editor of that paper.

SPEECH.PARA: It may well be that the economic theory that there requires to be higher profits for more money to be re-invested for this economy to get moving again is correct although in the present climate the expectation may be as well that whatever surplus profits there are will be invested in speculation on real estate and not create any further employment. Be that as it may, what the figures reveal from the point of view of the equity argument in this case is that wage and salary earners, in terms of their total share of gross domestic product, were worse off at the end of September than they were before. In that context, where the company sector has become better off, let us look at this legislation and at the tax measures from the point of view of the overall necessity for there to be a perception of equality of sacrifice in order to get Australia back to high profitability, more employment and greater prosperity for all.

What underpins the economic strategy for this Government is the prices and incomes accord. As Senator Tate made reference to it, quite well, I too want to make reference to it. The accord rests on a perception by everybody that the load will be borne equally. Wage and salary earners are required to accept that their incomes will move in a centralised way according to the movements in prices. So in real terms the value of their wages will remain constant. The effect of a wages policy, as every commentator will agree, is central to economic recovery. If there is a perception backed by a reality that avoidance, in terms of taxes, is still at a high level--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not. The Act has been changed. There is no way in the world that this Bill will change that.

—I am going back to what was our original legislation. This is our third try to introduce legislation to improve the tax laws of this country. As I have said, because honourable senators opposite voted against our previous legislation we are trying now for the third time to get this legislation through . The perception is that there is still large scale avoidance of tax obligations and--
—Who is spreading that?
—That is the case.
—I hope you are not.

—I am not spreading it, but the record shows that that is the case. In view of that, I point out to honourable senators opposite that the reality and the record should be corrected and this legislation should be passed as indeed our original legislation should have been passed. If it is not passed, we are contributing to the view that everyone should get in for his chop and do the best he can irrespective of the economic plight of this country; we are accepting the slogans 'The devil take the hindmost' and 'Buyer beware' and all the other slogans that attend the private enterprise mentality. I make those remarks about equity because they are fundamental to the public perception of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The second area to which I want to address a few remarks concerns mandate. I think it is indisputable that the Hawke Labor Government has a mandate for this legislation, as it had for the other items of legislation we put forward. I do not necessarily want to go through a recitation of how that mandate was clear in the public mind, but it certainly was clear when we were in opposition. It certainly was clear in the policy speech, in our platform, at the National Economic Summit Conference and in the communique following the Summit. The mandate is there.

TALK.START.PARA: —So was mine.
—I am interested by the honourable senator's interjection.
—I opposed the Liberal one, don't forget. You were not here then .

—The honourable senator ran in the last election on a slogan of keeping the bastards honest. If we are the bastards in this case-that is, the Government-elected with a clear mandate to reform taxes in this area, why do the Australian Democrats not vote with us and make sure we can deliver the promise on which the Australian people elected us into office? That is the challenge they should accept. If they run on a slogan of keeping us bastards honest and then act to thwart and frustrate our mandate, they are not being directly honest with the people who have elected them.
—I said I would not vote for retrospective legislation. To be honest I must vote against it.

—All right. My understanding is that last year Senator Harradine voted for similar legislation by way of an amendment. I trust that he may do the same again. A question has been raised in terms of retrospectivity. Many things have been mentioned about it. I oppose as a general concept the use of retrospective legislation. But, like all generalities, if this concept is applied in every instance it can create anomalies which, in turn, create inequities and problems. While, as a generality, we operate on the basis of no retrospectivity, we cannot apply that mindlessly in every circumstance. Each case has to be held up against that principle and tested.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is not a commitment by governments to legislate respectively in the taxation field, we invite slick lawyers and smart accountants to manipulate the system in order to avoid their obligations. If everyone in the community knows that as soon as those smart lawyers and slick accountants manipulate the system in order to avoid their obligations, a government will move retrospectively to wipe out their ill-gotten gains, the incentive for tax avoidance and evasion is removed. While I operate on the general standard that retrospective legislation is to be abhorred, there is a perfectly good reason why retrospective tax legislation should be used, and used in such a way that everyone can be sure that no one else is avoiding his obligations. If there is a feeling that people should get in for their chop and avoid their obligations, the whole system comes unstuck. The finest definition of free enterprise might be 'how to pervert the system and take from it what one can'.

This legislation is essential. However, it is a pity that this our third attempt does not go as far as our first and second attempts. For that reason we are having to make do with legislation which is not up to the level of our mandate. That is not a responsibility we bear, because we have tried. It is a responsibility which those who have opposed us bear. I hope that if they get the chance to explain their actions to the Australian community they can do so, because I am damn sure that they cannot explain them to the Senate. I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having heard the speakers on this subject now for the third time-it is pretty much the same topic being regurgitated for the third time-a few points need to be put into perspective. The first is that the Government of Australia stands indicted. It has been found guilty of inaction and gross dereliction of duty from 1972 to 1980 when tax avoiders and tax evaders, call them what one will, ran riot around this country, not just quietly underground but blatantly and openly ripping off the Australian taxpayers as a result of their activities. They did it with the help, the blessing and-one suspects the motives-the implicit support of a number of key people around Australia, people in government and people in places such as the High Court of Australia, which had ruled, for instance, that section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act was ineffective to bring tax avoiders under some sort of control so that they did not move into that darker, grey area of tax evasion. Once that ruling that the government and the Commissioner of Taxation had no powers under section 260 to collect taxes was given, it was open slather. The sad thing is that the innocent victims of that ruling and the government's subsequent inaction are the darn near 15 million Australians who over that period had to pay additional tax as a result of government negligence.

SPEECH.PARA: I am probably one of the few people in this Senate in a position to claim innocence, because I was elected to the Senate in March this year when this damage had been done and when one could look back at government inaction as an observer of that previous inaction, as one of main people in the community who had become aware of the inaction and of the sort of activity taking place- blatant advertising of tax avoidance and evasion schemes which were rife around the community and which were being used by people to avoid their obligations, whether legal or moral, to pay their way for living in this country. The sad thing is that when ultimately a government decided to take action it had to start looking for scapegoats to ensure that not all the odium compounded upon it . The scapegoats it picked out, of course, were the Opposition parties. Ultimately the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine became scapegoats. In some cases innocent shareholders as well as the guilty shareholders became scapegoats. On top of that a search for culprits commenced. Some of the guilty parties, some of the people who should have been picked up in this net, have undoubtedly been embraced in the provisions and are now being pursued by the Commissioner of Taxation.

In some cases the search for culprits developed into a vendetta against some people. That was rather sad to see because, whether justified or not, I do not believe that the powers of that guilty government should have been used against people who, whether morally right or wrong, were legally acting within their rights. The interesting thing to have witnessed over that period was that it was not the lawyers or accountants, the people arranging these deals, nor even public servants or the legislators, who were highlighted as the culprits over this decade of inaction; it was the shareholders who copped all the blame for the negligence over this period.

One would have thought that with the passage of the 1982 legislation by the Fraser Government the tax avoidance industry would have been killed but, regrettably, it is still alive and well. That is one of the reasons why this measure is being debated today. It is to tidy up a little more of the legislation. Tax avoidance is alive and well because our tax Acts still provide opportunities for people legally and legitimately to avoid what others would regard as their moral obligation to pay their way in this community. In all probability, tax evasion has gone either underground or off-shore. Certainly, as was indicated earlier by Senator Macklin, the big tax evasion area, the cash economy, has made its move underground, quite effectively I am told, and is still evading or avoiding-probably evading now that it has gone underground-its tax obligations. I am not suggesting for one moment that that is a result of bad or inappropriate legislation. I think that the legislation can go only so far at this early stage in picking up the withholding tax evaders.

The arrival in 1982 of the Fraser bottom of the harbour legislation came complete with loopholes for friends. That was discussed around Australia. It was discussed within the Liberal Party and it was revealed in the media around Australia that there were problems with the legislation, that some people who would be picked up were influential within the Liberal Party and needed to be accommodated. So section 3 (12) was inserted into the legislation to provide that accommodation. The sad thing to me is that while the Fraser Government in 1982 was busy looking after friends, it provided inadequate safeguards for the genuinely innocent people who could prove that they had not benefited.

It was for that reason that in 1983 the first Labor Government attempt was made to remedy the position and to increase the size of the tax evader or avoider share of the community to be netted in the bottom of the harbour legislation. It introduced its first Bill. Senator Mason and I, while we felt it was justified under the mandate that had been given to the Labor Party to clear up once and for all the tax avoidance and evasion industry, persuaded the Government that some modifications were needed not just for those caught up in the 1983 legislation but also for those who in 1982 had been denied natural justice. We persuaded the Government to go down that path with us; but, in the event, that Bill was lost at the second reading stage, so no firm arrangement was made to help the people who had been unjustly caught up in the 1982 legislation.

However, the Government tried again to bring in a supplementary bottom of the harbour Bill-its second attempt. Senator Mason and I went once more to the Government and again achieved a further leap forward in the agreement for the creation of an anomalies tribunal, completely independent from the Taxation Commissioner, which would hear the appeals of individuals who had been caught up in the 1982 or the 1983 legislation and who did not deserve to be hit with additional tax either because they had not benefited from the bottom of the harbour activity or because they were completely innocent of any involvement as shareholders remote from the directors making those decisions and were totally unaware, and could prove that they were totally unaware, of the moves to put the company to the bottom of the harbour.

Once again, the Government's legislation failed. It did not achieve a majority in the Senate and, therefore, once more the opportunity to provide justice for the people unjustly caught up in the 1982 legislation was denied. So, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, I introduced a private member's Bill which would create that anomalies tribunal-that tribunal of appeal-completely independent of the Taxation Commissioner, which would allow people the right to set out before the tribunal reasons why they should not be assessed-that is, reasons based on the fact either that they had not benefited in any way from the sinking of the company to the bottom of the harbour or that they were completely innocent and could prove their innocence in regard to the actions taken by others.

That Bill is still before us; but, of course, it will be superseded by this third attempt by the Government-the Labor Government-to expand the effects of the bottom of the harbour legislation of 1982. This third attempt adopts the proposal that we put for the creation of the anomalies tribunal and at the same time removes the innocence clause-the loophole clause-inserted into the 1982 legislation by the Fraser Government. I believe that it will be necessary for the anomalies tribunal to hear not only from shareholders of public companies who have been unjustly dealt with in the 1982 legislation or this legislation but also from private companies. It is my understanding that there are shareholders of private companies-maybe comparatively few; there might be only several hundred; perhaps as many as several thousand, but in the overall context not a great proportion-who were caught up as a result of being remote, innocent and completely unaware shareholders whose companies were sent to the bottom of the harbour by their directors without their support for, knowledge of or agreement in any way to that action being taken. Those shareholders may have received absolutely no benefit from the action of their directors but still may be caught up in this net and, as a result, be quite unjustly dealt with. There needs to be that additional provision for those private company shareholders to be embraced in that anomalies tribunal provision.

I should like briefly to go over the difficulties that we in the Australian Democrats and a lot of people around Australia are experiencing with this legislation as they did with previous legislation introduced on this matter. I have already indicated that I believe that most Australians feel that the Bill covers up government mismanagement and that, that mismanagement having been discovered, the problem is now being remedied retrospectively.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct a question to the Attorney-General, as Minister representing the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I again refer the Attorney to the statement on yesterday's AM program by the Minister for Defence, Mr Scholes:

QUESTION.PARA: But with regard to the Invincible, the British Government advised us that it would not be taking up the offer of docking in Sydney.

I ask: Has the Attorney-General checked with Mr Scholes that he used these words and, if he has confirmed them, is the Attorney still somewhat surprised, as he said yesterday he would be, to learn that such an offer had been made? When was the offer put to the British Royal Navy, at what level was it put, what were its terms and conditions, and when and why did the British High Commissioner intervene? Finally, in view of Mr Scholes's further statement on AM that the matter had been under constant discussion with officials at the Department of Defence and Navy, will he table all relevant signals, correspondence or records of conversations so that the confusion can be cleared up?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have discussed the matter in question with the Minister for Defence, Mr Scholes, since yesterday. He advises me that although he cannot disagree with the tape recording and transcript of the AM program yesterday, which does indicate that he used the word 'offer'-'offer of docking in Sydney'- that was not the word he meant to employ, because a more appropriate word, although he readily concedes that it is not one he used on the occasion, was ' option'. 'Would not be taking up the option of docking' is really what he meant to say. There is nothing elsewhere in the text of his answer which suggests that there was anything in the nature of an offer and certainly Mr Scholes has consistently denied that any such description would be appropriate to the exchanges and discussions which did take place between Australian and British authorities. I will refer to the Minister the question as to what, if anything, he might be prepared to table so far as documentation relating to those discussions is concerned. I would be doubtful, given the nature of it, that it would be appropriate for him to do so, consistent with the kinds of freedom of information principles that have been so vigorously and noisily espoused by honourable senators opposite.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Would the Minister agree that the marked decline in days lost due to industrial disputes over the last year is in part due to the reintroduction of a centralised wage system? Does the decline in the level of industrial disputes suggest that the now abolished Industrial Relations Bureau contributed nothing to industrial harmony?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already noted in the Senate on several occasions the marked decline in the level of industrial disputation in Australia since the Hawke Government was elected. One of the remarkable features of that decline has been the fact that it has occurred in recent months, during a period of improvement in the employment situation. I think that is a worthwhile observation because it is unusual that such a circumstance should arise. I do not know whether I would be able, on behalf of the Minister, to pass judgment on the worth or otherwise of the Industrial Relations Bureau, or to comment on whether the level of industrial disputation had been adversely affected by the existence of such bodies. I just make the point that in the last few years there have been two basic approaches to industrial relations in this country. One was that demonstrated by the Fraser Government. It involved a virtual armoury of legislative provisions for dealing with the consequences of industrial relations , as former Prime Minister Fraser used to call it. I think in this Senate we passed more legislation dealing with industrial relations issues than we had hot breakfasts. But all that legislation never seemed to produce any result.

ANSWER.PARA: A different approach is adopted by the Hawke Government which has, as its elements, the accord and the attitude adopted at the National Economic Summit Conference. It is a fairly realistic and hard-headed approach by the Goverment to the unions on a variety of issues, including the restructuring of industries and so on. I think maybe the Industrial Relations Bureau did not achieve very much. I do not know whether it would have been worse or better if the Industrial Relations Bureau had not existed in the period of the Fraser Government. I think the fundamental point to be made is that there is a difference of approach which this Government recognises has difficulties associated with it in terms of the provisions of the accord. But it is a calculated approach taken by the Goverment on the assumption that a successful industrial relations climate is integral to the economic well-being of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence and Minister for Foreign Affairs. I preface my question by referring to the Attorney-General's statement yesterday that warships are required to disarm before the enter Australian dry docks. I presume the Minister meant to say 'de-ammunition', as disarming would require the removal of a vessel's guns and missile launchers. I assume that the Attorney was not suggesting that this was normal procedure. In any event, will the Minister agree that he has been badly misinformed on this matter, since I, for one, have many times been in ships in Captain Cook dry dock with all their ammunition on board? As the Minister has admitted that the refusal of the American and British navies to confirm or deny the presence of nuclear weapons on their ships is quite reasonable, why is he trying to change this policy by requiring de-ammunitioning in an Australian dockyard for display before people such as members of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union? Can the Minister now answer my question of yesterday as to what the increased risk to people of Sydney would be from a hypothetical nuclear device if HMS Invincible were in Captain Cook dry dock rather than alongside Garden Island? Finally, is not all the Government's talk about de-ammunitioning a red herring? Is it not true that the real fear was that if the Invincible were docked the militant dockyard unions would not release her from the dock and the Government would be too feeble to do anything about such disgraceful international blackmail?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not presume to enter into a dispute about naval terminology with the former admiral, rear admiral or whatever he was, which I cannot recall. I know Senator Hamer was much more important than a mere captain. My brief yesterday did not distinguish between de-ammunitioning and disarming, although I am led to understand from subsequent discussions that disarming can refer not only to cleaning the decks of major weapons systems but also to the disassembling of triggering devices and matters of this kind which have the effect of making unusable weaponry and explosives that might otherwise have a certain potential to blow up. In those circumstances my use of the expression ' disarm' was certainly meant to subsume primarily what Senator Hamer described as de-ammunitioning, together with, possibly, other forms of activity which would have the effect of neutralising the explosive potential of weaponry on board.

ANSWER.PARA: Having resolved, I hope, that element of confusion, the second matter is that it is the case, as I understand, it, that not all ships going into dry dock are de-ammunitioned or disarmed, in the narrower sense I have mentioned. Again, I bow to Senator or Admiral Hamer's superior experience in this respect. I am led to understand that there are circumstances in which that normal practical requirement is in fact waived, depending on the case. As to the further questions Senator Hamer asked yesterday, in respect of which I sought answers, I am in a position to say this as to the increased dangers which would be involved in the ship being in dry dock as distinct from being alongside it at Garden Island: I am advised by the Minister for Defence that the main consideration involved is that if an accident occurred it would be more difficult to move a ship from dry dock than from a berth alongside a wharf. I am always surprised to see a commonsense proposition emerging from the Department of Defence. On this occasion, it is one that seems to have some plausibility and weight.

I am also advised that vessels enter dock for repairs or maintenance-that appears to be so-and safety requirements point to the desirability of not having large quantities of explosives aboard a vessel in that situation. I am further advised, in a fine example of Defence Department prose which I put into the record for what Senator Hamer might be able to make of it, of the following: There are differing public perceptions of the relative safety of ammunition on ships in dry dock and that in ships elsewhere. Consideration also needs to be given to the possibility that industrial relations questions could arise if there were doubts about the risks entailed in having ammunition and other explosives on a ship being worked upon in dry dock. I hope that that answer will sufficiently demonstrate the sensitivity of the defence establishment to the matters that have been raised by Senator Hamer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Resources and Energy seen the article in yesterday's West Australian headlined 'Coal power cheaper than atomic-report' in which it was reported that the non-profit Washington based research group World- watch Institute has published a study showing that in nearly all countries nuclear generated power is more expensive than coal generated power? Does the Government concur with the study's findings? Does the Government have a policy of promoting the sale of Australian coal overseas in order to encourage other countries to take advantage of the cost savings reported?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the specific report to which Senator Cook referred in his question but I have seen similar reports of what I think is the same study, that is, a study by the United States World-watch Institute on the comparative costs of nuclear generated and thermal electricity, or indeed electricity from any source. Some time ago I asked that a copy of that study be obtained as quickly as possible, but as yet I have not received it. In the absence of receiving the study and the assumptions on which it is based it is not possible to make firm judgments about the conclusions drawn in the study because analyses of that type depend very much on the assumptions used, particularly in regard to matters such as interest rates, inflation and the prices of alternative energy inputs. I presume the study notes that these comparative costs vary considerably in different regions and in different countries. The cost of nuclear power stations has been increased because of high interest rates and the long lead times required for construction.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the second part of Senator Cook's question, certainly the Government is interested in expanding the sale of Australian coal. When I visited Europe towards the end of last month one thing I noted particularly in northern Europe was a great deal of concern about the atmospheric pollution caused by burning high sulphur coal. The sulphur dioxide-it is called acid rain-is alleged to be destroying the Black Forest and doing a substantial amount of environmental damage in Europe and also to some extent in North America. I took the opportunity to impress upon those Europeans to whom I spoke that by world standards Australia had very low sulphur coals and that we would be very happy, to say the least, to supply greater quantities of low sulphur Australian coal to at least remove that source of pollution.
