Finally in regard to the comparative costs of nuclear and non-nuclear electricity, on 17 November I had incorporated in Hansard some relevant figures. However, they are fairly lengthy and I will not bother to try to summarise them now.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I ask: Is it a fact that the American Government does not send warships which are nuclear-armed into New York Harbour? If this is good enough for America's largest city, why is it not good enough for Australia's largest city? Is it a fact that the presence of allied warships at Garden Island at the outbreak of a global war would make early nuclear attack on Sydney much more likely? If such visiting ships were carrying nuclear weapons, would not the chain reaction from the destruction of those weapons enormously increase the number of deaths, the damage, and the residual radiation in the Sydney area? In the light of these matters, why is the Government actually expanding the Garden Island base? Will the Government now actively consider shifting that facility from the heart of Sydney to a location that could safely be used by the ships of any of our allies and which could be substantially financed by the sale of the very valuable real estate that Garden Island represents?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first point, with respect to the American Government's policies so far as New York is concerned the only information I have is contained in an answer by the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, which appears in the House of Representatives Hansard of 8 December 1982 . He said:

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed that no cities in the United States of America deny access to their ports by United States Navy ships in the categories mentioned. However, some ports in the United States are not visited by conventional or nuclear- powered warships either because there is no operational requirement to do so or because of particular port characteristics such as channel depth, accessibility, port services, and so on. These requirements are assessed by national, not local authorities. The criteria employed by the United States authorities in deciding visits by United States Navy nuclear-powered ships to United States domestic ports are identical with those employed for visits to foreign ports.

Accordingly, I am not in a position to deny the suggestions that have been made by Senator Mason, but certainly the Government appears to have no information which would confirm it. As to the question of nuclear attacks on Sydney being made more likely by the presence of allied warships, the Government's response is that it is our judgment that United States naval visits support important Australian strategic interests. The Government will continue to welcome United States ships to Australian ports, confident that the United States Navy will apply the same rigorous safety measures in Australia as it applies in United States ports.

As to the third and fourth matters about the potential destructive capacity of nuclear weapons in these circumstances, I am advised that the Government considers that global nuclear war is a remote and most unlikely possibility. Indeed, I have stated that proposition on behalf of the Government on several occasions in recent months. The risks of utter devastation inherent in conflict on such a scale sustain the maintenance of deterrence and peace. If a period of tension were to ensue and the possibility of such conflict were in prospect, it would not be assumed, as the question appears to do, that there would be no change in the pattern of activities of warships in order to take account of the changing strategic circumstances.

As to the final matter with respect to the relocation of the dry-docking facility where it might be less controversially utilised by allies, the Government's response is that, provided satisfactory safety standards are observed, the considerations raised by Senator Mason in this respect should not influence the balance of judgments which led previous examinations of the relocation of Garden Island Dockyard and fleet base to the conclusion that the large capital and social costs involved in moving from Garden Island were not justifiable and that development should continue on that site.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I referred to the fact that the moving of Garden Island could be substantially financed by the sale of the very valuable real estate Garden Island represents, which I am told would probably realise close to the value of $1 billion. Was this taken into account when the survey was carried out?

—Certainly that point has been taken into consideration in the briefing I have received on this matter. I understand that there is still a substantial net cost involved in any transfer, even taking into account that return from such sale.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of a survey being conducted by a public relations consultant in relation to the introduction of Medicare? As the letter uses such phrases as 'in the national interest', it is conceivable that a number of people who received the questionnaire would believe that it has some official standing. Will the Minister advise whether this is so or whether, as I suspect, it is being done on behalf of private health insurance companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention has been drawn to an alleged survey being done by Ross M. Walker, who is allegedly a management and public relations consultant in Sydney, who claims to be surveying prominent national figures as to whether they will take up health cover after the introduction of Medicare or whether they will continue or discontinue private health insurance that they already have once Medicare has been introduced. First, let me assure the honourable senator that this is not an official survey. There is no indication on the letter as to who has commissioned the survey, but if one reads the letter and looks at the questionnaire one can have a fair idea of what it is all about. In conducting a survey such as this to find out the facts and, therefore, to publicise the facts, there are certain criteria that polling organisations use usually that this organisation is clearly not using. First, the survey and the answers for which it is asking are not anonymous. The respondent's name is required to be put on the letter. Secondly, I believe it is necessary that the results of the survey as taken should reflect the views of the people who are taking part in the survey. The second paragraph of the letter states:

ANSWER.PARA: This is being done in the national interest with the purpose of establishing or otherwise the considered need by the majority of private health cover.
One would wonder what a survey of only a select group of public figures has to do with the general needs of the community for private health cover. But the third paragraph states:
Your co-operation in replying would be appreciated as a non-reply will be taken as an indication that you are maintaining your private health insurance.

In a survey taken like this, in which people are asked to divulge private information, which many people may consider to be their own business, for an organisation then to say that a non-reply will be taken as an affirmative result and to incorporate this in the findings can result only in a false result and in a grossly distorted survey. It is interesting that the letter speaks of maintaining private insurance in one section, but then speaks of whether people will take out or continue private insurance; but the questions refer only to continuation of private insurance, as though everyone surveyed would automatically have had private insurance in the first place.

In summing up and in looking at this, one can conclude that this is not a survey but a questionnaire designed to produce a phoney result, which will then be reproduced as a scientific survey in order to push one line, that line being that overwhelmingly the select group of private figures take out private health insurance. The survey is not honest. The results of such a survey cannot be honest. One can conclude that the public relations aspect of Mr Walker's business is the one that is predominant here and that he is acting on behalf of interested parties to produce a specific result, not in any scientific way.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Attorney-General in his capacity representing the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I draw the Attorney's attention to yet another quotation from the interview with Mr Scholes, the Minister for Defence, on yesterday's AM program, when Mr Scholes said in respect of what he told the British High Commissioner:

QUESTION.PARA: I set out what were the Government's requirements, the Government's long- standing policies.
I ask the Attorney whether one of these policies would be that outlined to the House of Representatives last Thursday, by the Minister, when he said:
This Government has a very specific policy on nuclear ships and matters nuclear . We do not permit nuclear weapons on Australian soil.

As HMS Invincible is not nuclear powered, does not the Minister's AM statement clearly refer to the possibility of Invincible carrying nuclear weapons? Does the Attorney concede that the Minister raised the nuclear arms issue knowing full well what response he could expect from the British High Commissioner and forcing him into the position of having to forgo use of the Sydney dry dock on the ground of 'operational reasons'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what matters Mr Scholes was referring to in his interview on AM yesterday to which Senator Scott referred. I do not know whether one of the matters the Minister for Defence was talking about then was the matter to which he referred in the House of Representatives the previous week. I will refer that aspect of the question to the Minister to see what further information he might care to provide. As to the Government's general policy on the question of access by nuclear or possibly nuclear armed or powered ships, I simply say that that matter was the subject of further consideration by the Cabinet this morning. A number of discussion points have been identified which will be the subject of quite detailed consultations with our allies in the period immediately ahead. Those consultations will clarify the guidelines as they have operated in this area in the past because there are some manifest difficulties and obscurities in anticipating all the different situations that may arise and, to some extent, did arise in this case. Until those consultations continue it is not appropriate to say anything more publicly about what is or is not the Government's present policy.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe, however, Mr President, that this might be an appropriate time to put in context some further matters about the course of events leading to the decision of the British naval authorities not to dry dock the ship and perhaps in that respect to add to the answer which I gave to Senator Sir John Carrick yesterday and which I promised to expand further after consultation with the Minister. The further material that I have been supplied with by the Minister is to the following effect: The British decided that, for operational reasons, it would not be necessary to dry dock HMS Invincible during its visit to Sydney. We understand that the technical problems which Invincible was experiencing were not so serious that dry docking was essential at this time. It is, of course, for the British Government to decide whether and in what circumstances it might wish to dock its ships. Further, the Government has no reason to believe that the captain of Invincible had any cause for thinking that the maintenance and repairs of the ship would not be done expertly and speedily and the ship released in reasonable time to continue its journey.

Senator Sir John Carrick sought further assurances about a third point. The question of giving assurances that the work would be performed effectively and speedily did not arise. As to the last matter on which Senator Sir John Carrick sought assurances-that is, whether the Government or the captain had any reason to believe that the work might not be performed speedily and effectively-the position is as follows: We have no reason to believe that the captain of Invincible entertained any doubts about the effectiveness and timeliness of the work which might have been performed in dry dock. All that goes to the question that was essentially at issue here, that is, the operational requirements of the Royal Navy and the fact that, having regard to those operational requirements, the question of dry docking was, after some discussion, not pursued.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. I ask the Attorney-General whether the early part of his answer, in particular, means that the Government as well as our allies are somewhat unclear as to the policy that controls the docking of naval ships in Australian dry docks?

—There has been no lack of clarity in the basic principles. They are those that have been articulated on other occasions by Mr Scholes in, for example, the parliamentary speech to which Senator Scott referred. There may be a degree of uncertainty as to the way in which those principles are to be applied in particular cases. That is something that remains to be explored in consultation with our allies to ensure that there is no possibility of misunderstanding occurring in the future. I make no concession that there was any misunderstanding or uncertainty on this occasion. I simply make the point on behalf of the Government that, in the light of all the controversy that has been generated by this matter, it is obviously desirable to reconsider the language in which those principles and guidelines are expressed and to consult with our allies in ensuring that everyone is in fact happy with the way they operate.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is he aware of an Australian Broadcasting Corporation news report of 12 December which stated that the Japanese Prime Minister, Mr Nakasone, said that Japan would apply to all ships its long standing policy of not allowing nuclear weapons into the country and that this would apply also to HMS Invincible? Is this the same criterion as the Australian Government will apply to ships wanting docking in Australian ports, including HMS Invincible?

—I understand that there have been Press reports that the Japanese would apply certain conditions before approving a port call by HMS Invincible. I am not able to comment on whether these reports reflect accurately the view of the Japanese Government. I do not have that much information available at the moment. We have not discussed with Japan its policy on port calls by warships which may be carrying nuclear weapons, nor are we aware of any discussions which Japan may have held recently with others, including the British, on this matter. Under the Japanese Government's three non-nuclear principles, which have been articulated publicly from time to time, the introduction of nuclear weapons into Japan, the possession of nuclear weapons by Japan and the manufacture of nuclear weapons in Japan, all are prohibited. How in practice those guidelines are applied is not something on which I am able to give the honourable senator any further information at the moment. As to the part of her question which relates to Australia's policy in these matters, my answer to that has to be the same as that which I just gave to Senator Scott.
—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. What will the Government do about the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Amendment Bill 1983 and the constitution alteration proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government decided this morning that, when this matter goes to the vote tomorrow, if the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine continue to insist either that the Government can spend nothing on promoting the Yes case or that the Government must spend an equal amount on promoting the Yes and No cases-that is, over and above the $5m which the Government has already committed to spend on preparing and distributing the statutory even handed Yes-No pamphlet-the proposed referendums will not proceed on 25 February. The Government remains committed to pursue the proposed Constitution alterations which have attracted broad cross party and cross government support in both the Australian Parliament and the Australian Constitutional Convention. We will give further consideration in the New Year to the most appropriate timing for doing so.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me just add that, if any responsibility is to be attached for these referendums not proceeding in the event that the Opposition, the Democrats and Senator Harradine persist with their present attitude, it should be clearly understood that that responsibility squarely lies with those whom I have mentioned-the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. Despite all the huffing and puffing we have heard from these parties about a commitment to constitutional reform, despite all that we have heard about the desirability of measures not going to referendum without cross party support, despite all the support that has been evident over the last 10 years for these proposals at the Australian Constitutional Convention, it is apparent that the real support for constructive constitutional change so far as the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats are concerned is about as great as the degree of commitment of Peter Clyne to pay his taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer to the Minister's decision last April to overturn the razor gang decision of the previous Government to allow commercial manufacturers a share of the market in supplying artificial limbs to repatriation beneficiaries. I ask the Minister whether his decision to deny any new manufacturers access to the repatriation free limb scheme has resulted in a significant reduction in the share held by commercial manufacturers in that scheme. If not, what further steps does the Minister plan to take?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably not generally known that the Rehabilitation and Artificial Limb Appliance Centre which operates under the Department of Veterans ' Affairs supplies artificial limbs not only to veterans but also to all other disabled persons throughout Australia. The cost is borne by the Commonwealth Government. The decision of the Fraser Government to take advantage of the Review of Commonwealth Functions to enter a private enterprise content into the system created a greater destabilising effect upon that organisation than I expected. As Senator Zakharov suggested, my announcement earlier this year was in two parts. Firstly, I indicated that no new commercial manufacturers would be allowed into the system from the date of that announcement because their entrance into the system would increase by about 33 per cent the cost factor for the supply of the artificial limbs. Secondly, I indicated that I would act on recommendations from an independent consultant's report on the fees and the structure of the free limb scheme. Having had a chance to look thoroughly at the RALAC organisation since then, I have come to the conclusion that the razor gang decision almost destroyed the viability of the whole operation of that scheme, which has been functioning since World War I. It is quite clear to the Government that there is no place for the profit motive in the rehabilitation services, in particular the supplying of artificial limbs to disabled persons.

ANSWER.PARA: I have now made three further decisions designed not merely to halt the decline which the razor gang set in motion but also to create some improvement in the scheme and to get the scheme back into efficient operation. The first decision I have had to make in recent times is to freeze the share of commercial enterprises in the free limb scheme as at 31 December 1983 to prevent any unauthorised change of ownership or corporate structure by participating companies and to require those companies to use award wages in their pricing calculations, thus limiting their ability to poach skilled RALAC staff, something which has been a very big problem for that organisation. The second decision is to improve the service provided by RALAC by extending its hours of operation, providing a RALAC visiting service to country centres, including the establishment of decentralised agencies and a mobile workshop, and expanding the marketing of our services, particularly in Victoria because something is radically wrong with the operation of the scheme in that State as it relates to the State hospital system. The third decision is to control the cost of the free limb scheme by introducing measures to reduce the scope for overservicing by private participating companies. I am confident that those three additional decisions will ensure a much more reliable, efficient and cost-effective RALAC service for those who participate in the free limb scheme.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VISITING WARSHIPS: PORT AND DOCKING FACILITIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Ministers for Defence and Foreign Affairs. I refer to the discussions which were initiated as a result of the phone call between Mr Hayden and United States Secretary of State Shultz yesterday and between the Department of Foreign Affairs and the United States Government which, I take it from earlier answers which Senator Evans has given today, are continuing as a result of a Cabinet discussion this morning. Is the Attorney-General aware that British defence officials are looking already for alternative ship repair facilities in the Asian region because of the Australian Government's attitude to the docking facilities for HMS Invincible? Is the Attorney-General in a position to assure the Senate, the Australian people and our allies that the Hawke Government will not deny access to Australian port and repair facilities for allied warships and that such access will not be just on the narrow basis of safety which he mentioned yesterday?

—I doubt that there is anything I can add in this respect to answers already given. I did make it perfectly clear yesterday that if ever there were any question of the safety of a ship or its crew being in issue, whether that ship be merchant marine or any kind of naval vessel, there would be no question but that assistance would be rendered, under those circumstances, in whatever form necessary. There are, obviously, very much larger public policy questions involved here. When one comes to the other criteria that might be applied as far as both docking and dry docking facilities for naval warships are concerned, as I have already indicated those matters-the particular criteria to be applied, the particular principles and the particular guidelines that are to operate in practice-were the subject of Cabinet discussion this morning and will be the subject of extensive consultation with all our relevant allies in the next few days.

—I ask the Minister representing the Ministers for Defence and Foreign Affairs a supplementary question. How does the Government possibly reconcile that wishy-washy response with the responsibilities that we have to our allies?
—I call the Minister representing the Ministers for Defence and Foreign Affairs, if he regards the question as supplementary.
—I regard it as no more than a piece of windy rhetoric, Mr President, and I do not answer it further.

—Can the Minister representing the Treasurer document the interest, or lack of it, in economic matters displayed by members of the Liberal and National Party Senate Opposition, as evidenced by their performance at Question Time in recent weeks? Is the number of questions asked on economic matters an indicator of an economy which is strengthening, contrary to claims made yesterday in the Age by the shadow Treasurer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have some figures on the analysis of questions asked by the Opposition during this session of Parliament. The Opposition asked no questions on economic growth and on interest rates the Opposition-at least the Liberal and Country parties; I am excluding the Australian Democrats-asked one. Members of the Opposition asked three questions on the Budget. They did ask 20 on incomes policies, presumably because they do not have an incomes policy of their own. On macroeconomic issues in general they asked a total of 45 questions, which was about 9 per cent of all the questions they asked. However, that is about 6 per cent higher than the figure for the Australian Democrats; approximately 3 per cent of their questions were on macroeconomics. The Liberal and Country parties, on the other hand, take a great interest in New South Wales. They asked 27 questions about New South Wales, compared with 25 questions on macroeconomic policy, excluding an incomes policy. I can, of course, understand. Most of the questions asked by the Liberal and Country parties were on frivolous or phoney matters.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The Minister is using the wrong title for the National Party. It is the National Party, and I bring that to his attention.
—There is no point of order.

—I do not want to be misunderstood. If Senator Boswell insists on its being the National Party, so be it. It is, however, known in my State as the National Country Party. It is known by various names and aliases. Most of the questions asked by the official Opposition were on phoney and frivolous matters.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. The question in no way relates to the responsibilities of the Minister or of any Minister he represents in this place. The fact of the matter is that the Minister has done a great deal to sabotage Question Time by giving long lectures instead of answers. I ask you to keep him to the question and to ensure that he permits genuine questions to be asked in this place instead of farcical questions such as that asked by the senator from South Australia.
—Order! I did listen closely to the question. It did involve government administration. I ask the Minister to relate his remarks to the question and not debate the issues involved.
—Very well, Mr President. I can understand the Opposition's reluctance to ask questions on economic issues. I have just noted its record on economic issues.
—I ask the Minister to relate his remarks to the question.

—Yes, Mr President. Senator Maguire also asked me about an article in, I think, yesterday's Age. I had noticed yesterday's Age. I noticed that the discredited former Treasurer is not so reticent, or perhaps astute, as other members of the Opposition in this place, because in this article he is reported to have predicted that interest rates and unemployment would both go up in the next year. He is, of course, an expert on those matters because at the end of five years of his Treasurership unemployment and inflation were both above 10 per cent; unemployment at the highest level at which it had been for 50 years, and interest rates at the highest level they had ever been.

ANSWER.PARA: So one can sympathise with the reluctance to discuss economic policy. One can sympathise with the Opposition in general for still having as its economic spokesman a former Treasurer who, after five years, produced those results as the end result of his policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing both the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has he seen reports that about $15,000 worth of blocks were ordered by the Captain Cook drydock in Sydney in anticipation of their use by HMS Invincible? Can he give an accurate figure as to the cost of this preparatory work? Will the bill be footed by the dockyard itself or will responsibility for the expense be borne by the Department of Defence or, possibly, the Royal Australian Navy? Who will pay?
—I have no information on the matters to which the honourable senator referred but I will do my best to find out as soon as possible and let him know.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer able to advise what use is made of data produced by the question on Australian census forms in relation to religion? Is it proposed that there will be no question in relation to religion in the next Australian census? If so, what is the reason for this decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a note on this matter which tells me that in relation to the first part of the question, that is, what use is made of the data, the answer is rather complicated and the Australian Bureau of Statistics would prefer to supply to Senator Colston in time a written answer and a considered reply.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of the question, as to whether the non-obligatory question on religion is to be included on future census forms, is currently under review. It is expected that, by the time the Senate sits at the end of February next year, a definite decision will have been made on whether any question on religion is to be included on the next census form.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I refer to the unique approach which has been adopted by the Government to referenda. I do not mean by that the on-again, off-again nature of the proposals which have been put forward by the Attorney over that time, but I refer firstly to the attempt made by the Attorney and the Government, without reference to this Parliament, to re- word the questions which were to be put to the Australian people; secondly, the failure of the Government to table the regulations in the normal way so that they could have been subject to parliamentary disallowance-an omission which the Attorney sought to rectify by putting the new questions into the legislation we have recently had before us; and thirdly, the unique proposal to fund an advertising campaign using taxpayers' funds for the Yes case only. Does the Attorney believe that he advances the cause of constitutional amendment by trying to present the people of Australia with a stacked deck?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take those issues in turn. As to the re-wording of the questions on the ballot paper, it has long been the view of many people on both sides of politics that the practice which has prevailed, albeit only since 1967-before then the short title of the Bill was used in the question-of putting the long title of the Bill served only to make more unintelligible and inaccessible to the average voters what the subject matter was that they were being asked to pass upon than was appropriate for anyone committed to the sensible operation of the democratic process. The path taken was in fact to try to write the essence of the proposal going before the people in plain, concrete, non-abstract language. That effort was made in good faith, so much so that the wording of the first question added a reference to a variation of the terms of honourable senators, which is something dear to the hearts of the No case, which was not in fact there in the terms of the long title.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr President, these matters have been debated amply in this place and I do not think this is the occasion to debate them again. I make the point though that the re-written language of the ballot paper was made the subject of a regulation which was of course able to be and was meant to be the subject of proper debate in this place should anyone have been minded to move a disallowance motion. There is no question of bypassing parliamentary scrutiny.

As to the second matter of the tabling of that particular regulation, the circumstances in which there was a delay-I readily concede an unfortunate delay- which occurred as an administrative matter have already been explained. There was no intent to deceive in any way in this respect and, if Senator Chaney wants to make such an allegation under cover of privilege, well, that is his coward's entitlement and I welcome the opportunity to pursue--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Mr President!
—Order! I suggest the honourable senator withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw, Mr President. I think the point is made. To the extent that--
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Attorney said: 'I withdraw, but the point has been made'. I do not consider that a full withdrawal .
—I ask the Attorney-General to withdraw.

—I withdraw, Mr President. I believe the regulations were in fact tabled last week and, to the extent that it remains relevant for them to be further debated in the light of recent developments and the incorporation ultimately of the ballot paper questions into the legislation itself, that opportunity will of course arise and, I understand, has been created by a notice of motion from Senator Harradine today.

ANSWER.PARA: I turn to the final matter which is the question of the Government's proposed financial support for the Yes case over and above the $5m that has already been provided even handedly under the statutory obligation which the Government readily continues to accept to put a pamphlet containing the No case as well as the Yes case into every letterbox in the country. As to this particular controversy, the reason of course, I repeat, why the Government chose to follow this path is that we believed there was cross-party support and indeed cross- government support for these particular referendum proposals, as demonstrated not only by the votes in this Parliament but also by the whole course of proceedings in the Australian Constitutional Convention over the last 10 years.

We believed further that there was very strong evidence from past history that the No case in any referendum campaign, whatever its intrinsic irrationality, always starts with an advantage because of the apathy of the Australian electorate to these matters, the complexity of the issues on which they are obliged to pass and the natural response of people when confronted with conflict to adopt a cautious No approach. That is well established as a matter of political science research over the better part of this century. That is a fact of life that anyone running a referendum campaign has to cope with. To get the Yes case into the same perceptual field even as the No case does require a differential effort. The fact that such an effort has not been made in the past, the fact that no sophisticated campaigning involving expenditure of the kind that was contemplated by the Government has been conducted in the past, is one clear and obvious reason, I would suggest, why so many referendum campaigns in the past, whatever their merits and their degree of bipartisan support, have in fact failed. If there are any conventions, to quote Senator Macklin's contribution to the debate on radio this morning, governing the conduct of referendum campaigns, the only one I can think of is the convention that referendums in this country always fail, and that is a convention we were seeking to break-the convention we were seeking to turn around. We wanted to create the possibility where the Yes case would be fully appreciated, given the bipartisan support it commands, by the Australian people. The refusal of the Opposition parties, notionally committed to constitutional reform and notionally committed to these measures to come on board, the refusal of the Australian Democrats to accept the force of this proposal,which is of course given added weight by the notorious public fact that Mr Grey is proposing to spend taxpayers ' money in Tasmania on the No case and that Mr Bjelke-Petersen will do the same in all those matters there has been utter refusal to take them into account by honourable senators, if that is the proper description, for reasons of crude, political opportunistic advantage and for reasons having nothing to do with the high principles which they so hypocritically espouse.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. How does the Attorney square that answer with the fact that the Fraser Government succeeded in three of its four referendums without recourse to taxpayers' funds in the way that he was proposing?

—The particular matter which was most important, and universally regarded as most important, in 1977 and on which the No case people campaigned most vigorously and most irrationally was the proposal that in fact went down notwithstanding that it won the support of 62 1/2 per cent--
—What was that proposal?

—The simultaneous elections proposal. It went down, notwithstanding that it won the support of 62.5 per cent of the Australian electorate, because of a very carefully devised and tailored No case campaign which concentrated in three small States only in electorate terms-Tasmania, Queensland and Western Australia. It was possible by the expenditure of significant sums of money by the No case campaigners and the focusing of the campaign in that way to defeat what was manifestly a proposal that commanded widespread, popular and community support across the nation. Exactly those same logistics are potentially applicable in the context of this referendum campaign and it was, of course, for that reason, amongst others, that the Government thought it entirely appropriate, bearing in mind the supposedly consensual character of these proposals, to spend the extra money-really only a drop in the bucket compared with the basic cost of the referendum-in order to promote effectively and ensure that the Yes case would be understood effectively.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs been drawn to an article in West Australian Education News which states that parents and students in Western Australia have described secondary schools in that State as good, caring institutions with many satisfactory courses of study? Can the Minister comment on the suggestion that education decision makers, principals and teachers may take encouragement from this preliminary research into perceptions of public education in Western Australia?

—Yes, I have seen a newspaper report of the matter with which Senator Giles's question is concerned. It does not surprise me at all that a survey has shown a very high degree of satisfaction by parents who choose public education in Western Australia. Nor would it surprise me if surveys showed a similar high degree of satisfaction by parents using public education throughout Australia. Certainly, in the Australian Capital Territory-my own electorate-I am very well aware of a very high degree of parent satisfaction with government schooling. However, I think it is useful to have such evidence available because some of the claims that have been made in the current education debate suggest that government schooling is not satisfactory to the majority of parents who choose it. So I am pleased to see that there is some objective data backing up what I think anybody who moves around the education community would know, and that is that, generally speaking, our government schools meet the needs of parents, teachers and students.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. What action, if any, does the Government intend taking to reduce the potential for a relatively minor dispute in the railways system of one State of Australia from disrupting railways across Australia? Is the Commonwealth Government taking any steps to avoid another major strike which could take interstate trains off the system, disappointing thousands of trans- Australia passengers simply because of a demarcation dispute between two unions in Western Australia?

—Senator Jack Evans asks a question which primarily at this stage is still in the jurisdiction of the State Government of Western Australia. The resolution of that dispute lies in negotiations between the railway unions and the Western Australian Government. At this stage I am advised that there is very little that the Commonwealth Government can do in respect of that dispute. Even though I concede the honourable senator's interest and, for that matter, the Commonwealth's interest in averting any sort of national rail strike, I advise the honourable senator that the matter does not strictly come within my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I suggest that the matter is more one for the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations than the Minister for Transport. I do not know, therefore, whether my colleague the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations is able to add anything further. My advice is that it would be inappropriate to make any further comments on the dispute at this stage, except to say that it is hoped that common sense will prevail and a national stoppage will not eventuate.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Has the Queensland Premier communicated with the Federal Government his intention to disrupt industrial stability by introducing repressive industrial laws modelled on Britain's anti- union employment act? Is this not in direct conflict with the Federal Government 's prices and incomes policy which is committed to review the manner in which Commonwealth-State industrial relations systems might be better interrelated? How can the Federal Government use its industrial wisdom to persuade the Queensland Premier that such authoritarian legislation will not be tolerated within the Australian union movement and that Queensland workers are Australian citizens and, therefore, are entitled to industrial justice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as I am aware the Queensland Premier has not specifically communicated with the Federal Government to indicate that he has what a former aspirant to politics in Victoria once called 'a fresh approach' to industrial relations. He has, however, made a public announcement about this matter that he was clearly impressed, I gather from what he saw overseas and so on. He is intent apparently on embarking on more draconian industrial relations legislation.
—Seriously, I think you should send him a copy of the select committee's report.
—He is intent on introducing more draconian anti-union legislation or industrial relations legislation than that State has previously had.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked a question earlier in Question Time today about the relationship between the Federal Government's industrial relations policies and the level of industrial unrest in Australia in the nine months that this Government has been in office. I commend the approach adopted by the Federal Government to the Premier of Queensland for a number of reasons: Firstly, it is very important that all aspects of government in Australia be brought into the latter half of the twentieth century as quickly as possible. That applies to Queensland as well as everywhere else. Secondly, I hope that the Premier heeds the view of what I would describe as moderate trade unions in Queensland, such as the Australian Workers Union, a powerful and influential union. It has made the point that the proposed legislation can do nothing but exacerbate bad industrial relations in Queensland.

I take it that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations will convey to the Premier of Queensland the different approach which the Federal Government has in relation to industrial relations. By common agreement in the last sitting week of this Parliament we moved towards a more unified and co-ordinated approach to industrial relations in this country when we passed the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983. It was universally supported that there was a need for greater co-ordination and unity in our approach to industrial relations issues throughout the Commonwealth. If the Premier of Queensland thinks that in 1983 he can embark on a different course successfully, the Federal Government does not agree with him and we will let him know, for the reasons I have indicated.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the rail strike in Western Australia?

—I suppose that Senator Bjelke-Petersen has a particular place of honour in this Senate in that she is able to communicate with two parliaments at once. Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked: 'What about the rail strike in Western Australia?'. The honourable senator can go on until she is black and blue in the face picking up isolated instances of unfortunate industrial relations behaviour around the Commonwealth, and they will occur. But it does not make a case for a change in a system of the kind which has been mooted by the Premier of Queensland. Senator Harradine asked by way of interjection why we do not send him a copy of the Harradine report, that is, the report of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation. I am sure that if I provide the postage Senator Harradine will see that he gets a copy. I hope he reads it.

—Yesterday in Question Time Senator Messner asked me a question relating to the employment of staff in the Department of Social Security in connection with the proposed assets and incomes test. I undertook to provide the answer. At this stage a total of 482 staff are currently employed on activities associated with the proposed assets test. They are employed as follows: One hundred and thirteen working on planning and development activities in State headquarters and the central office, 369 new recruits undertaking basic training or who are gaining on the job experience so that they can replace staff who will be required for further training prior to the implementation of the incomes and assets test. The staff are being paid from the principal salaries appropriation for the Department of Social Security which is division 560.1.01, salaries and allowances.

—This morning during the debate on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983, Senator Watson asked me a question about some activities of what was believed to be an officer of the Department of Health in Launceston. I undertook to obtain information for him. I have had the matter investigated by the Health Department. My information is as follows: Health Department officers have undertaken a number of investigations in Tasmania including Launceston in recent weeks. I understand these investigations have now ceased. These investigations are not to imply that any doctor has, of necessity, been found guilty or is involved in fraud or overservicing. In the course of these investigations I am informed that no Health Department officer has entered a doctor's surgery in any way or behaved in any way in the manner alleged, namely, that a female officer was sitting in a doctor's surgery with a stopwatch timing patients. I am further informed that no female investigator was involved in these departmental investigations at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 November I was asked a question without notice by Senator Jessop relating to the decision by the New South Wales Government to transfer nurse education from hospital based to college based training. In my reply I undertook to see what information the State Minister for Health would be prepared to make available to the Senate on the subject. The Minister has provided me with a lengthy summary of the main features of the transfer proposal. I ask leave to have this information incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The main features of the proposal on the transfer are as follows:

1. All student nurses currently in training in hospital based schools of nursing will not be affected and will be able to complete their studies in hospital nurse training schools as hospital employees.
2. Hospitals will continue to train midwives, enrolled nurses and mothercraft nurses for the time being.
3. No students will be recruited by hospitals into programmes preparing nurses for general, psychiatric and mental retardation nursing registration after 1984.
4. Recruitment to hospital based programmes will continue in 1984.

5. Commencing in 1985, country and metropolitan colleges of advanced education in New South Wales will offer a total of about 3,000 student places a year into nursing programmes leading to the award of a diploma (UG2 level) in nursing.
The student numbers enrolled in basic nursing programmes in colleges funded by Health by April 1987 is expected to be about 7,500.

6. Teachers of nursing employed in hospital based schools of nursing in New South Wales will be afforded job opportunities in colleges of advanced education , detailed arrangements for this will be developed in consultation with relevant industrial organisations and the higher education sector.

7. Courses will aim at preparing a safe and reliable first year registered nurse. All basic courses will include instruction in medical/surgical, psychiatric, paediatric, maternal and child health nursing and nursing care of the developmentally disabled and the aged.

8. A state planning group of senior officers from health, education and treasury has been established to develop a detailed plan to implement the proposal in consultation with the nursing profession, higher education sector and the health system as a whole. Much of the implementation will be effected at the local level by negotiations between colleges and health services in their geographical area.

9. Courses which propose a compulsory period of paid workforce experience as part of the course will not be agreed to for funding by the health department because of the difficulties this would create for hospitals as employers. However, some colleges may offer study by part-time mode as the question of employment is then unrelated to completion of the course.

10. Clinical teaching will be the financial responsibility of colleges. It is anticipated that a variety of arrangements will be made depending on local circumstances and the expertise available in both colleges, hospitals and health services generally.

11. It is anticipated that the nurses registration board will require about half of the course to be devoted to practical training in either a simulated or real clinical environment e.g. hospitals, community health. The courses will consist of about 6 semesters of 16 weeks full time study.
12. Health will fund the full equivalent full-time student (EFTS) costs of colleges for the conduct of these basic nursing programmes.

13. Hospital nurse training school facilities and equipment will be available for use by colleges if required. Colleges will gradually undertake responsibility for the maintainance costs of such facilities from their EFTS funds provided by the state health department.

14. State savings made as hospital based student numbers reduce will be allocated on a per capita basis for students commencing after 1984 in colleges of advanced education. Fourteen colleges are involved and the slight variation in costs between colleges, and the college places for state funded students will be monitored initially by the state planning group.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Instruments and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

This is a series of conventions adopted by the International Labour Organisation in June 1982. The conventions go to a number of matters and are accompanied by a text commenting on them by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). While it is true, as the Minister makes clear, that the Labor Government of Australia has not yet deliberated on its final attitude to recommending the adoption of these conventions, some of them are obviously appropriate for adoption in Australia and others are less appropriate. The International Labour Organisation, a sub-organisation of the United Nations, is a major and important organisation for industrial relations in Australia. This country has participated in the ILO all the way through. It has played an important role. It is respected. The Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Hawke) was a member of the governing body for many years and a leading participant in debates at the ILO. Last year he opened the session that later brought forth the documents the Senate has before it today.

Australian delegations to the ILO, of which in the past I have been privileged to be a member, have played a significant role and are respected on the world stage for making significant contributions to international debate on industrial relations. Irrespective of the differences employers, unions and governments might have domestically, and while we form a tripartite delegation to attend the ILO, it is amazing how much accord and commonality of view can be found and jointly expressed in that world forum. While all those things are true, it is unfortunate that in the period of office of the last Government the Committee of Experts on the Application of Conventions and Recommendations of the ILO found, on application by the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association of Australia and the Australian Public Service Association, that the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act transgressed one of the conventions of the ILO. While Third World countries and countries with authoritarian and military regimes from time to time are held by the Committee of Experts to have broken ILO conventions, it is not expected that a developed country such as Australia, with a mature system of parliamentary democracy, should break a convention which it has adopted.

Two significant conventions have been tabled today. One relates to social security and deals with the reciprocal exchange of benefits between countries. Because of Australia's wholly government-funded and government supplied social security system, as opposed to contributory systems in other countries, it is not as obvious that we should proceed in haste to adopt that convention. The other convention before us relates to termination of employment at the initiative of the employer. I participated in the ILO debate on this convention. It is unfortunately important in Australia today. One finds in any country suffering the throes of economic recession that workers are victimised in employment, that sexual harassment is rampant in the employment situation, and that workers have their employment terminated at the initiative of the employer without consultation because of automation, structural change or mere economic matters.

This convention seeks to encode internationally a series of provisions which would ensure proper conduct in those circumstances. It is important to note that the Australian Government, in making submissions to the recently concluded job security case taken before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, was backed by this convention in all of the submissions that it made. It is an important convention that Australia would do well to adopt. It is also significant that Australia, unlike a number of other European and, in this case, Asian countries, including Japan, has difficulties in effecting automation and changes in the economy. That is because we have a tradition of not consulting with the workers who will be affected by those changes. I conclude my remarks at that point. I commend the papers to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to speak briefly on the question of the day, that is, the availability or otherwise of dry docking facilities through the Department of Defence Support. In recent days the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), speaking on behalf of the Government and the relevant Ministers, has added confusion to confusion and has refused to come to the nub of the matter. He is certain that HMS Invincible sought to have repairs done and that discussions took place intimating that the Government was willing to allow it to do so. I understand also that substantial preparatory measures were taken at Garden Island Dockyard to facilitate the docking of the vessel and that considerable expenditure was incurred in that regard. Then suddenly a number of things happened. The Minister for Defence, Mr Scholes, made a statement on the matter and after that Invincible decided that it would not proceed. There has been no explanation of this at all; just deliberate confusion.

This took place after the debacle when Mr Cain, the Victorian Premier, sought to exclude nuclear powered ships from Port Phillip. It is important to know that Mr Hayden had to eat his words and to lay down certain principles. Those principles were laid down following a meeting on 22 June at which I understand Mr Scholes, the Minister for Defence, was present. These are important things for the public to realise. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, acknowledged that a failure to accept visits by nuclear armed warships would, in his words, 'effectively demolish' the ANZUS alliance. That is very much what has happened on this occasion although we are dealing with another ally. Mr Hayden went on to say:
If we were to require a declaration that ships were nuclear-armed, it would make it virtually impossible for the Americans to operate in the context of ANZUS.
He said further:
Nothing I have said here would prevent the use of our ports for maintenance, essential repairs or refits, regular rest and recreation for crews and ships of allies or treaty partners.

That was Mr Hayden's statement. Nevertheless, what he said would happen has not happened. The very reverse has happened. Contrary to what Mr Hayden said on 22 June, Mr Scholes intervened with something quite different. He said that we could not have nuclear armament ships being dry docked in Australia. Where was the basis for that statement? That was a deliberate rejection of what Mr Hayden had said in the past.

More and more nonsense has been talked. The Attorney-General treats this Senate like a group of schoolboys. He gave a complete misrepresentation of nuclear armaments. He talked of them exploding as though those kinds of armaments would explode. As everybody knows, they are not triggered in their normal storage situation and there is no circumstance in which they will explode. He has added a schoolboy misstatement to the whole situation. I think the crux of what he said today when he was talking about the various factors was his statement that an industrial factor might be involved. Indeed, we have not heard enough about this situation. I do not believe that anything as serious as this has happened in recent years. Here is a threat to the defence security of Australia, the very rejection of our allies. We say to the British and the Americans: 'You cannot get repairs here for ships that are nuclear armed'. Something very drastic has happened. What has happened in the last few days is quite different from what Mr Hayden said on 22 June. The Australian people need to know why the statements of 22 June were not applied in this case. Was the Australian Government unwilling to ensure or incapable of ensuring that such a ship could be docked, repaired and released? What went on? That question is unanswered and should be answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a little distressed to hear Senator Sir John Carrick who, like myself, is a senator for New South Wales, raise this matter and canvass some important issues; but they are not the only important issues at stake. The Australian Democrats and I would be the last to denigrate the ANZUS alliance; we would be the last to say that we should not assist Britain whenever we can. We are very well aware of the historical background and the importance of these friendships and alliances. But I should have thought that the duty of a senator for a State is to think first for the people of that State. I cannot for the life of me see why we should tolerate or continue to tolerate a situation in which our largest population centre, Sydney, is being compelled by circumstances to be the place in which nuclear weapons are to be regularly located. That, after all, is what is being said by people who say that HMS Invincible should not have been denied dry docking in Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: The other side of the coin is to say that the people of Sydney must tolerate a situation in which, without notice or knowledge at any time, peacetime or wartime, they must have nuclear weapons in their midst. Let us remember that Garden Island is right in the middle of Sydney. It is a quarter of a mile from the Opera House. Sydney is our largest centre of population; approximately 25 per cent of Australians live there. I do not believe that anybody will bring in nuclear weapons with the idea of them exploding. But the history of the world has always depended on the odd chance. Although the risk of having these weapons in Sydney is a very small one-I acknowledge it to be small-the consequences could be absolutely appalling.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they do not explode.
—They explode if somebody hits them with another missile.
—They do not.

—Indeed they do. I suggest that Senator Sir John Carrick do some more reading. I can recommend some material to him. If a nuclear weapon were dropped over Garden Island and there were a ship in that place carrying nuclear weapons, of course those weapons would vapourise and their isotopes would be scattered over a wide area. Writers of the calibre of Jonathan Schell, the noted American who wrote the highly respected book, The Fate of the Earth, last year, have researched this matter and have set the consequences for a city. If a nuclear bomb or a nuclear reactor is exploded by a bomb, there would be approximately eight times the extent of damage as if the city were hit by a nuclear weapon without those things being in place. I recommend that honourable senators read that book and check on the research, as I have, because it is impeccable.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer is not, of course, to deny our ANZUS allies facilities, nor is it to say that the people of Sydney should be put at risk. That is woolly thinking; it does not grasp the necessary nettle; it is irresponsible. We must look very carefully again at the means which we are to use to help our allies. As I have said in this place before, it is ridiculous that we should locate B52 bombers in a population centre, in Darwin. We have a large new airfield at Learmonth right on the Indian Ocean to which we have allocated a great deal of money. Why can that airport not be upgraded? Is it that rest and recreation are more important than the lives of our citizens? I have yet to hear any other reason for the absolute insistence that these dangerous weapons should be placed in our centres of population at the risk of our own people.

Garden Island is an extremely large section of central Sydney in an area of very high property values. I put this point at Question Time to the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans), who comes from Melbourne and not Sydney so I will forgive him. He does not appreciate the enormous value of the real estate on Garden Island which, after all, would be the equivalent, if it were half park and half high rise development, to that of Elizabeth Bay and areas of that kind. The opportunity exists for us to move Garden Island out of Sydney. It is a nettle we should grasp, and the sooner the better. Not to do so is simple, lazy irresponsibility bordering on the criminal.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I am very interested to take note of the report of the 1983 session of the Committee on Disarmament in Geneva. In particular I find it of some real use to follow the agenda and the deliberations of such a committee. Those of us who have any concern at all about matters of disarmament know the continuing frustration of seeming to talk to an empty space, where neither the military- industrial complex nor the governments of the countries involved in the production and maintenance of nuclear weapons seem to heed or hear what people around the world say. So I find it quite interesting to read this report on the deliberations of the Committee. The Committee has not been established for any great length of time but it does seem in the short period since 1978 to have spent a lot of time discussing its agenda and what should be on it, rather than dealing with the agenda items themselves. The problem of what gets on to the agenda seems to have been the substance of much of the original meetings this year. I was interested to read too that the delegations that attended the conference operate informally in three political groups-a group of 21 non- aligned and neutral countries, a western group which includes Australia, and a socialist group, comprising the Soviet Union and its allies. I was also interested to note that China continued to stand aside, not joining any group, and that Romania consulted either the socialist group or the group of 21, according to the issues involved.

The report notes that during the course of the deliberations the United States continued its broadly cautious approach to the nuclear test ban, prevention of nuclear war, outer space and protection of nuclear facilities issues. I am interested in the caution of the United States in discussions because I think that stands in contrast to its practice in the matter of production of nuclear arms. The Western states in general accorded a political emphasis to much of the discussion in 1983 and it is reported that this of course had to do with the increased tension between East and West and a sharpening up of the debates over the period when there was an increased distancing, I suppose one would say, of the relationships between the East and West sectors. But the group of 21 countries, it is reported, expressed new levels of impatience with both the procedural and substantive aspects of the Committee's work and 'pressed spiritedly for negotiations on all items on the agenda'. That line in particular strikes me as something about which we can be a little heartened. Certainly, there is no report that anything too dramatic has changed but some countries are beginning to argue rigorously for more to happen than merely further discussions on agenda items.

The report also indicates that the Australian delegation devoted special attention to two items that Australia regards as having priority and on which we have the capability to make constructive contributions, in particular the nuclear test ban discussions and the chemical weapons convention. In both areas delegates from Australia were assisted by experts from the relevant departments. Throughout the work of the Committee the delegation took opportunities to put Australia's view on the broader issues of international security, prevention of nuclear war and non-proliferation. It would seem that Australia's view on these matters is well understood and well stated on our behalf. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1982-83

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The 1982-83 annual report of the Department of Trade indicates that in that financial year, following two disappointing years, Australia's exports grew by 13 per cent. The report confirms that in that year we had a positive balance of trade, after a deficit in the previous year. That is a very welcome development. It also indicates that the higher export values in the last financial year were due to higher contract prices for minerals and, very encouragingly, stronger growth in manufactured exports, something which is long overdue.

It is very striking that in 1982-83 the share of rural products in Australia's exports fell to 36 per cent compared with a figure of in excess of 40 per cent in the previous year. That 36 per cent share of exports possibly is the lowest in Australia's history. Of course, in that financial year the figures reflected the drought which affected most States of Australia. Most of the farming community was affected. It also reflected the poor world prices for various Australian export commodities. It was said once that Australia rides on the sheep's back but I think the figures for 1982-83 give some suggestion that certainly in that year that was not the case.

For example, last financial year 45 per cent of all Australia's exports came from minerals, fuels-for example, coal-and metal products, a figure now well in excess of the share of exports contributed by the rural sector. It is very striking that last financial year the exports in the minerals group grew by some 28 per cent, a very rapid growth indeed. In fact, in recent years the minerals group has been contributing most of Australia's export growth. It is very encouraging that in the last financial year exports to member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations grew very rapidly and there was good growth in our exports to the People's Republic of China. The Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade is looking at that subject at the moment to try to encourage further growth in trade with China.

One matter which concerns me greatly in relation to our balance of payments is the growing share of invisible items incurred by Australia. For example, in 1979 -80-three financial years ago-intangible items in the balance of payments cost Australia $4.7 billion. But in 1982-83 the intangible items-that is, royalties, copyright, property income and so forth-exceeded $6 billion for the first time, a very rapid growth in the intangible element of Australia's balance of payments . Those intangibles or invisibles now actually cost us in the order of 30 per cent of the total value of our exports. I think that matter really needs to be looked at.

It is very striking that of that component of intangible items the one known as other property income-that does not include all property income-grew by 80 per cent in three financial years to a massive $3,400m. Over $3,000m each year is now being taken from Australia in the form of property income. Over that same period of three financial years the cost to Australia in respect of royalties and copyrights grew by over 50 per cent. I think it is time that those intangible items in our balance of payments were the subject of a comprehensive study to identify the trends at work, to try to establish what causes are at work and perhaps to identify areas where Australia and Australian firms could contribute more.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF IMMIGRATION AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1982-83

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report includes a report on the operations of the adult migration education program as required under the Immigration (Education) Act 1971. I want to use the few moments available to me to set down a gross dereliction of an election promise by the Australian Labor Party Government in that it has failed to implement a specific promise to a group of teachers who operate within the adult migration education service. I received a copy of a letter dated 1 December from Carole Elvin of Newtown, Sydney, written to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in which she states:
Dear Mr Hawke,

Early this year you stated 'Labor will create a permanent Adult Migrant Education Service to provide English instruction for all new arrivals who require it and to overcome the enormous backlog of need. All full-time casual teachers will be transfered to permanent service. We will provide $3.68 million during the first year of government to facilitate this transfer'.

There cannot be a more specific promise than that-a promise that in Labor's first year of office $3.68m would be provided to establish a permanent adult migrant education service and that all full time permanent teachers would be transferred to that service. The letter from Ms Elvin goes on to make it clear that that promise has not been kept and that teachers in the adult migrant education service have not had extended to them the facility of full time employment that the Labor Government promised. If one looks at other reports from within the education community one finds that the same promise-publicly made and widely known-is being quoted and the Government is being called on to honour what it promised and what it has failed to provide.

It promised an amount of money-$3.68m. It has not delivered that amount of money. In the Budget it provided merely $800,000, which is less than a quarter of the amount of money promised. The Government has not given to the teachers who operate in adult migrant education the certainty or the assurance which they want and require. Before the election Labor Party spokesmen went to the migrant education teachers and promised they would do better then the Government they sought to replace. They replaced that Government. Labor is now in government. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) should have redeemed that promise. It was a specific promise to people who simply want to be able to have permanent employment in providing to migrants the kind of language teaching they require and deserve. They were entitled to believe that a promise for a certain amount of money in the first year was a promise Labor would redeem. But, along with so many other promises made as election bait before the people went to the polls, the promise has been set aside and has not been honoured.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you seen today's Bulletin?

—Senator Tate, who interjects, was a member of the Party that made that promise. Senator Tate was party to that promise. Senator Tate is one person who has to explain why he and his colleagues made the promise when it suited them in going to an election and why they now have broken that promise. The honourable senator can sit there grinning from ear to ear because he got the votes of these people. He got the votes when the promise was made and he has failed to redeem the promise. We know that in the whole education area, not only adult migrant education, Labor's record so far has been characterised by the breaking of many promises. Those promises referred to what would be done in its first year. This is merely one more of them. When people write to the Prime Minister and beg him to redeem promises he made because they affect them, it is our duty to draw to the attention of the Parliament the deception which has been practised upon adult migrant education teachers in this country. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
