SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 220th report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have a short statement on the report incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Report 220 of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts contains the Department of Finance Minute on the Committee's Report 193-Reports of the Auditor-General 1979-80 and March 1981. Report 193 was tabled in Parliament on 20 April 1982. The Finance Minute was forwarded to the Chairman of the Committee on 4 November 1983.
The Department of Finance Minute is the formal mechanism used for responding to the Committee's recommendations.

Examination of Reports of the Auditor-General is part of the Committee's prescribed activities. Report 193 presented the Committee's findings from several public hearings into matters raised by the Auditor-General's Reports for 1979-80 and March 1981. The matters included in Report 193 were:
Department of Defence-HMAS Stirling
Department of Transport-Payment of monies for the Second Hobart Bridge in advance of demonstrated need
A.C.T. Schools Authority-Delays in the presentation of financial statements
Department of Foreign Affairs-Accounting at overseas posts
Department of Defence
The Auditor-General raised a number of matters with the Department of Defence concerning the administration of the naval base HMAS Stirling in Western Australia.
The Committee was pleased to note at the time of its Inquiry that the Department was in the process of rectifying the matters raised by the Auditor- General.
The Committee is also pleased that the Department has adopted its recommendations to proceed with the purchase of two tug boats and to expand the range of stores held at HMAS Stirling.
Department of Transport

The Committee's inquiry into the Department of Transport arose from comments by the Auditor-General that a payment for the Second Hobart Bridge of $450 000 from the Department of Transport to the Tasmanian Department of Main Roads was made in advance of a demonstrated need for funds.
The Committee concluded that the payment was made in good faith but that sufficient care was not taken to ensure that the necessary conditions for the payment of the grant were met.
The Committee is pleased that the Department of Transport has instituted new arrangements which will prevent a recurrence of this problem.
A.C.T. Schools Authority

The Committee's Inquiry into the A.C.T. Schools Authority arose from comments by the Auditor-General concerning the delay in the submission for audit of the Authority's financial statements for 1976-77, 1977-78, 1978-79 and 1979-80.

The delay was caused by a dispute between the Authority and the Department of Finance over the form of accounts and uncertainty as to how to account for non- government monies collected locally by schools.
The Committee's major recommendations were that the Authority adopt accrual accounting and that its legislation be amended to allow greater accountability of non-Government monies.

The Committee is pleased that the Authority has taken these actions. The Authority's financial statements for 1981-82 have been prepared on an accrual basis and the A.C.T. House of Assembly has agreed to amendments to the A.C.T. Schools Authority Ordinance 1976 to make monies raised locally monies of the Authority for auditing and financial reporting.
However, the Committee is concerned at the length of time taken by the Authority to achieve a satisfactory response.
Department of Foreign Affairs

The Committee's inquiry into the Department of Foreign Affairs arose from comments by the Auditor-General regarding deficiencies in accounting and financial administration at overseas posts operated by the Department.

The Department informed the Committee that it was aware of the problems and that a Joint Management Review was in progress. The Committee also suggested that the Department review the Finance (Overseas) Regulations and where necessary seek permission for special procedures.
The Committee is pleased that the recommendations of the Joint Management Review and its other recommendations have been largely implemented.
In conclusion, the Committee is generally pleased with the responses contained in the Finance Minute. However, it wishes to stress again the need for timely responses to its recommendations.
I recommend this report to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 221st report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have a short statement on the report incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The 221st Report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts contains the Department of Finance Minute on the Committee's earlier report No. 196. The Committee's 196th Report which examined the curatorial and conservation functions of the Australian War Memorial and other aspects of the National Collection was tabled in Parliament on 27 April 1982.
The Department of Finance Minute is the formal mechanism used by the Government for responding to the Committee's recommendations.
The Auditor-General had reported in March 1981 on a number of weaknesses and inadequacies disclosed during a comprehensive audit of the Australian War Memorial.
Broadly, the Auditor-General found:
lack of formal written objectives in regard to curatorship, loans and conservation;
inadequate control, security, stocktaking and assessment of the collection;
gaps in catalogues and registers and no maintenance or restoration programs;
inadequacies in the loans policies.

In general the criticisms of the Auditor-General were conceded and the thrust of the Memorial's response was to blame lack of staff. In the area of conservation alone there was an estimated backlog of 450 manyears.

Whilst focusing on the state of the War Memorial's Collection, the Committee examined other aspects of the national collection held by the National Library, National Gallery and Australian Archives and warned of the consequences of their neglect. The Committee described the National Collection as being at a 'crisis stage' as a result of years of neglect and a lack of recognition of its worth and value.

Given the importance and value of the National Collection of which the War Memorial's Collection forms a significant proportion, the Committee saw a need for a review from the national viewpoint as to how much the National Collection is valued and what price the nation is prepared to pay to retain it. The Committee identified the need for a more equitable and coordinated allocation, improved management and expansion of resources for the care and conservation of the National Collection.
The Committee is pleased to note that the main thrust of its recommendations have been accepted and implemented.
In response to the Committee's inquiry the Public Service Board announced in 1982 the following changes at the Australian War Memorial:
expansion of full-time staff ceiling by 10 to 124;
approval for the position of Registrar of Collections;
creation of permanent positions of Curator;
approval for a senior officer responsible for writing the official history of the Vietnam War and the Malayan Emergency;
secondment of an experienced officer to assist in the preparation of an ADP strategic plan for the War Memorial.

The Committee's recommendations were addressed by an Interdepartmental Committee established on 23 July 1982. As a general response, the IDC considered that overall benefits could be gained if there were a formal co-ordinating body from which the Minister could receive advice, particularly on issues affecting more than one institution.

The Advisory Committee on National Collections (ACNC) was established to provide an effective means of co-ordinating advice to the Government on all issues affecting the National Collections and of facilitating the sharing of resources and co-operation between the institutions concerned. ACNC is chaired by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment and includes the executive heads of the Australian Archives, the Australian National Gallery, the Australian War Memorial, the Museum of Australia and the National Library of Australia with representatives from the Public Service Board and the departments of Finance and the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

The ACNC has been asked to produce major reports on resource sharing and funding; arrangements for improving the conservation and preservation of the National Collection; and cataloguing items both in the National Collection and held by Commonwealth departments and authorities.

The 1982-83 budget for the National Library was increased by $12.6m for extensions which included a new and modern conservation facility. Also announced was an $11m modernisation and renovation building program for the Australian War Memorial to be completed in time for the 1988 Bicentenary.

The Committee is pleased to note the interest generated by this Report and the recent media coverage concerning the preservation of historic and archival material vital to Australia's National Collection.
I commend the report to honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCHOOLS COMMISSIONCOMMONWEALTH TERTIARY EDUCATION COMMISSION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) I seek leave to have the text of a statement regarding the report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission on participation and equity in Australian schools and the report on the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission recommendations for 1984, supplementary report on participation and equity programs-I understand Opposition honourable senators were given a copy of it some time ago- incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I wish to draw the attention of honourable senators to two significant reports concerned with the development of the Participation and Equity Program. These are the Commonwealth Schools Commission's Report ''Participation and Equity in Australian Schools'' and the Report of TAFE Council of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission ''Recommendations for 1984-Supplementary Report on Participation and Equity Program''.

Preparation of these papers was required in the funding guidelines to the Commonwealth Education Commissions which I issued on 28 July 1983. I indicated then the Government's wish to receive papers from the Commissions outlining proposed general principles and directions of development for the Program in 1984.

For 1984 the Government has allocated $74 million ($71.6 million in estimated December 1982 prices) for the Participation and Equity Program (PEP). The new program subsumes the School to Work Transition Program under which $49.4 million was allocated in 1983 ($48.6 million in estimated December 1982 prices).

The Government sees the PEP as the centre piece of the overall framework of youth policies which it is developing. The Schools Commission and the TAFE Council will administer the program with the Department of Education and Youth Affairs exercising a strong co-ordinating role to ensure that education, training, income support and employment policies are harmonised to the maximum possible extent. The approach has been endorsed by the Australian Education Council and by the historic first Youth Ministers Meeting held in November this year.

The program will work towards the important national goal of all young Australians completing a full secondary education or other appropriate education or training. Participation of our young people in education and training lags significantly behind a number of comparable countires. It is the general standard of education of Australians which will sustain national progress. Policies which resulted in only about 30 per cent of our youth completing secondary education, compared with 90 per cent in many other OECD countries, must be changed. In addition the Government is concerned about the unacceptably high level of youth unemployment-currently 22 per cent for 15-19 year olds.

The Participation and Equity Program places strong emphasis on equity. It will seek to develop education systems under which the less advantaged groups in the community can receive a fair share of the range of benefits education brings. The position of women and girls and other under-represented groups such as Aboriginals and some ethnic groups will be given particular attention under PEP.

The Government hopes that PEP will provide a focus for involving people in creating a constructive consensus about education. Employers and unions, parents and the community generally have an important part to play in developing and supporting constructive policies for education and training provision in our schools and TAFE colleges.

The Government expects that non-institutional initiatives will be taken under the program, particularly for the benefit of young people who would otherwise be unlikely to participate in education or training.

PEP represents an important stage in the developing co-operation between the States and the Commonwealth in respect of schooling and TAFE. Ten years ago, in more abundant times, the Labor Government began its program of substantial support for education from which all schools and TAFE institutions benefited and in which the real needs of schools serving disadvantaged communities were first addressed. Now we must resume that important work.

The success of PEP will depend, to a very large extent on the work of the large State education systems which, historically, developed because of a concern for equity-the need to deliver services to children in vastly differing geographical and social circumstances. The conditions of the 1980s present new challenges to these systems and also to the non-government school systems. The Commonwealth is confident that the partnership between the States and the Commonwealth will enable productive efforts to meet these challenges.

The Commonwealth Government has had to exercise restraint in many important areas of public spending because of the difficult economic circumstances which it inherited. The increase in funds which it has committed over the next three years to PEP and in other areas of education training and support for young people shows our commitment to young people and a recognition of their significance in national recovery and reconstruction.

The reports now presented by the two Commissions are important in the sequence of development of PEP. Since the Commonwealth's intentions were announced in general terms in July, the Commissions have consulted with State and non- government authorities about the program's development. Arrangements to ensure the orderly continuation of Transition Program activities consistent with the new program have been put into place. State and non-government authorities are currently developing their 1984 programs and some of these have been submitted to the Commonwealth.

The Commissions' reports will be of particular significance for allocation of the additional funds to be made available in 1984. During that year significant progress will be made towards changes in schools enabling them to give all students and especially those from a disadvantaged background a rewarding and useful education. In TAFE new courses and activities will expand the possibilities for youth, particularly those currently unemployed.
The Government expects that the needs of the severely disadvantaged will be given increased prominence in the provision of services.
COMMONWEALTH SCHOOLS COMMISSION REPORT

The Commonwealth Schools Commission's Report makes recommendations on the program covering its developmental nature during 1984, the targetting of effort appropriately amongst schools, and the allocation of funds between school-level and system level activities. I now outline the Government's response to these recommendations.

The Commission recommends that 1984 should be a developmental year for schools during which the foundations are laid for the long term effort required for the achievement of the Program's goals. While it is essential for the Program to be phased in this way, I am concerned that positive and concrete steps are taken in 1984 to address the many issues confronting secondary education which the Schools Commission has outlined in its agenda for action. This agenda focusses on the following areas of major importance:
curriculum
assessment, accreditation and credentialling
teacher/student/parent interaction
teacher renewal and support
school structure and organisation
post-school links (especially with TAFE)
groups with special needs
public support for education

Underpinning the Commission's recomendations is the principle of co-operation at all levels-among students, parents and teachers within the school, between school and community, among schools within a locality or region, between State and Commonwealth. The Program will build upon existing Commonwealth and State programs and activities in secondary education. The extra resources being made available for the Participation and Equity Program will provide the means of giving these initiatives and the co-operative principles I have referred to a significant impetus.

I welcome the detailed examination and investigation of the educational implications of the two elements of the new Program, participation and equity, undertaken in the Schools Commission's paper. Its discussion of questions associated with the inequitable educational provisions for a number of important groups of young people in our society-Aborigines, those from working class backgrounds, migrants, girls-provides an important basis for specific recommendations on program administration.

As a result of its analysis of the Program's two key concepts and to ensure that the funding provided will have the maximum possible impact, the Commission has recommended that a limited group of secondary schools be given priority for funding in 1984. The target group should total about 40 per cent of government and non-government schools in each State or system. Inclusion is to be determined on the basis of socio-economic, retention and participation data. I endorse the Commission's approach on this, but have also asked it to develop ways for all secondary schools progressively to become involved in and to benefit from the Program.

The Commission has stressed the importance of change and development taking place in individual schools or groups of co-operating schools, and has recommended that the majority of funds for 1984 be devoted to school based projects and activities. The balance of funds will be available for systems to develop support services, to disseminate information and foster understanding, and to promote research and development activities.

I believe this emphasis on individual schools is most important if effective reform is to occur, and I have therefore accepted the Commission's proposals. It will be most important that this approach is administered flexibly and that the Schools Commission provides opportunities for consultation with State and non- government authorities about its application in their individual circumstances. The Commission's Program Guidelines to be issued in January 1984 will set out ways in which these arrangements can be introduced.

The Government regards this as a most important Commonwealth initiative, and the Commonwealth will be closely involved, not only through its membership of State Committees, but also in the development of national perspectives for the schools program. The Commonwealth Schools Commission will establish a committee to advise it on aspects of the implementation and development of the program, to assist with consultations, and advise on Projects of National Significance.
TAFE COUNCIL REPORT

The paper from the Technical and Further Education Council indicates the broad lines of activity under the Participation and Equity Program in TAFE in 1984. While the program is particularly concerned with 15-19 year olds, courses will be available to young adults up to the age of 24, many of whom now have limited access to appropriate education programs. The emphasis will be on the provision of places for the most disadvantaged groups.

The Government acknowledges the important role being played by TAFE in improving the employment prospects of young people. TAFE authorities are proposing to structure PEP courses so that students can more readily enter the wide range of vocational programs in TAFE which many of them are well able to complete with success. We fully support this approach: PEP courses will help to provide them with the confidence, the vocational awareness and the motivation they need.

Our high youth unemployment rate causes this Government the greatest concern. PEP will not itself create jobs: other measures of this Government directed towards economic recovery are helping in this task. But I commend the TAFE Council's views that the benefits of PEP should be measured in much broader terms. For those young people whose employment opportunities are limited, these courses can help to replace frustration and disappointment with useful skills and greater self-esteem.

In 1984, our expectation is that nearly 17,000 young people will undertake PEP courses and an even larger number of school students will be involved in link programs between schools and TAFE colleges. The Government is anxious to encourage closer co-operation between the sectors, leading to much more extensive arrangements for cross-crediting.

The Government does not support the user pays approach to the funding of Link Courses provided by TAFE for secondary school students as put forward in the TAFE Council's report. I am discussing this matter with State Education Ministers with a view to there being interim Link Course funding arrangements in 1984 pending their thorough review during the year.

Since the TAFE Council completed its paper, detailed submissions for PEP in 1984 have been received from a number of States. These indicate a very positive reaction to the Government's Guidelines. I refer to some of the major initiatives.

In accordance with Government emphasis on youth who are particularly disadvantaged, New South Wales is proposing to provide special courses for Aboriginals, students from various ethnic backgrounds and isolated students.

The needs of women and girls are receiving special consideration in terms of courses which widen their suitability for, and awareness of, possible employment options. In South Australia, for example, course to introduce trades to young women and courses to enhance career awareness amongst rural young women will be introduced.

Courses of a general rather than specific vocational kind have been available in TAFE in recent years and will be further developed. In Queensland, for example, such courses will embrace basic vocational skills, employment awareness and personal development. They will also provide ''survival skills'' to help young people to cope with difficult circumstances.
Victoria has placed particular emphasis on complementary arrangements between the Schools and TAFE Sectors and with local and community projects.

In South Australia, courses to integrate disabled young adults into mainstream vocational courses, a Foundation Program for the intellectually handicapped and courses for people in remote areas will be introduced.

PEP courses will be tailored to meet local circumstances. TAFE Colleges will work closely with officers of the Commonwealth Employment Service in the selection of students and the development of courses.

Proposals will be approved by the TAFE Council as they are received on a State by State basis. I will make announcements as they are approved, and States will be able to proceed with the new Program from the beginning of 1984.

The Participation and Equity Program will help the TAFE Sector to contribute to the Government's objective of providing a comprehensive range of educational provisions for young people within the framework of an overall policy for youth. In particular, PEP will give an impetus to structural change within the TAFE sector and will assist States in targeting resources more efficiently to groups who, for various social and financial reasons, are under-represented both in education and employment.
STATE COMMITTEES

In the July 1983 funding guidelines to the Education Commissions I referred to the Government's intention that joint Commonwealth-State Committees should operate in each State to plan the implementation of the Program.

After consideration of the Schools Commission's proposal on the structure of these Committees, the Government has concluded that State Committees should be established with the following membership, to plan the implementation of the government schools and TAFE programs:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

The Opposition welcomes the report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission on Participation and Equity in Australian Schools and the report of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, and the statement by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) in relation to the reports. As was made clear in the debate last week on the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Bill to establish the participation and equity program, the program has objectives which are shared by the Opposition. If the Government is able to build upon what was started in the school to work transition program and if the Government is able to achieve greater participation in more relevant courses it will enjoy the enthusiastic support of the Opposition in what it is seeking to do.

In looking at the statement and then at the reports one is struck by the statements made in relation to tertiary education, by the compliments that are paid to the school to work transition program on which, of course, the participation and equity program is based. It is made clear in the report from the Tertiary Education Commission that the school to work transition program was achieving many of the objectives which are set down for this new program. In particular it was identifying certain groups which are disadvantaged, and the details of that are set out in the report. However, what pleases the Opposition is that from the school to work transition program we have a solid base on which this Government and this community can build in trying to increase participation and equity.

I will speak for only a couple of moments and will concentrate on only one aspect in one of the reports which was drawn to my attention by the Minister's statement, and that is the section which deals with the subject of assessment, accreditation and credentialling. One of the real problems in Australian education has been that children can go through our education systems, State education systems generally, and can come out at the end of 10 years, 11 years or 12 years with not a single credential or a single qualification which they can take to an employer or which they can look at themselves to get some sense of achievement out of their educational experience. We have a system in which there tends to be one major hurdle for accreditation at the end of people's school training. It has seemed to me for a long time that the credentialling approach in Australia leaves a lot to be desired. I am attracted by moves which have been made recently in New South Wales to provide a more comprehensive means of credentialling.

When I was in England earlier this year I had the opportunity to discuss credentialling with English education authorities. I learned, for example, that the Inner London Education Authority, which operates a system bigger than any we have in Australia, is examining credentialling in a very particular and positive way. It was put to me then by Mr Stubbs, the Chief Education Officer, that there is no reason why we cannot develop a portfolio approach to credentialling whereby pupils leaving an education system could carry with them a formal record of their achievements, whether or not they are able to pass the formal examination for university entrance. The difficulty we have had in this country is that the final qualification which provides generally the only useful credential for schooling is one which has been determined by tertiary institutions for their legitimate purposes and which leaves without a single qualification many students who cannot satisfy that credential. Mr Stubbs put to me earlier this year that an approach which might allow each student to develop a portfolio of achievement is one that might be looked at. I would commend that. If that is what the report is talking about, it is something which the Opposition would support.

I endorse the other approach to achievement and credentialling which has been put to me. That approach recognises that pupils might move at different speeds according to their academic ability and prowess and that they might meet standards at their own speeds, rather than being required to satisfy the normative standards for their age or peer groups each year. It has been put to me that students studying for music examinations in Australia simply take each level when they are ready. They take each level as they are prepared for it. Having passed it, whenever they pass it, they go on to the next level. There seems to be considerable merit in looking at our schooling system and at the credentialling and accreditation systems within the schooling system from the same point of view. Why should it not be possible for a student at one time to be studying mathematics at year 11 level, English at year 9 level and history at year 8 level? There should be no reason whatsoever why that should not be possible. It would give to the student extra flexibility and a chance to succeed at a speed he or she could accept as being appropriate for himself or herself.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that specific area.

—I accept Senator Jack Evans's interjection. At the moment we have a system of credentialling and of accreditation which is placing barriers in the way of students and contributing to the unsatisfactory experiences which many of our students have.

SPEECH.PARA: I said that that was the only point I wished to talk about in detail. I wish to commend the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for the way in which they are responding to the Government' s call in this program. I indicate to the Government that we will continue as an Opposition to look at the programs to see whether they are achieving their objectives. We wish those programs well. We wish them well on behalf of students throughout the Australian education system. We hope that the Government is able to achieve its aims of greater participation and greater flexibility. As I said at the outset, the Opposition will do all it can to help promote positive outcomes in education.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983 (No. 4)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch I referred to the dilemma which this Government faces, a dilemma which the previous Government faced, which was the making of Australian governments and which came about as the result of the gross negligence of a series of governments in this country. That negligence was compounded by inaction in certain departments and was made far worse because of a ruling by Justice Barwick which let a great number of tax avoidance and evasion schemes through the net because there was no section 260 to pick up those tax avoiders and evaders and make them pay their just dues to this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 (No. 4), more commonly known as bottom of the harbour legislation, has arrived as the third instalment of this Government's endeavours to tidy up the 1982 legislation passed by the Fraser Government and to expand that legislation to embrace more tax avoiders and evaders. It is late. It is very late as a remedy for the problems that have been created and have built up over that 10-year period. I will not deal any more with the problems that this Government, the previous Government and their predecessors met in bringing down this legislation. The problems are not just those of the Government. They are problems that concern the Australian Democrats. This Bill, like its predecessors, contains the retrospective element. I know that I speak on behalf of all the Australian Democrats when I say that nobody denies the need to clean up tax evasion in this country. The Australian Democrats are united in their efforts and in their support for any government which moves to clean up tax evasion in this country. The question is how can it be done and, more importantly, how can it be done with justice, with fairness and with equity.

This legislation contains the retrospective element. Its purpose is only to clear up loophole provisions which were contained in the 1982 legislation. Therefore, one could probably argue that it is not retrospective in terms of its ingredients in taxation assessments and that all it will do will ensure that everybody who should have been picked up in the 1982 legislation is picked up. Despite that, I appreciate and sympathise with those Australian Democrats who have been absolutely consistent in opposing any retrospective legislation, legislation which says: 'The things that a person did legally last year or five or ten years ago will now be deemed to be illegal'. I can understand that point of view.

I repeat that the three Australian Democrats who in 1982 announced their opposition to retrospective legislation and who stood rigidly by that position should be respected and, I believe, are respected by most members of this Parliament. Colin Mason has consistently adopted a very principled stance that if a person robbed the taxpayers of Australia in 1975, 1977 or 1980 and the Commissioner of Taxation caught up with him in 1983, the Taxation Commissioner should hit him with a tax assessment. The fact is that that form of robbery was conducted by many people under the guise of phony tax avoidance schemes as distinct from blatant tax evasion schemes. Therefore, those people thought that they were going to get away with it forever. This creates a problem. The problem is one of principle because it means that to catch up with these people one must apply legislation retrospectively.

Senator Mason and I have been consistent in our points of view. We believe the sins and the actions of those people were deliberately aimed at robbing the people of Australia, at avoiding and evading obligations, by allowing their companies to be committed to the bottom of the harbour so that the Taxation Commissioner could never catch up with their misdeeds and therefore discover whether they were legal or illegal. Senator Mason and I maintain that in those circumstances there should be an overriding principle of ensuring that justice is done to the whole of the people of Australia.

One of the problems that the Democrats are experiencing difficulty with is that the system as it was in 1982 and as it will be under this legislation did not and will not allow for any appeal from shareholders who feel that they are being unjustly dealt with. As I indicated earlier, a Democrats' private member's Bill is currently before the Senate. It aims at giving the right of appeal to people who have not benefited from and who were unaware of the moves that were being taken by the directors of their companies to send their companies to the bottom of the harbour. It is my understanding that the Government agreed to that proposal each time we put it to the Government. I am delighted to see that that proposal is part of this new legislation. The repeal of section 3 (12), the original loopholes clause which was inserted in the 1982 legislation, is something for which this Government believes it has a mandate. As its objective is consistent and has been consistent right the way through, to ensure that everyone who sent a company to the bottom of the harbour and benefited from that should pay the tax, the repeal of section 3 (12) is an appropriate move.

I should like to refer to a couple of minor anomalies. I hope to get the Government's response. One is that this new Bill gives the Commissioner of Taxation the right to refuse to disclose to shareholders who are to be assessed under this legislation information about the company's actions which were the cause of the assessment arriving. That is a harsh move to be taking in this legislation. Therefore, I appeal to the Government to withdraw clause 4 (c). I also suggest that it is harsh, and it is not normal practice, for late payers to be named by the Commissioner of Taxation. All sorts of people are named by the Commissioner, but under this legislation late payers will be named. That sets them apart from others. It is not a fair approach to tax legislation. Again, I ask the Minister to consider withdrawing clause 4 (a).

My final appeal to the Government is to support the amendment which I shall be moving in Committee, which will become clause 13, which would give those shareholders caught up in this legislation the same right to 60 days in which to appeal as was given to those who were originally caught up in the 1982 legislation. It is only fair that these people, who were under the impression from the outset of the 1982 legislation that they were not caught in this net and therefore took no steps to make their appeal within the requisite 60 days, should be given that same right of appeal. My amendment would give them that right. I ask the Government to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of the contributions to the debate have been quite general in reference to tax avoidance and tax evasion. However, I should like to comment on a couple of matters. Senator Macklin, if I heard him correctly, claimed that he had a case which would be affected by section 3 (12) of the principal Act, backed up by documents. I found it a little hard to follow him here, but essentially he said that there had been no fraudulence, no deliberate tax evasion or no participation in an arrangement which was clearly designed to evade tax at some stage, and that the vendor-shareholders of a particular company had not been participants in that arrangement. If Senator Macklin has such documents, I should like him to tell us, at some time, whether he supplied those documents to the Australian Taxation Office. As far as I know, they have not been supplied to the Taxation Office or to the Government. While it would be improper for the Commissioner of Taxation to supply documents about a particular firm to the Government, it would certainly not be improper for Senator Macklin to do so, since presumably the alleged firm in question gave him the documents for that purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the Committee stage of this Bill that really matters. Senator Jack Evans raised a matter in support of the amendment proposed by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, to extend what has been known as the anomalies provision to private companies as well as to shareholders in public companies or shareholders in private companies in which public companies were stripped, which in turn had shareholdings in public companies which were stripped. Senator Jack Evans said, as an example in justifying that proposed extension, that he knew of individual shareholders in private companies who had no connection with the directors, the people who set up the tax evasion schemes, and received no financial benefit from the schemes. In those circumstances, the existing Act imposes no liability. If a vendor shareholder in a private company has derived no financial benefit in the form of an excessive price for the shares, a price which reflected a consideration for the tax which it was planned would be evaded, that shareholder does not receive an assessment under the existing Act. So, if that is his only reason for suggesting that that so-called anomalies provision be extended to private company shareholders where there was no evasion of tax by a public company, I suggest that he reconsider his attitude to that and, therefore, reconsider whether he will proceed in supporting the amendment proposed by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle.

Finally, I note that the Opposition has given notice that with the exception of clause 10, which it intends to seek to amend, and the first two clauses, which concern just the short title and the date of commencement and are purely formal clauses, it intends to oppose all the other clauses. I do not know what will be the attitude of the other six senators who are not members of the official Opposition or of the Government to the Opposition's stated intention of voting against clauses 3 to 9 and clauses 11 and 12. I just serve notice that, if those proposals to oppose all of those clauses receive sufficient support from other senators to produce a negative vote on the clauses, the Government will certainly not accept an emasculated Bill. In those circumstances, all that would be left in the Bill-assuming that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's amendment to clause 10 were carried-is a provision to extend the anomalies provision to shareholders in private companies which had no involvement with public companies . The effect of that would be to delay considerably the collection of a substantial amount of tax which ultimately would be payable. I note that the Opposition, at this stage anyway, has given no substantive reason for intending to pursue that course.

As to the other amendment circulated by Senator Jack Evans, an amendment to allow a period of 60 days in which to appeal to certain classes of taxpayers who may already have made decisions related to section 3 (12) of the Act, the Government is advised that the Taxation Office is not aware of any case in which this would actually have practical relevance. Therefore, the effects on revenue would be either zero or negligible. Although we do not believe that the amendment is necessary and although it would write some additional complexity into the law-something which should be avoided as much as possible, particularly in taxation law-the Government is willing to accept it. We would prefer it, however, if Senator Evans did not proceed with it, because it just unnecessarily complicates the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 and 2-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 3 (Interpretation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes clause 3. Clause 3 omits section 3 (12) of the principal Act. That section excludes a company from the scope of the legislation if its inability to pay tax is the result of an unsuccessful post-sales scheme to avoid tax. The Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans), in his second reading speech, said that section 3 (12) defies logic and was inserted by the previous Government for reasons which are best known to it. The fact is that that section ensures that bottom of the harbour legislation does not apply to companies that have not been sent to the bottom of the harbour. It really does defy logic from our point of view for the Government to seek to apply the bottom of the harbour legislation to companies that are still alive. For this reason we oppose this clause. In any event, it is generally considered within the accounting profession that there are very few companies to which this so-called innocence provision could apply. The removal of the provision would have little or no impact upon revenue raising. As I said in my speech during the second reading debate, the Opposition will be opposing all clauses from clause 3 to clause 9.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has evaded paragraph (c) of clause 3 of the Bill . That paragraph refers to section 3 (12) of the original Act. She has failed to give any rational reason for doing so. I think the precise effects of section 3 (12) ought to be put on the record. It should also be put on the record that that section in the existing Act was not in the first Bill which was introduced by the previous Government last year. The later inclusion of section 3 (12) in the principal Act by the previous Government exempts from liability vendor shareholders in companies on which tax was evaded but which had been put into unsuccessful tax avoidance schemes after the sale by the original vendor- shareholders.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators should bear in mind that the legislation passed by the previous Government made the vendor-shareholders-we are talking only about private companies here-responsible for their proportion of the tax evaded, providing they had gained a price when selling their shares which reflected the tax which it was planned from the beginning was to be evaded. After the last Government inserted section 3 (12) the situation was that those vendor- shareholders who disposed of a company to a promoter-the promoter then sent it to the bottom of the harbour, to use the colloquial expression-would be responsible for the tax. Section 3 (12) provides that those vendor-shareholders who sold companies under exactly the same conditions to promoters and who post- sale put the companies into unsuccessful tax avoidance schemes will be exempt from their liability to pay their share of the tax evaded. In other words, the liability to pay or not to pay is to be determined, if the Opposition's view on this is accepted, by the actions of people over which the vendor-shareholders had no control and of which necessarily, if the rationale for the original Act is to be accepted-I will return to that in a minute-they had no knowledge. That is plainly absurd. That view was stated here last year. It has been stated on a number of occasions since and I state it again today. I invite the Opposition to come to grips with that fact and I defy the Opposition to provide a plausible rationale for it.

The rationale for the existing Act-that is, the Bill introduced by the previous Government-depended very heavily, if not primarily, on the allegation that it would be too difficult to collect tax for what the then Prime Minister described as illegal transactions under existing law and, therefore, the recoupment tax was necessary. So much for paragraph (c) of clause 3.

There are two other paragraphs in clause 3-paragraphs (a) and (b)-to which Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle did not address herself. They are provisions which apply interest on late payments for penalties on both promoters and vendor -shareholders. The existing legislation ensures that for the tax proper which has been assessed both the vendor-shareholders and promoters will pay interest if their payments are late. The amendments also incorporated in clause 3 impose the same interest charge on the late payment of penalties. We have heard a great deal from the Opposition, particularly during last year, on how the promoters should be punished and not the vendor-shareholders. Paragraph (a) of clause 3 provides that the promoters will pay interest on any penalty taxes which may be imposed if the promoters are late in making those payments. I invite members of the Opposition, who believed in punishing promoters last year so they told us, to explain why they now propose to exempt promoters from any interest liability on the late payment of penalty tax imposed upon them under the Act passed by the last Government.

It appears that nobody else is going to speak in this debate; everybody had the opportunity. Therefore, I suggest, in order to clarify this matter, that the three separate questions in clause 3-paragraphs (a), (b) and (c)-be voted upon separately.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the Committee that clause 3 be taken in three separate parts? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That clause 3 (b) stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wish to speak briefly to clause 3 (c) because, as I understand it, this is the principal clause on which this Bill lives or dies. A lot of heart searching has been done on this clause because it effectively removes the loophole clause which was inserted in the 1982 legislation and, therefore, in the opinion of many people, it should be adopted by the Parliament. As I have said earlier, it embraces an element of retrospectivity and therefore, understandably, a number of people will vote against it.

SPEECH.PARA: Together with Senator Mason, I have given a great deal of consideration to the justice of this Bill in weighing up whether the people who were allowed to escape their obligations through the inclusion of section 3 (12) of the Act, should be allowed to continue to escape their obligations when in this once only opportunity we can get an anomalies tribunal which will hear appeals from all of those shareholders who were unjustly dealt with by the 1982 legislation. In the event, Senator Mason and I have decided that for the good of and to give justice to those people who were unjustly dealt with, who were left no right of appeal under the 1982 legislation, they should be given that right to appeal and we believe that outweighs the retrospectivity principle which would apply if section 3 (12) were now repealed. It is for that reason that I now appeal to all honourable senators to allow section 3 (12) to be repealed; that is, to allow clause 3 (c), which will repeal it, to go through the Senate today. I think it is fair to suggest that, if it is not passed, the rest of the Bill virtually falls apart and therefore the people we are trying to protect and to whom we are trying to give this right of appeal will forever be denied that right of appeal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is reasonably accurate to say, as Senator Evans put it, that this Bill lives or dies on this vote. That being so, I think I should repeat precisely what this clause does. This clause would restore the rules which applied when the previous Government introduced its original Bill last year. A few weeks after introduicing its original Bill last year, the previous Government added sub-clause (12) to clause 3 of what is now the principal Act. The effect of that addition was to determine the liability of vendor-shareholders to pay tax evaded , not by whether they received a cash benefit but by whether the target company on which current income tax was ultimately evaded had been sold. If that company had been put into an unsuccessful tax avoidance scheme the vendor-shareholders of that company were exempt from liability to pay tax even though they received cash benefits. In other words, the view of the previous Government, the present Opposition, was that the liability of vendor shareholders in those companies on which current income tax was evaded should be determined not by whether those vendor-shareholders received a financial benefit but by subsequent actions taken by other people over which the vendor-shareholders had no control and about which, it is asserted by the Opposition, they necessarily had no knowledge.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle did not respond to my invitation to explain why the Opposition took that view. That remains a mystery. She has had ample opportunity to do so. She has not also disputed the facts as I have presented them. Those who vote in the negative on this motion will be voting for this proposition: The liability of individual vendor-shareholders to pay tax should be determined by the actions of other people over which the vendor- shareholders had no control and about which they necessarily had no knowledge. That is the proposition before the Senate. Those who vote against this clause will endorse the liability to pay or not to pay as I have outlined.
Question put:
That clause 3 (c) stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 4 to 9-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated earlier, the Opposition opposes all of these clauses. They cover a number of matters such as amendments to machinery provisions, identification of arrangements and things of that sort. We have stated throughout the many debates that we are unable to support the proposals by the Government with regard to retrospective taxation legislation. For instance, the amendments to clause 4 which authorise the Commissioner of Taxation to name in his annual report persons who fail to pay vendors or promoters recoupment tax and the omission of the provision that requires the Commissioner to disclose to a vendor or promoter all information held by him relating to the stripping scheme and clarification of the Commissioner's power to make refunds of company tax paid by a vendor or promoter in anticipation of an amendment under this legislation reveal the philosophy of the Government with regard to the legislation before us. I believe the proposed authority for the Commissioner to name persons is vindictive and discriminatory. Why should we single out those who are liable for tax under this legislation? It could apply equally to all taxpayers who do not pay or who have disputes with the tax authorities. Persons who object to ordinary assessments and who do not pay do not have their names publicised, and accordingly a provision of this kind must be viewed purely as an attempt to pressurise or blackmail taxpayers into paying rather than contesting their assessments. Those sorts of provisions in that clause do not find support from us.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, in relation to clause 5 we argue that there could be no basis, other than that it is proving impossible to enforce the legislation, for the removal of the provisions in that section. It seems from all reports that the provision is not making the legislation difficult to enforce. Indeed, the accounting profession reports that in any event the legislation is being administered in such a way that no argument of innocence is ever entertained by the Commissioner and it is always assumed that the taxpayer had a fraudulent intent. A number of matters are covered in clauses 7, 8 and 9 with regard to the identification of a particular arrangement. For instance, clause 7 will remove the requirement that the particular stripping arrangement which rendered the company unable to pay its tax must be identified. Clauses 8 and 9 are consequential upon that clause, and again do not have our support. Clause 7 was included to ensure that before an innocent taxpayer faced an assessment it was certain that an arrangement had occurred. The Taxation Office says that it is merely an unnecessary hurdle being used by taxpayers to avoid assessments. If so, there is little evidence put forward by the Government to support this claim. As we have said on many occasions with regard to all of the provisions in clause 9 of the Bill, they do not have the support of the Opposition parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I make some general comments on the clauses before the Committee. The last vote effectively sealed the fate of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill. The Government will not accept that amendment in the House of Representatives and I do not think that too much more time of the Committee should be taken up in dealing with it. I do want to make a couple of points which demonstrate how little interest the Opposition actually had in what this Bill would do. The Opposition was determined, for reasons which it still does not feel under any obligation to explain, to preserve section 3 (12) of the principal Act. That has been the determinant of the Opposition's policy in respect of this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 4 does provide for publication of the names of tax evaders, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle said, and it also allows the Commissioner of Taxation to refund, with interest, payments of assessments where an excess assessment has been issued. Clause 4 of this Bill, which the Opposition opposes, empowers the Commissioner to return to taxpayers tax for which they should not have been assessed in the first place, and to return it with interest. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle reversed the meaning of that clause. I do not know why she did that, but it does reveal how little interest the Opposition actually has in the Bill. A simple inquiry to the office of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) or a direct inquiry to the Australian Taxation Office would have shown the Opposition that the latter part of clause 4, which it is going to oppose, does in fact do the opposite to that which Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle believes, or at least said, that it does.

I could go on with explanations about the effects of a number of other clauses, but at this stage I do not think it is terribly important. However, I do believe it should be noted for the record that three Australian Democrat senators effectively voted against this Bill by voting against the deletion of section 3 (12) of the principal Act. Those three Democrats voted in similar fashion throughout last year and this year on the ground that they were absolutely opposed to retrospective legislaton. Whether or not one agrees with that view, it has been consistently held and they have voted accordingly. Of the other two Democrats who voted for section 3 (12), Senator Evans was not here last year but Senator Mason was and effectively he voted the same as he voted last year. He too has been consistent. Clearly, the great majority of the members of the official Opposition, however, have no objection in principle to retrospective legislation because they passed an Act with retrospective effect-the principal Act which we are seeking to amend now. They do not have that cop-out. They have not responded to my invitation to explain why they have supported the retention of section 3 (12) of the princpal Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have no shame.

—No, they have no shame. Nor have they disputed the facts as I have presented them. Senator Harradine also voted to retain 3 (12). He also voted in favour of the proposition that the liability to pay tax will be determined by the actions of other people, over which the taxpayer has no control and of which necessarily he has no knowledge. That is the proposition for which Senator Harradine and all the members of the Opposition voted, and for which the three Democrats voted but for different reasons. But last year, when from opposition I moved the same amendment to delete 3 (12) from what is now the principal Act, Senator Harradine voted for that motion. As a result of that vote , the Commonwealth will lose approximately $15m in revenue this financial year and $40m ultimately. Senator Harradine voted today in the opposite way to the way he voted last year. Not only did he do that, but also he has clearly not felt obliged to give any explanation to the Committee or the electors of Tasmania as to why he did it. The facts show that Senator Harradine voted to delete section 3 (12) from what is not the principal Act at a time when his vote was not crucial, but 10 minutes ago, when his vote was crucial, he voted in the opposite direction. He voted for the tax evaders. He voted-bear in mind that he voted in the opposite way to the way he voted last year-for the proposition that the liability to pay or not pay tax will be determined not by the actions of the taxpayers or potential taxpayer but by the actions of other people over which the taxpayer has no control and of which necessarily the taxpayer has no knowledge. As a result of his voting in that way, in the opposite way to the way he voted last year, and without giving any explanation as to why he has reversed his vote, the revenue will lose $15m this year and $40m ultimately.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, Mr Chairman, I do not intend to call any more divisions on this legislation. The Government will formally vote in favour of the remaining clauses of the Bill and will oppose Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's amendment. As the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, said 10 or 15 minutes ago, this Bill is now effectively dead because the Government in the House of Representatives will not accept the amendment which has just been passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Chairman, Senator Walsh cannot help himself.
—He has got a good case.

—He has no case whatsoever. When the proposition was made last year in respect of section 3 (12) of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act, I did vote for it. The reason I voted against it this time is simply that the omission of section 3 (12) has a retrospective effect in that taxpayers who would be entitled to relief under that sub-section and who have requested that it be applied by the Commissioner of Taxation will now have that right removed and face recoupment tax liability. The reason that I say that Senator Walsh cannot help himself, concerns the question of tax evaders. He said that I have voted for tax evaders. That shows that he does not understand the Bill that is before the chamber, because the Bill before the chamber, by definition, when it is dealing with vendor-shareholders does not deal with tax evaders. Tax evaders are those who have breached the law. We are not talking about people in this legislation who have breached the law. Senator Walsh owes an apology to this chamber for that reflection.

SPEECH.PARA: If he continues to make those comments, which are not only ignorant but inane, I will remind him of what he said in a debate on 4 May 1982. It will be recalled that at that time Senator Walsh, as the Opposition spokesman on treasury matters in this place, moved an amendment which was designed, according to him, to overcome a loophole, to use his words, in the Income Tax Assessment Act. On page 1957 of Hansard he stated:

. . . a loophole under which tax on short term profits from the purchase and sale of shares may be avoided if the company which nominally purchased the shares is sold rather than the shares being sold directly.
Presumably that was a legitimate activity at that time. Senator Walsh was at pains to point out:
The Opposition's amendments, if accepted, will ensure that the Bell group and the Bond Corporation pay the tax which they ought to have paid on those transactions.

When the Australian Democrats and I, on a matter of principle-I do not know about the Democrats, but I do not know Mr Bond from a bar of soap-voted against that amendment, we were pilloried in this place by Senator Walsh as being supporters of tax evaders and tax avoiders. He quite unjustly called Mr Bond a tax evader and he called us, when we voted against it, friends of tax dodgers. Who in Australia was the greatest friend of Mr Bond when he won the America's Cup? Who calls him 'my mate Bondie'? Who turned up at the reception at the Lodge which was put on by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)? None other than the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins. The whole lot of them are friends of tax dodgers.

I believe that Senator Walsh ought, firstly, to get his facts right and, secondly, desist from the nonsense with which he is carrying on, because all of this is absolute nonsense. The Government is not fair dinkum about these so- called bottom of the harbour proposals-this is not a bottom of the harbour proposal-and it is not fair dinkum about the so-called unpaid company tax proposals. Were it fair dinkum about them, it would have brought back the first Bill. But it did not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you vote for it?

—Does the Government want me to move an amendment to amend this Bill in precisely the same terms as the first Bill? If it wants me to do so , I will test it out and I will do it, because I know several members of the Cabinet who would run a mile rather than vote for the first Bill. Furthermore, I say to Senator Cook, who interjected, that I know that none of the unions with which I am associated would be caught by this legislation. But I wonder whether he is sure about all of the unions. He had better start checking up on that.
—I am absolutely certain, Senator, about what is the policy of the ACTU and the union movement, and that is to wipe out tax avoidance and evasion.

—I am talking about commercial operations. I asked that question because I do not regard those people who have operated within the law as being tax evaders. They are not by definition tax evaders. If the Government were fair dinkum about all of these things, it would have brought back the first piece of legislation; it did not. It brought back the Mark II Bill. The second reading speech of that Bill referred to the need that the Government saw to amend the Bill to take into account the matters that had been raised in this chamber. History will show-and any members of the Press or others who take an objective look at the legislation will know-that the Government did not do that.

SPEECH.PARA: One aspect, of course, as an example, is that repeatedly the Government was warned of the roll over effect. Ongoing business enterprises would be affected, and if it wished to put back into the barrel the so-called avoided tax, it could do so by certain deeming provisions. None of that was picked up, but it was a very major problem. The Government was reminded about that by me on the last occasion that this measure was introduced. Now we have the Mark III Bill, which is totally different again. That shows that the Government is not fair dinkum about this measure, because the wiser heads in the Government know precisely what the effects will be. Also, the more mature persons in the Government realised that their attempt in this area was contrary to the principles of certainty before the law and, indeed, contrary to the principles of fairness. Mr Chairman, I do hope that that is the end of these stupid remarks that flow from Senator Walsh, but I am afraid that is a forlorn hope. I suppose we are now about to hear further from him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Harradine will not be disappointed, Mr Chairman. When he was goaded to explain the reason why he reversed today the vote that he cast a year ago on exactly the same matter he resorted to false argument. His apologia for reversing the vote is to claim that if section 3 (12) were deleted from the principal Act at this stage it would impose retrospectively tax on those people who had already been exempted from their liability by section 3 (12). In fact section 8 of the Acts Interpretation Act provides that that could not be done. It preserves the right of those who have utilised section 3 (12) provided an assessment has already been issued. So the reason Senator Harradine gave for reversing his vote is no reason at all. Again, that is a fact which could have been checked, had he been at all interested in it, by a simple inquiry to the office of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) or the Australian Taxation Office. It reveals that, like the Opposition, he has had no real interest in determining the crucial facts of this matter. He has determined that section 3 (12) will not be repealed even though 12 months ago he voted for its deletion from the original Act. He has yet to give an explanation as to why he did that, and I do not believe he will.

SPEECH.PARA: None of the other things he had to say had any relevance to the reversal of the vote he cast in 1982. He cannot claim, as the three Australian Democrats are able to claim legitimately, a complete and principled objection to the principle of retrospectivity. He had no total objection to that principle last year. He has changed his vote this year. The reason he has given is spurious. It is in fact simply not correct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Chairman, let me deal first of all with that question. The reason that I gave is absolutely correct. First of all, it places those who would have been involved since 1980 and who would have fallen under the jurisdiction of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act are placed at an advantage compared with those who would be covered under this legislation. In fact if honourable senators analyse the legislation they will see that it imposes retrospectively a harsher penalty on those who undertook certain steps which were within the law between the years 1972 and 1980. It imposes upon them a greater penalty than is imposed upon persons who, deliberately and knowingly, since the introduction of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, did virtually the same thing. I notice that Senator Walsh ignored the points that I made about his calls on friends of the tax dodgers.
—That has got nothing to do with section 3 (12).
—It had something to do with what the honourable senator said. He just said--
—Senator Chipp said that the Democrats were offered half a million . How much would you take?
—Order! Senator Walsh, you will not interject any more. I call Senator Harradine.
—I did not quite hear that interjection but I hope that the Hansard reporter has got it down.
—I said that Senator Chipp said that he was offered half a million dollars. That had no influence on his vote. But you have not yet given a valid reason why your vote has been changed.
—Order! Senator Walsh, from the tone of your words there was a clear reflection on Senator Harradine and I ask you to withdraw.
—I withdraw, Mr Chairman.

—Mr Chairman, that statement is a reflection upon Senator Walsh. It is not the first time that he has made that sort of allegation. He made a similar type of allegation at the Tangney electorate council of the Australian Labor Party in Western Australia. That was a most serious allegation against Senator Chipp and a most serious allegation against me. Frankly, I believe that this is an indication of one of the reasons why Senator Walsh ought to resign from the Ministry or why Mr Keating ought to get somebody else to replace him as representing him in this chamber.

Clause 10.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 6, clause 10, proposed new paragraph 19A (1) (d), lines 34 to 44, leave out the paragraph.

Mr Chairman, clause 10 will provide partial relief to public company shareholders who did not benefit from the bottom of the harbour scheme. I have circulated this amendment in my name on behalf of the Opposition. The amendment will extend the exemption under this clause to private company shareholders. The Opposition welcomes the amendment that the Government has brought forward in this clause, but it is concerned that it will be restricted only to public company shareholders. The relief that is provided arises from a realisation that some unfairness exists in the legislation and that no form of appeal is presently provided, but we would ask: Why exclude private company shareholders from the relief that it is proposed to provide? The Commissioner of Taxation admits that the only reason for not extending the exemption is administrative inconvenience. We suggest that the Commissioner's fear, that taxpayers may seek to delay by claiming that they have received no benefit, is discriminatory if he can relate that only to public company shareholders and not to those who are in private companies. This amendment will have the effect of applying the relief also to private company shareholders. The Government already intends to provide such relief for public company shareholders. I commend the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe I speak for all of the Australian Democrats in saying that we support this amendment. We believe that the anomalies which are revealed need to be corrected and, as I have said previously, the only way of correcting them, outside of moving a vast number of amendments to the taxation legislation as well as to this Bill, is to provide an opportunity for people to appeal to an independent tribunal. That provision should be there not only for public company shareholders but also for private company shareholders who have been dealt with unjustly. They should be allowed that same right. So the Democrats will support the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 11 and 12-by leave-taken together.

Senator Dame MARGARET GUILFOYLE Victoria) (5.10)-Clauses 11 and 12 relate to evidence. Section 23 of the principal Act states that a certificate by the Commissioner of Taxation to the effect that company tax is due and payable but unpaid shall be conclusive proof of that fact, that is, that that certificate cannot be disputed. The provision in that section is under attack and has been litigated in the High Court of Australia on the basis that similar provisions have been previously deemed to be outside the Commonwealth's taxation power. The amendment will make the certificate merely prima facie evidence-that is, it may be argued. However, the onus of proof is upon the taxpayer. It would seem to us that the Government is anticipating a judgment from the High Court. We believe it is not timely to consider this point during the course of a hearing in the Court. It is for this reason that the Opposition opposes the clauses.

The matter that is under consideration in the High Court would need to be considered if a judgment were given along the lines of the fears that are evident at this time in the minds of the Commissioner of Taxation or the Government. The Opposition and I do not believe it is appropriate to insert a provision in legislation while a decision is still being awaited from the High Court on that legislation. For this reason the Opposition will oppose clauses 11 and 12.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to refer to clauses 11 and 12 . It might be remembered, though probably by nobody except myself, that when the original legislation was before this chamber last year I moved an amendment in fact to delete the word 'conclusive' and to insert the words 'prima facie evidence'. I did so on the simple basis that it seemed to me very odd that any tendered document could be conclusive. I pointed out at that time that there could be problems in that an error could be made in the document, in good faith or otherwise, by someone who had charge over the document. There could be a typographical error, a misplaced word or a wrong amount entered. It seemed to me at the time that, in terms of the normal method by which these items are entered , prima facie evidence would be sufficient to carry the case for the purposes of the Bill. Although I believe that the Government has made a useful move in this regard I share some of the misgivings that were mentioned by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. I, too, think it is a bad principle for the Parliament to change legislation while court proceedings are in process in that a person appearing before the court could find himself without recourse in the middle of a case. However, on balance, I support the clauses because I believe they ought to have been in the Act in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we go through this rather puerile exercise of injecting and rejecting clauses of this Bill knowing that its fate is doomed, I see no point in moving my amendment which applies to defeated clause 12.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Bounty (Room Air Conditioners) Amendment Bill 1983. On 17 August 1982 the Liberal Minister for Administrative Services, the Hon. Kevin Newman, forwarded a reference to the Temporary Assistance Authority concerning certain air-conditioning machines and parts for inquiry and report. This reference arose from representation by the major local manufacturer Kelvinator Australia Ltd. In conformity with its charter to enable quick action to be taken, the Temporary Assistance Authority was asked two questions: Firstly, whether it was necessary that urgent action be taken to provide assistance to that industry; and, secondly, if such action were necessary, the nature and extent of the assistance. The Authority found that urgent action was necessary to protect the industry producing certain air- conditioning machines and parts. It recommended that a bounty of up to $1.5m be paid for certain locally produced goods from the date of the Government's decision on the Authority's report until 30 June 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it should be said that legislation of this kind which provides a measure of protection, relief and assistance to manufacturers can, by its very nature of quick action and severity, impose certain high costs and losses on some importing companies which have paid for goods subject to order and import by what is known as an irrevocable letter of credit. I think it has to be recognised that, while on the one hand these are protective measures, on the other hand there are inevitable losses to the importers.

There are two measures in this Bill, both of a temporary nature, which will assist local producers to sell their products in Australia despite intense competition from overseas. The Bill provides for $1,500,000 additional duty for 1983-84 for what are known as portable or fixed window-type designs for use without ducting, and having a nominally rated cooling capacity of 5.4 kilowatts or less. The second feature of this Bill is the introduction of a procedure of import restraint for 1983-84-a tariff quota limiting imports for that period to 55 per cent of the 1982-83 level because of the very high level of imported air- conditioning products and, consequently, the high level of stocks of these goods .

This Bill is a manifestation of some of the many problems which are facing Australian manufacturers at present, particularly specialised manufacturers. These manufacturers must be in a position eventually to meet international competition on equal terms. I think the emphasis must be on the words 'equal terms'. The debate on protection has revolved around the costs which are imposed on the community by Australia's assistance structure. Exporters, farmers and consumers generally wish for a lower rate of protection because of the impact that that protection will have of adding to the costs of domestically produced goods.

I do not think there were many problems with the White Paper that was produced in 1977. It was suggested in that White Paper that, as a long term objective, the community would be best served by a manufacturing industry with a structure that required minimum levels of government support.
