But any form of assistance, whether it be a subsidy, tax relief or a tariff, has the effect of redistributing income from one group to another in society. The real question is whether the benefits to one sector outweigh the costs to the other. Generally, all things being equal, it is acknowledged that a higher level of protection tends to diminish the rate of growth.

Traditionally, the farming community in particular has complained the loudest about the disadvantages imposed upon it through various protective devices, in particular the tariff. We acknowledge that the costs to the community are both direct and indirect. For example, the direct cost of the recent tariff on imported harvesters essentially raises the cost to the farming community and for that reason it was opposed. The less obvious costs are the indirect costs. They tend to raise the cost of labour or they can have an impact on the appreciation of the exchange rate to the disadvantage of exporters. The protection argument is much more difficult to sustain in Australia in situations or environments where costs could be higher and productivity substantially lower than in competing countries enjoying similar living standards. However, I for one am not prepared to stand by and see Australian standards of living drop to what might be regarded as low Asian standards, while at the same time a few people enjoy very high incomes from what might be regarded as a total free trade approach.

Whilst the export industries demand a free, unregulated approach except when commodity prices appear to be down, the manufacturing sector requires a measure of protection. I think a change is required by some trade union officials in their philosophy of adopting wage structures which are geared to the greatest good for the whole community; that is, the employed, the unemployed and those people seeking work. I think it is unfortunate that a minority of union leaders- this has not necessarily always been supported from the heart by the rank and file-have adopted an unfortunate policy of obtaining the highest wage possible for those privileged to work in what I might term sheltered employment. This form of employment can be sheltered through a number of factors. It can be sheltered through the inherent nature of the industry in which these people work or it can be sheltered through measures other than tax measures. It is unfortunate that the whole of the protection debate has essentially revolved around assistance to manufacturers. It is unfortunate that those people employed in the manufacturing industry have had to carry the brunt of the criticism of so -called inefficient operations in Australia, rather than all those workers employed in what I might term sheltered industries.

I recognise that the Australian Government has a responsibility to intervene in the management of international trade. I think this is inevitable. We have to match similar policies of intervention which are adopted by countries such as Japan in assisting their industries. Australia is highly vulnerable to dumping of all sorts. Australia's small market tends to place limits on economies of scale in manufacturing operations. It is regrettable that there has been so little assistance in Australia through subsidies and other fiscal measures. Australia's protection is what is known as visible protection basically because Australia abides by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, unlike most other competing countries. It is unfortunate that we hear criticisms from GATT officials directed towards Australia when so many other countries are offending in a much greater way.

There is an inevitability of greater government intervention in world trade. We are already witnessing a very much greater share of trade from the centrally planned economies and the developing countries. Australia just cannot afford to stand apart from these sorts of developments. We have to recognise that great distortions are taking place through non-tariff measures. I repeat that great distortions are taking place through non-tariff measures. Protectionist techniques nowadays are becoming less transparent, therefore creating GATT problems. GATT really is not getting to grips with this problem, but it continues to attack the situation in Australia. According to the statistics something like 70 per cent of goods entering Australia come in either tariff free or with under 5 per cent duty in terms of value. We acknowledge that there are a few high flyers. The whole criticism seems to be taken out of kilter. It becomes biased and is directed towards these high flyers rather than towards the general level of imports that are coming in with under 5 per cent duty or no duty at all.

World trade is increasingly becoming managed by a vast array of interventions. These include customs manipulations, quantitative restrictions and tariff resources. Countries frequently exploit non-tariff matters relating to health, quarantine and safety to limit trade. Across the Tasman we in Tasmania are experiencing a particular problem in relation to the export of our goats to New Zealand. The New Zealand Government is temporarily imposing health and quarantine restrictions on that item of import. Other countries provide budgetary assistance through tax holidays and tax incentives, such as generous depreciation rates, low interest rates and finance.

The Industries Assistance Commission is unique in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. In Australia it has become the linchpin for evaluating and publicising levels of assistance and in advising government on the nature and extent of assistance. Naturally this Commission is viewed rather sceptically by business because of its free trade philosophy despite its independence from political processes. The preferential system for developing countries, which is a humanitarian scheme, I believe now requires some review as some of the listed countries in the schedule have reached a level of technical competence in production and marketing skills. But their products are now having adverse effects on local Australian employment. This is manifested in the air conditioning industry. The Bounty (Room Air-Conditioners) Amendment Bill we are debating today is a manifestation of one of the problems. The growth in the manufacturing sector supported a larger population with a growing standard of living. It supported a bureaucracy whose growth has outstripped the private sector. What we are seeing now is seriously declining manufacturing activity. In the last decade employment in manufacturing has declined dramatically. This has brought a decline in the standard of living of many hundreds of thousands of Australians.

Much of Australian manufacturing industry commenced at a time of excess demand and limited supply and has subsequently grown up under a cloak of protection. If the Government wishes industry to invest in high technology, which appears to be the in thing at the moment, it must at the same time allow industry to have volume to recover its high fixed costs as a result of investment in that technology, otherwise there will be no incentive to invest. I believe government departments must be directed to source much more of their requirements from what is known as the growing or the new technology-type Australian companies. It is regrettable that all too often heads of departments, their assistants and their purchasing people opt for the large overseas supplier to the detriment of the young Australian owned and operated company so frequently in the high technology area. Less risk and less chance of criticism is involved. Unfortunately the IAC never reports on the social consequences or indicates where jobs are to be found for retrenched manufacturing employees.

The manufacturing industry employs sixteen times as many people as the mining industry but it gets very little support. It employs three and a half times as many people as does the rural industry. Unfortunately, in Australia budgetary assistance is erratic and uncertain and involves problems of planning and financing. The Bounty (Room Air-Conditioners) Amendment Bill is but part of this scenario. It is providing assistance to the year 1983-84. There must be a long term plan. There must be a package of measures involving taxation as well as industrial measures to overcome the dilemma of manufacturing. On the other hand, society is increasingly becoming concerned about the extent of government intervention, because the more government intervention the higher the level of taxation.

A survey was conducted this year by the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research. It found that 70 per cent of the people surveyed felt that the regulation of business usually does more harm than good. This is a sobering thought. More debate is urgently required on this and associated protection measures in Australia. I believe we cannot afford to lose our manufacturing industry. A long term policy encouraging efficient export industries and employing Australian capital and Australians will certainly be to the long term benefit of this country. As I mentioned earlier, our high standards of living were built up on a growing manufacturing base. Unfortunately , that manufacturing base has been eroded at present. The end result has been high levels of unemployment and uncertainty about the future. I welcome this measure today as but one interim measure that is essential to try to overcome a malaise in manufacturing in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Bounty (Room Air- Conditioners) Amendment Bill 1983. The Bill provides for the continuation of the bounty assistance of $1.5m which applied in 1982-83 and, in addition, provides for the application of a tariff quota to restrain the level of imports. As a South Australian senator, I have taken a great deal of interest in the debate concerning protection measures for this part of the white goods industry. The industry is vitally important to the South Australian economy and the measures contained in this Bill will, no doubt, assist Kelvinator Australia Ltd in achieving a greater market share in 1983-84 than it did in 1982-83. At the time of the introduction of bounty assistance by the former Government, I expressed my concern that the bounty in itself would not provide sufficient protection for the industry. In the Senate on 18 November 1982 during a first reading debate I said:

SPEECH.PARA: The way out chosen by the Government will not guarantee Kelvinator a reasonable market share. I am afraid that it will not guarantee the jobs of the workers. A bounty system in conjunction with a form of quota protection would have been a more sensible compromise in the circumstances.

The way things have turned out it seems history has shown the former Government made a very grave mistake in not granting the quota protection I was advocating at the time. The latest Temporary Assistance Authority report on certain air conditioning machines states quite clearly that employment attributable to the production and sale of the Kelvinator range of room air conditioners declined sharply after the previous inquiry. In 1982 Email Ltd's employment attributable to the Kelvinator range stood at 458. In March 1983 it had fallen by 61 per cent to 177. If we look at the sales and production figures of Kelvinator room air conditioners we see that total sales for 1982-83 were about 28,500, a decline of 45 per cent over the previous year, and that total production was estimated to be 24,800 units, a fall of 58 per cent since 1981-82. The report goes on:

The profitability of the Kelvinator room air conditioner operation decreased markedly during its financial year to 31 March 1983. Whereas in 1981-82 the operation achieved a return on funds employed of 12.4 per cent, a substantial loss was recorded in 1982-83.

In other words, the previous Government's measures to deal with the problem of increasing imports was clearly inadequate. According to the report, imports from Japan increased their market share from 35 per cent in 1981-82 to about 50 per cent in the nine months to March 1983. In fact local production accounted for only 10 per cent of the total market supplies during 1982-83, compared with 23 per cent in 1981-82 and 42.5 per cent in 1979-80. Quite clearly the previous Government must accept some of the blame for the disastrous decline in sales and production levels during 1982-83 and the failure of the local company at least to maintain its 1981-82 market share.

During my speech in the Senate last November I pointed out that until October a total of 160,000 imported room air conditioners had arrived in Australia for the 1982-83 financial year. If we look at the report we see that a further 34,000 room air conditioners came into the country between October 1982 and March 1983. Therefore, had some form of quota protection been applied immediately last November, Kelvinator's potential market share could have been increased substantially and some of those 281 jobs could have been saved. Instead, the previous Government blindly accepted the recommendations of the Temporary Assistance Authority, knowing full well what the possible consequences would be for the workers in Adelaide if the bounty measure alone proved insufficient. Obviously the previous Government's economic policies were also partly to blame for the drop in total sales of room air conditioners in 1982-83. With the prospect of a 12-months wages freeze many people just postponed their decision to buy costly items such as air conditioners. This, combined with a cooler than normal summer in Western Australia and New South Wales, meant that total levels of sales in 1982-83 were considerably less than expected. Nevertheless, whatever the level of sales last financial year, had quota protection been applied at the time we could have saved at least some of those jobs. Even the Temporary Assistance Authority has recognised that Kelvinator was badly affected by imports last year. Its latest report states:

While the Authority recognises that the downturn in the local industry is due to a number of factors, it considers that the evidence demonstates that the Kelvinator operation was adversely affected by import competition in the nine months to March 1983.

Of course, there is now a considerable build-up of excess stocks, many of which are imports. These high excess stock levels combined with a continuing high level of imports in 1983-84 would have led to a complete domination of the market by imports and a closing of the Adelaide operation. This is why I am pleased that the Government has seen fit to impose a quota on imports for the coming year. As the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) pointed out during the second reading speech, the bounty itself may not have been adequate to assist Kelvinator to contain the competition from imports in 1983-84 . However, by limiting imports to 55 per cent of the 1982-83 level, the Government has effectively given Kelvinator greater scope to achieve a much larger market share in this financial year. As a senator for South Australia, I am very pleased with this decision because it will assist the company to become more viable and hopefully guarantee the jobs of the workers in the Adelaide plant. The company will certainly now have a much better chance of achieving these ends than under the previous arrangements introduced by the former Government.

This Bill seeks to arrest in some way the enormous pressure being placed on our local manufacturing industry by imports. This situation of imports pouring into Australia and putting at risk thousands of jobs in our manufacturing industry is , of course, confined not only to the white goods industry. There have been far too many incidents of importers using unfair practices and dumping goods on to the Australian market to obtain what they consider to be a satisfactory market share. One such example is the motor vehicle industry where at present we have the problem concerning the importation of light commercial vehicles and the threat this is posing to thousands of jobs in the local car industry. In fact South Australia has been hit hardest by the tremendous increase in imports we have seen over the last three years. Thousands of manufacturing jobs have been lost in that period and we have had the unenviable reputation of being the State with the highest or the second highest unemployment rate in the country for several years. Therefore, I am heartened by the Government's decision to act to halt the flood of imports in this section of the white goods industry. It is a credit to this Government that it has decided to act in a more vigorous and decisive way than our predecessors. I, therefore, have much pleasure in supporting the Bill and commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the two honourable senators who have contributed to the debate. The reasons for this legislation are explained in the second reading speech. Senator Foreman has canvassed the issue in some detail and Senator Watson, if I might use the analogy, painted on a much broader canvas a picture of the problems of manufacturing industry and changing attitudes to protection. I do not feel I need add any more to the debate at this stage. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 December 1983, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prices Surveillance Bill has been described by the Government as a major commitment as part of the prices and incomes accord. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his second reading speech stated that the mandate to establish the Prices Surveillance Authority has been widely recognised in the community. He went on to describe how a working party had been established to provide advice to the Government. I noted that the working party included representatives of the trade union movement, business and State and local government and that they had been extensively consulted by the Government before bringing the Bill into the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that it has been widely recognised by the community as something for which the Government had a mandate under its prices and incomes accord is perhaps not disputed, but the fact that it is recognised does not mean that it is accepted by the whole of the community in quite that spirit. In fact, the National Economic Summit Conference communique stated:
The employers accept that the Government has a mandate to establish a price surveillance mechanism. Many employers believe this is unnecessary . . .

There was consultation with the trade union movement prior to the introduction of the Bill. That leads me to say that it was evident that the Australian Council of Trade Unions was not satisfied with the Bill that had been introduced or with the statements that had been made by the Government with regard to the authority at the time of the introduction of the Bill. In fact, early in December the President of the ACTU stated that the trade union movement would take no part in co-operating with the proposed authority and that the authority should determine a firm set of price guidelines with general application to the community.

I have noted with some interest today's Press, which has stated that the ACTU is happy with assurances that have been given by the Government on the prices watchdog, as the headline described it. I would be interested to hear from the Government as we proceed through this debate what assurances were given by the Government to the ACTU with regard to the Bill or the authority and its powers and application to change the views of the ACTU so markedly in the space of a week or two. If the trade union movement was part of the consultation process that preceded the Bill and it was previously not happy with the Bill, I would be interested to know what adjustments were made. Have some changes to the legislation or the vesting of some further powers in the authority led the ACTU now to be happy or satisfied with assurances that have been given?

The Opposition is opposed to the establishment of the Prices Surveillance Authority. We believe that it would be an unwarranted interference in the operations of commercial enterprises at this time. There is a need for continued and increased competitiveness of Australian industry and, as is always said at times of government from industry, it is at enormous cost to industry that it needs to fulfil requirements of government through government authorities, government procedures, government charges and things of that sort.

The Government says that it will give the authority a somewhat limited role. That was probably the concern of the ACTU. We would want to know more about how the Authority would use the powers provided in the Bill and the direction that the Minister concerned will give to the Authority. We think that at this time it would pose a further difficulty for business. I do not think that, despite the figures that were read out I believe by Senator Cook this morning, anyone would dispute that business profits are low, that businesses have difficulties and that the tentative signs of recovery in our economy are to be nurtured rather than impeded. It would have to be accepted by anyone who understands the application of business that price surveillance cannot reduce unemployment, which is at present so much of a difficulty in our economy. It was excessive wage increases, not price increases, which produced our high level of unemployment. When talking about prices, perhaps we ought to be looking at the price of labour as well as the price of goods, because the price of labour is of enormous consequence in our economy and in our competitiveness as we try to establish growth in our economy and the opportunity to do some of the things that we would wish to see achieved for this country.

The Government has established its wages policy, a policy of full indexation. The prices and incomes accord will not survive wage increases and wage pressures as the economy gathers momentum if the recovery of which we see signs at present takes place. There have already been stresses on the wages side of the Government's wages and prices policy. The stresses that we have seen in the building industry unions in relation to the building agreement, the food preservers' case, the increase in salaries of New South Wales parliamentarians and so on lead us to see that there are pressures with regard to wage increases. The prices and incomes accord will continue to guarantee a high level of unemployment. The figures that were produced to the Economic Planning Advisory Council showed the difficulties that arose from the return to full wage indexation, projecting an 11 per cent plus unemployment rate for 1984-85 and a slightly lower rate for 1985-86. This is the climate in which we see the introduction of a Prices Surveillance Authority. It is in these sorts of circumstances that we find it somewhat illogical to talk about restraining prices or interfering with the profits of business.

The tentative acceptance by employers at the time of the Summit was evident in the fact that, as I said earlier, many employers stated in the Summit communique that they felt it was unnecessary. The Government's argument is that if there is to be wage restraint it is reasonable also to expect that there should be price restraint. I do not believe that people would argue with that in terms of a simple statement but if we look at economic conditions we are looking at wage restraint, company profitability and the capacity to employ. If price restraint is to be imposed to the detriment of profitability and capacity to employ, I feel that another element is introduced into the economy which could present great difficulties.

Business profitability in terms of the profits share over recent years has shown that there is an historical low in those figures. That, of course, is one of the accepted reasons for the difficulties in the economy and the decline in both our competitiveness and our ability to provide employment. We have seen that that difficulty is yet to be addressed. It is quite wrong to address that by the introduction of a Prices Surveillance Authority and the problem of job creation will certainly not be solved by the introduction of further detailed Government requirements of business through the application of this authority.
The President of the ACTU, on 7 December, said:
The Federal Government's Prices Surveillance Act in its present form poses the first serious threat to the prices and incomes accord.

As I said earlier, that apparently has now resulted in some assurances being given by the Government. It will be of very great interest to see that we are informed of what those assurances were, and whether the present Act will be able to be used in the way in which the trade union movement finds acceptable.

Mr Dolan said at that time that the ACTU and the trade union movement might have to reconsider the commitment in the wages area of the accord if the prices side were not adhered to, and that this legislation destroys the prices element in the prices and incomes accord. The talks that have been held since that statement of 7 December have not caused a great deal of public comment, with the exception of the article which I read today. It is of interest to us that the Bill does not apply to State authorities. The States, as I understand it, have rejected the idea of any surveillance over their authorities, although the Government says it will consult State authorities. The States, as I understand it, have rejected the idea of any surveillance over their authorities. If we are to look at costs and prices, the cost of power and other services that are provided by State authorities, the costs of State charges, State duties and State taxes are very important indeed in looking at prices that result from the manufacture of goods or from the provision of services by those in the commercial sector.

The Treasurer said that this Bill incorporates legislative guidelines which will require the Authority to exercise its powers and perform its functions having regard to the need to maintain investment and employment. Of course we see that as an absolute prerequisite for any government dealing with the economy at this time. If there is to be any body that does not have to have regard to the need to maintain investment and employment it would seem to be an act of destruction rather than one that would give any assistance at all to the creation of employment or the maintenance of existing employment.

The Treasurer also said that if necessary where it is clear that a company has taken all reasonable steps to resist a breach, that is, a breach of the wages system, a ministerial direction under section 20 will be issued to the Authority that the resulting cost increases should not be disallowed. I should like some information as to the criteria that will enable the Treasurer to conclude that a company has taken all reasonable steps to resist a breach. I think it would be of great importance to companies to know in what way they will need to deal with the requirements of that section.

While removing restraints on union behaviour the Government is being asked by the unions to impose even more stringent controls over employers regarding prices than is mentioned in this legislation because there are the proposals, some of which have been put into effect by the Government in the name of the prices and incomes accord, with regard to a number of matters relating to industrial matters. I refer to such things as the abolition of the Industrial Relations Bureau, the legislation for which has been passed to enhance further the position of the trade unions in the Australian community; the repeal of the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act which was designed to protect the provision of essential services in the community, and the fact that the Government has indicated its intention to revoke section 45D of the Trade Practices Act, another step to put the trade unions beyond the laws which apply to the rest of the Australian community.

Trade union power, it must be argued, can be as monopolistic and as restrictive as corporate power. When we are dealing with a body such as the Prices Surveillance Authority, which is designed to deal with corporate power, we need to remind ourselves of the other side of the coin, that is, the sorts of legislation and requirements of government regarding trade union movements and those who offer their labour, because the price of goods is related very much to the price of labour and to other costs endured by companies. It is of interest to us that claims have been made by professions and by small businesses that they have apprehension with regard to the establishment of a Prices Surveillance Authority. I think that some evidence from the Government of its intention with regard to the ACTU or the trade union movement assurances that have been given would be appropriate as we are dealing with a Bill of this nature.

I have noted in particular the statements by the Treasurer with regard to the way in which he would use the Authority and his hope that the Authority will have some effect on prices. But as I said earlier, that statement and the introduction of this Bill were entirely rejected by the trade union movement which said it would put the prices and incomes accord under severe threat. I think at this time, when dealing with a Bill which, as I have stated, the Opposition will oppose, it would be very appropriate for us to hear a little more about the application of the Authority when it is established and what changes have been made from the time of the second reading speech, the introduction of the Bill and the passage of the Bill through the House of Representatives, to reach the sorts of statements that have been made today with regard to the trade union movement being happy with the assurances that have been given to it. I confine my remarks to those matters that I have mentioned and state again that the establishment of the Prices Surveillance Authority at this time is opposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Prices Surveillance Bill 1983. I listened intently to the remarks of Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. I wish not at this moment, but later in my remarks, to make some comment on some of the questions she put because I think there are very simple answers. If those questions dealing with undertakings, et cetera, are the main issue that the Opposition is concerned about, this Bill should have unanimous passage through the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: In February of this year at a national unions conference called by the Australian Council of Trade Unions in Melbourne the prices and incomes accord was adopted. I think it is important to begin my remarks on this legislation by quoting for the Senate record what is the undertaking between the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions on prices because the accord which sets out that undertaking can be seen as clarifying some of the issues raised by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. Under the heading 'Agreed Policy Details', with the sub-heading 'Prices', the accord reads:

A pricing authority will be established which will be given legislative criteria by which it must asses the validity or otherwise of price rises sought by corporations and the public authorities within its justification. It is considered unnecessary to attempt to regulate prices of all corporations if the large corporations, which are generally the price-setters in their industry, are subject to public surveillance.

The legislative criteria will be designed to ensure that enterprises do not earn profits beyond levels necessary for the maintenance and the expansion of the enterprise, that real wages of employees are protected, and that unnecessary cost increases are not reflected in higher prices. In this regard the amount by which wages may increase beyond that warranted by increases in prices and national productivity will not normally be allowable as the basis of a price rise.

The pricing authority will operate in a less legalistic manner than the former PJT so that cost to the corporations concerned, and the time involved in processing price rise applications, will be less than those which previously applied.

The Trade Practices Legislation will be strengthened to promote more effective competition and to reduce the possibility of excessive prices through stronger regulation of mergers, more effective outlawing of abuses of market power, tougher prosecutions against price agreements and additional protection for consumers against unfair practices.

That is the provision in the accord. By setting out in those terms an accord which has been assented to by the union movement and the Government it is clearer, as distinct from the remarks made by the previous speaker, what this legislation is about.

However, the accord is not the only formal reference that can be referred to when tracing the origins of the Prices Surveillance Bill. The Government, elected on a 'bringing Australia together' mandate called, as we know, one month after it was installed in office a National Economic Summit Conference. That Summit brought forth a communique, after meeting for four days in a quite historic economic parliament, as it was labled by the media.

Several parts of the communique are relevant. Paragraphs 12 and 24 ought to be referred to but the key paragraph, in terms of price surveillance, is 26 which, to be consistent, should be quoted. The last speaker argued that there had been a considerable expression, on the part of industry, of lack of support for this legislation. Since it springs from the Summit communique, in terms of the tripartite government, industry and unions perspective, paragraph 26 of the communique is pertinent. It reads:

26. The employers accept that the Government has a mandate to establish a price surveillance mechanism. Many employers believe this is unnecessary but they are prepared, together with Government and unions, to be involved in an examination as to the most appropriate form and functioning of a prices surveillance mechanism. It is agreed that this examination will be conducted by a representative working committee.
It is a matter of record that that committee has met and deliberated extensively and that a tangible result of its labours is the Bill before the Senate today.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about small business representation?

—A working party was set up after the Summit and it was drawn from the participants. I cannot recall, while I am on my feet, whether the small business community was represented on the working party but I can say that the Government, in all of its economic considerations, has been very concerned-
—How many representatives on the working party were from small business?

—Small business was represented at the Summit and it supported the communique. Therefore, one assumes that small business backed the processes that have been followed. The Government has been very concerned to consider and to protect the interests of the small business community. However, let me go on to speak of what I think is the outcome of all of those proceedings. The Government was elected on a mandate to bring Australia together. The steps that it has taken have done that. The legislation that we have before us is uncommonly supported across borders which are normally hostile to one another. That is a significant achievement and I think a case study in how a country should be managed by the co-operative effort of all of its major social partners. That is what this Government has achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn briefly to some of the philosophy behind the prices surveillance legislation. Of course, the key issue is that of achieving a level of economic recovery that will put people back in jobs, will make Australian industry profitable and will permit such development of the manufacturing and other industries as will ensure their long term viable future. Consistent with that aim, in terms of the Economic Summit communique and the philosophy of the Government, we have been concerned to see that there should be restraint in wages and prices. The commitment of the Summit was that restraint should be exercised on all sides; that we should all share the burdens necessary to bring about economic recovery. Wages-Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle made a remark about the subject-are of course regulated. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is the regulatory authority. It accepted the arguments of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government at the last national wage case hearing and brought in a centralised system of wage fixing which required that unions comply with certain undertakings in return for the 4.3 per cent increase. Nearly all unions have voluntarily gone before benches of the Commission, have given the undertakings required and have accepted the increase. Thus, they have given on the public record firm undertakings to abide by the centralised wage fixing system and to accept the level of increase that the Commission has awarded and not moved beyond it. That is the strongest agreement that one can have, in the sense not only of observing the Commission's decisions are properly observed.

In regard to non-wage incomes, there is some concern but a number of indirect measures are available to the Government if it should prove necessary to adopt them. In order to balance the mosaic one needs to have in place a provisoin on prices so that people in the community, who are being asked to restrain their activities, can see that there is equality across the board, that it is not just wage earners who are being asked to exercise restraint-the approach adopted by the last Government. Thus prices, which until now have been substantially unregulated, are to come under the purview of the Prices Surveillance Authority. I believe that will ensure restraint on all sides and will be seen by all parties to the central commitment to be a genuine exercise in restaint.

As is clear from all of the papers, the Prices Surveillance Authority will not regulate or control all prices. That is not its character; it is not that type of being. It will intervene where necessary against excessive prices and require , where they are prima facie excessive, that there be some accounting, investigation and review. Of course, if that investigation and review reveal that the prices sought are proper and reasonable those prices will apply. If it is found that they ought to be lower, or not increased at all, the public will know the basis upon which they have been shifted upwards and, will know of the evidence that has been adduced before the Authority. If the particular company, in regard to which the Government can exercise no direct constraint to compel it to observe the findings of the Authority, wishes to flout the heavy moral responsibility that it must bear, the public will have the ultimate sanction as consumers and will know how to treat the offender.

The important element of the Prices Surveillance Authority is that it is not all-pervasive. It is not a central regulatory body. It will not control prices. It will recommend prices after a proper investigation, public accounting and examination of them. Then, if the company wishes to pursue them, the ultimate sanction will be that exercised by the community, which can choose not to support the company; but there is no provision in the Bill for the Government to compel the company to observe certain prices.

One of the other essential aspects of the PSA, as it now is, is that it will be less legalistic and formal than was the Prices Justification Tribunal which, in my period before coming into this place, was colloquially known among a number of wage and salary earners as the prices bastardisation tribunal, simply because it seemed to run ahead of what were reasonable prices and provide a justification, that was really not merited, for increasing those prices. The PSA will play a vastly different role. It will be less legalistic or formal and therefore, I trust, more effective. Our approach in this field springs from the recognition and support by the Government of the fact that the Australian economy is essentially a mixed economy, that the private sector is the major sector and that it employs the majority of Australian workers. Therefore, there is a ready and willing recognition that companies need to be profitable in order to obtain income for capital reinvestment, and they must be able to attract investment themselves as undertakings.

In our lexicon profit is not a dirty word. It is recognised as being an essential component of a healthy private sector. It is the intention of the legislation not to constrain profit levels so that employment-generating expansion of the private sector will not occur. We are not so silly; that is not our intention. We want to see a healthy, robust and constructive private sector. That might go also to a couple of remarks that were made by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle earlier. She drew attention to a comment that I made in this morning's debate on the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill. I referred to the latest set of economic indicators and emphasised that they showed a redistribution, in terms of gross domestic product, from wages and salaries to profits. That is a fact in terms of what those indicators show. I do not pretend that, therefore, automatically the private sector is excessively healthy and robust. In fact, I think the effect of price surveillance legislation will be not to involve too many prices under surveillance in practical terms. Those indicators do show a redistribution away from wages and salaries to profits. That was significant in terms of what I said in the debate on equity this morning. But to make a general comment that it can then be construed that everything in the garden of the private sector, after a year of record low profits last year, is rosy is not an accurate reflection.

The other matter raised by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in her remarks was that the price of labour is a key price and that ought to be checked. I do not think that argument needs to be pursued because it is facile and superficial. As I have indicated, the cost of labour is set by arbitration commissions upon hearing argument from employers, unions and, if necessary in the public interest , governments. If it is held that those decisions are wrong it is not, as is normally the case for the Opposition, a matter of blaming unions. It is a matter of challenging the veracity of the umpire's decision and the fairness and fitness of it.

The feeble attempt to try to indicate a breakout from the prices and incomes accord on the unions' side by citing the building trades agreement or the food preservers' case is, of course, not sustainable in any sense. In all honesty and with respect to the honourable senator I say that it was not sustained be her. Those cases were merely cited as examples without being employed in such a way as to justify the argument Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was making. The facts are, however, that the building trades agreement has not resulted in widespread industrial disruption since it was rejected by the Commission and the building trades agreement parties are in close collaboration with one another to find some other way of expressing their mutual agreement which will meet the guidelines of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. In terms of the food preservers, one does not need to go too far into that argument to see that the food preservers represent no threat to the accord which has been remarkably successful. One, therefore, cannot be persuaded at all that those, I guess, feeble attempts which are really debating points and not serious argument should be considered.

The other point Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle raised about Economic Planning Advisory Council projections is, I think, adequately put to sleep if her reading of the same newspaper from which she quoted about the Australian Labor Advisory Council meeting yesterday was to be extended to the projections of EPAC in terms of the economy. In fact, the latest figures posted last Thursday show that the earlier EPAC projections which were leaked and from which she sought to draw some comfort are now indicative of a general strand and are not accurate in the sense of the latest score in terms of the statistics.

With those remarks, let me turn to what this Bill does do. This Bill provides a broad framework-not a detailed prescription-in which, selectively, key prices can be surveyed. The components of all prices will not necessarily be put through a detailed examination. The selectivity of it will depend upon the exercise of proper and due discretion by the Minister-in this case, the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Conditions for the selection of goods and services will relate to areas where effective competitive disciplines are not present and where prices or wage decisions have pervasive effects throughout the economy. The great majority of business will, therefore, not be subject to surveillance. Decisions on which industries need to be covered will be made by the Treasurer in consultation with the Surveillance Authority which, of course, can also consult, if necessary, the Trade Practices Commissioner.

The Authority will be asked to observe a number of legislative guidelines. They are the need to maintain investment and employment, including the influence of profitability on investment and employment; the need to discourage a person who is in a position substantially to influence a market for goods or services from taking advantage of that power and setting prices; and the need to discourage cost increases arising from increases in wages and charges in conditions of employment inconsistent with the principles established by the relevant industrial tribunals.

With those remarks I would like to turn to the major issue Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle raised. Indeed, I think it is a matter that requires some ventilation in the Senate Hansard record. On Thursday of last week a number of newspapers carried headlines to which I wish to refer. For example, the West Australian, said: 'Prices body inadequate, says the ACTU'. The Age had 'ACTU threat to pay accord' as its banner headline. The Australian Financial Review had as its headline: 'ACTU-Government prices collision'. I think the first thing that can be said about that range of headlines and the articles that followed those headlines is that they overstated the case quite considerably. Last Thursday in the House of Representatives, in answer to a question from the very celebrated honourable member for Port Adelaide, Mick Young, to the Treasurer, the Treasurer read into the House of Representatives Hansard a telex he had received that morning from the Secretary and the President of the ACTU concerning newspaper reports. Since I have the text of that telex in front of me now it is as well that it be read in this chamber too. The telex stated:
Attention: R. J. L. Hawke-Prime Minister
P. Keating 1. The ACTU has had extensive discussions with the Government on the question of the PSA.

2. The ACTU does not oppose the PSA legislation. There are no changes that we wish to make in regard to the legislation. The legislation has been discussed with the ACTU and we have accepted the legislation.
3. However, the legislative framework unequivocally puts the onus on the Treasurer to make the PSA an effective body.
4. In this context the Executive believes that a number of decisions, all of which are of an administrative nature, should be made. These are detailed in the resolution.

5. We believe that the ACTU Executive decision should be subject to further discussion. Those discussions have already commenced. We are satisfied that the Treasurer will genuinely consider each of the issues we raised.

6. The desire of the ACTU is to have an effective prices surveillance authority consistent with the prices and incomes accord. We do not want a repetition of the PJT with its emphasis on legalism and bureaucracy.
It concludes with this one sentence:
There is absolutely nothing in the ACTU resolution which detracts from that position.

It is signed by Kelty and Dolan in their respective offices on behalf of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. If the honourable senator had kept up her reading of the House of Representatives Hansard she would have read that answer, and a number of the concerns she raised in her speech would not need to have been raised. Her main concern seemed to be the undertakings given yesterday at a meeting of the Australian Labor Advisory Council when, of course, last week on the record we had the satisfaction of the ACTU in telex form, signed by the President and the Secretary of that body, with the legislation we are dealing with and debating now. I turn again to what the telex said:
There are no changes that we wish to make in regard to the legislation. The legislation has been discussed with the ACTU and we have accepted the legislation.

On that basis, there is no substance in what Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has argued. One of the areas of proper and genuine interest not only by the ACTU but also by a number of other people and organisations is what the administrative means of the PSA will be and how it will conduct its affairs. They are matters to be worked out with the Authority once it is constituted. I have a number of interests in that issue. Just to cite one of them, the old Prices Justification Tribunal worked on the basis of lawyers on one side arguing why a price should be as it was and often ACTU research officers on the other side arguing why it should not be.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had almost concluded my remarks when the sitting was suspended for dinner. The concluding point I want to make is that a number of procedures are yet to be worked out. However, what the Bill does provide is a broad legislative framework and that framework is such as to provide a basis for prices surveillance legislation which will ensure that the interests of all parties will be protected.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the procedures under that legislation are yet to be resolved, and I gave an example. I hope that the new body will avoid some of the mistakes made by the old Prices Justification Tribunal and that, rather than having the adversary style of inquiry which typified the PJT it will adopt a more inquisitorial style and get to the bottom of an issue without a great deal of legalism and undue formality.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you think there could be legalism in an inquisitorial style?

—If it adopted an inquisitorial style it would fulfil the reference to 'surveillance' in the title of the organisation in finding out what are the issues and the mechanisms involved. As I have said, the legislation has been agreed to by all of the major parties. They have worked hard and long since the National Economic Summit Conference to bring it to fruition. An earlier interjection asked whether the interests of small business had been taken care of. I can assure Senator Hill that not only were they taken care of in terms of participation in the Summit and therefore input into the communique-
—How many small businessmen were there? They were taken care of outside.

—I refer Senator Watson to the record of the National Economic Summit Conference. If he consults that document he will see that the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia was a participant-
—Only one, and 28 big businessmen.

—If the honourable senator insists on that line of argument, I point out that only one union organisation was represented-the ACTU-and there are 387 unions in Australia. There was one organisation representing all of the small business organisations of Australia. It is their organisation and they were represented. I will not dally with those ineffectual and pathetic interjections. It is clear that the small business organisations participated in the Summit. The Council had its say, put its views on the record, and supported the communique. That might be uncomfortable for the Liberal Party but, irrespective of how uncomfortable it is, that is a fact and the record clearly demonstrates it. Mr Don Gibbons, the Chairman of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, was part of the working party that turned its mind to the prices surveillance legislation. That working party which advised the Government had a major input into the legislation that is before us now. That is also another fact which may be, I concede, uncomfortable for the Opposition. Perhaps the criticism the Government has received for its decison to float the Australian dollar demonstrates the amount of support we have for that measure, which is about equal to the amount of support we have for this measure from the business community. I hope that the Opposition in this place will show confidence in this Government equal to what the business community has shown in supporting this legislation. I commend the legislation to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Prices Surveillance Bill 1983. The Bill seeks to establish a Prices Surveillance Authority, the charter of which will initially direct the Authority to provide prices surveillance over wholesale petroleum product pricing. In addition, we are advised by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in his second reading speech that major Commonwealth public authorities, where appropriate, will be subject to surveillance, whatever that may mean. 'Where appropriate' is just one of the matters on which we might have received some clarification from Senator Cook in his just completed contribution. We are still unsure what major public authorities the Government has in mind.

SPEECH.PARA: The Authority is further empowered under this Bill, subject to ministerial approval, to inquire and report on prices set by prescribed industries and corporations. There are no guidelines in the Bill. Certainly vague criteria are mentioned in the Minister's speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is one of the dangers.

—As Senator Watson says, that is one of the dangers. The criteria were outlined in Senator Cook's speech. But I think that when he made reference to the industries we could have expected some guidance as to what industries the Government has in mind to bring within these provisions. Unfortunately, that was not so. Basically it will be entirely up to the Minister's discretion as to when to interfere, a discretion that appears to be total. Like its predecessors, the Prices Justification Tribunal and the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority, the new Authority will have at its disposal only the threat of public exposure and the power of moral persuasion in seeking to hold down price rises in prescribed sectors of the economy. Financial penalties will principally apply only where prescribed industries and corporations fail to comply with the procedures set out for the notification of price changes or where prices are increased pending an inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of its intended structure and method of operation, it would appear that the Prices Surveillance Authority as set out in this Bill might turn out to be what some commentators have described as a toothless tiger. In fact, the Minister appeared to emphasise in his second reading speech that the Authority will indeed be benign. We are informed, for example, that the Government is concerned with prices surveillance and not price control. We are also told that although the Authority will be in the business of keeping watch on price movements in sensitive areas of economic activity, the disruption to corporations and industries will be kept to a minimum with price inquiries and required notification procedures being expeditious and not excessively legalistic.

Whilst such assurances may be soothing for those who fear price control, it raises the question of what the contribution of the Prices Surveillance Authority will be to the fundamental economic issues facing the Government. Will it make a contribution to the promotion of economic growth and prosperity? Will its presence help the task of providing increased employment opportunities? Will the operation of such an authority be supportive to improved private sector confidence? Will it have a positive role to play in ensuring adequate profit and investment levels? Will it serve any role in helping to facilitate the necessary structural adjustments which must be made within the economy so that Australia can better compete in world export markets? Will a prices surveillance authority help bring about an expansion in the small and medium business sectors, which hold the greatest potential as employment generators?

To all of those questions the answer is unfortunately no. Rather, the operation of this Authority will prove, on the face of the Bill and with the Minister's assurances, to be of little more than nuisance value to the private sector which has recently, of course, experience historically low profit levels and depressed investment activity. Why then introduce this benign animal? The answer, of course, is part payment for the privilege of having the prices and incomes accord-that much vaunted ticket to economic salvation. Although only 10 months old, the accord is already showing signs of proving a very dubious privilege. To date the accord has ensured that those lucky enough to have a job are to receive a wage increase of 4.3 per cent, and from now on they will be assured of wage rises every six months because of half-yearly indexation. Yet this 4.3 per cent is to be paid out by business which in 1983 is still trying to recover from the damage inflicted on its profit levels by the pay rounds of late 1981 and early 1982. But pay businesses must, because the accord is all important.

It would appear, in fact, that the accord has been so raised in status by this Government that it must be protected and nurtured irrespective of the long term costs to the nation. So, in order that the accord is adhered to, the trade union movement must have its long held penchant for price control satisfied. What this means was set out in the Australian Financial Review, in its editorial, on 2 December, when it observed that:

The union demand for prices control is stimulated by the desire to block price increases which tend to follow wage rises. It is, in other words, a demand for a mechanism to ratify and enforce transfer from business operating margins to real wages and to block any attempt by business to recover its cash flow position by subsequent increases in prices.

So we are to have a Prices Surveillance Authority not for reasons of sound economic management, let alone that such an authority could play a positive role in promoting economic growth. We are to have a Prices Surveillance Authority to satisfy the trade unions-in particular, the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It is a further abdication of the Government's national responsibility in favour of a sectional interest group. As the Minister says in his second reading speech :

The overwhelming majority of unions have undertaken to comply with the new wage indexation guidelines by undertaking to make no extra claims during the currency of the wage system. We are heartened by the development. However, there is also a need for a comparable supportive mechanism on the employers' side.

A comparable supportive mechanism on the employers' side means profit restraint. But profits have been shattered in recent years. What this Government and the unions, in the longer term best interests of their members, should be encouraging is profit recovery, because it is only with increased profitability that business will be able to maintain employment numbers and maintain real wages. Yet the unions and this Government, regrettably-the Government inexcusably-remain blinded to this obvious economic reality.

The real irony is that although this Bill is a sop to the unions, when the debate took place in the House of Representatives, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has said, the ACTU warned the Government that the accord was in danger of disintegration because of this Bill. While the Government has claimed that it is essential to set up a Prices Surveillance Authority in order to reinforce its 10-month-old agreement with the trade union movement, the trade unions said that it was not good enough. Following a meeting of the ACTU Executive, its President , Mr Dolan, said that his organisation was concerned with a number of aspects of the prices surveillance legislation. In general terms, he said that the Bill did not go far enough and that unless increased surveillance powers were given to the Authority, the ACTU would consider the Government as having failed to live up to its side of the accord.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—I am quoting from the report of Mr Dolan's Press conference.
—Why don't you quote from his telex, in which he said the reverse?
—Just be patient, Senator, and we will get to your explanation.
—You can believe what you read in a paper, but why don't you quote from the original document?

—This was reported by all the newspapers. I will give the honourable senator some quotations from the Australian and then from the Australian Financial Review. If he is serious in suggesting that all the newspapers misquoted Mr Dolan, he is fooling himself.
—Don't quote from newspapers; quote Mr Dolan himself.
—Ah! But that was the day after. The question is, what happened in the meantime?
—There is a telex here.
—What Mr Dolan said-and this was after the ACTU had reached its decisions; this was at his Press conference-was reported in the Australian on 8 December as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: We have carried a resolution in relation to the wages question and we would certainly need to reconsider that if we are going to be put into a position where the other side, the prices side of the accord, is not being properly adhered to or monitored . . .
Unless these questions are positively answered-
That is, questions relating to the surveillance powers of the Authority-
the ACTU will not accept the PSA as established as satisfying the basic conditions of the accord . . .
In the Australian Financial Review on the same day he is reported as saying--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you quote Mr Dolan?

—This is what Senator Cook's leader, the leader of the ACTU, said at his Press conference after the organisation had reached its decision. Senator Cook will be interested to know what was reported in the Australian Financial Review of the same day. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we're faced with legislation which is pretty useless . . .

Also it is reported that he said it would be wasting a trade union official's time to be on the Authority of the type proposed. This is what he said at the conclusion of the meeting of the ACTU, not the following day. It is not surprising that the unions are unhappy. The Bill pays only lip service to the principle of price control. One can have an economic strategy of wage and price control. It might not have a good record where it has been tried elsewhere but, nevertheless, it is a legitimate, economic strategy. But wage control and price surveillance is a nothing. It is a nonsense. It is the product of this strategy of consensus, not an economic strategy but a political strategy. It is a political strategy premised on the belief that if one keeps all people happy all of the time one ensures one's political survival. That is not the responsibility of government. By the following day, as we were reminded by Senator Cook, Mr Dolan had gone to water. The telex we have heard about was sent. It was almost in total conflict to what he said immediately after his Press conference. Whether he was, in the meantime, convinced that the Prices Surveillance Authority would not be a toothless tiger is interesting to surmise. Perhaps the considerable indirect influence that the Government will be able to bring over a particular enterprise should not be underestimated. Was this brought to the attention of Mr Dolan? The Minister, for whatever reason, can require the Authority to hold an inquiry. As Senator Cook knows, for the term of the inquiry that freezes the prices imposed by the party being inquired into. It is indicated in the Minister's speech that such inquiries hopefully will be limited to periods of less than three months but, as we all know, these things tend to continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —You got that bit right.

—Thank you. What that means, of course, is that the Minister's decision to refer can, in certain circumstances, be strategically destructive of the company concerned. Therefore, the mechanisms may appear ineffective as a general price control but in the mechanism there is considerable power to influence the conduct of individual businesses. Before Senator Cook tells me that it is possible under the proposed Act to obtain an interim price increase from the Authority, I suggest to him that that would, of course, be difficult because the Authority certainly would not think that political manipulation was involved. We would not like to think that a government would use the powers of this proposed Act to influence changes in, say, industrial relations areas. The problem is the lack of guidelines in this Bill. While that lack of guidelines exists there is the potential for abuse. That is of great concern to honourable senators on this side of the chamber. Whilst the Government plays at keeping the unions happy and whilst we speculate as to how Mr Dolan was placated, the major economic challenges languish. Those challenges-improving employment prospects for those out of work, the need to reduce further our rate of inflation to a level comparable to rates experienced by our trading partners, the necessity for the business sector to recover from the unacceptably low profits of recent years , the need for improved private sector confidence and with that confidence increased investment activity-are issues which this Government should be addressing. Little purpose is served in valuable time and energy being used up in pursuit of a workable price surveillance mechanism.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government is so concerned with price control and surveillance, it should practise what it preaches and look at its own increasing taxes and charges despite, of course, promises to the contrary which no doubt Senator Cook also remembers. In reducing taxes, this Government would be taking a real step towards increased profitability and all the benefits that flow therefrom without the same need for increased prices. But for this Government to dissipate its energies on setting up yet another bureaucracy which will serve no worthwhile purpose, not even adequately meet its internal debts to the ACTU, is further evidence of its abdication of economic responsibility. This Bill is a disappointment to those genuinely interested in economic recovery. It will make no real contribution to that goal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was disappointed with the tenor of the speech that has just been made by Senator Hill because I felt that here was something on which all parties would have agreement; that this was the second part of a deal which gained the support of all segments of the National Economic Summit Conference. I do not know whether it is being suggested that only one side of the deal be implemented by the Government or whether in some way the Government renege on this promise and allow the wage earners of Australia to be under constraint with absolutely no constraints or restraints on the profitability or productive side of Australian commerce and industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It has not been an easy existence but we have lived with the Prices Justification Tribunal with all of its faults. It at least gave some sort of semblance of balance towards the constraints on wages. When the wage freeze was introduced, in my opinion the sole reason that it was accepted was that some prices control mechanism was in operation at the time. This country would have exploded if there had not been some sort of control on prices, particularly in the vital area of petrol pricing. To suggest that the PJT and the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority go out the window and that nothing take their place would, I think, lead to anarchy.

One thing that concerns me, and I think it concerns many Australians, is that the arguments that we have heard pro and con have been pro and con wage earners and pro and con business. I just wonder whether anybody is concerned with the third element in this equation, that is, the consumers-not just the consumers at the retail end but the consumers in small businesses. One thing that is not covered adequately with this legislation is the potential for large businesses to be ignored as a result of having done a sweetheart deal with the Government. A classic illustration of this may well be the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, which undoubtedly controls the steel industry in this country, with or without the Government's approval. As a result of that it has an absolute stranglehold on the consumers of steel in this country. Under the legislation as it exists at the moment, if the government makes this sweetheart arrangement with BHP the consumers-be they buyers of refrigerators, bicycles or anything to go into a home, or be they small businesses such as engineering firms, the manufacturers of products that use steel-will have absolutely no redress because the only place to which they can appeal under the legislation is to the Treasurer. Of course the Treasurer is party to the sweetheart deal so there is no way that they will persuade him to reverse his decision, thus ensuring that the sweetheart deal with BHP holds fast. This is of great concern to me, to the Australian Democrats and, I suspect, to a lot of people, particularly those in small businesses who have no right of appeal, no alternative approach, because the only referral point in this legislation comes from the Treasurer. That is the big danger in the legislation.

I will speak briefly about the major differences between the Prices Justification Tribunal which is being abandoned and the Prices Surveillance Authority, which is the new authority being set up to look after the interests of those who could suffer from monopolies or from pricing which is not considered fair or just. The Prices Justification Tribunal had specific criteria on its target; that was any business or any industry with greater than a $30m turnover. The Prices Justification Tribunal was encouraged to examine industries rather than individuals. The Prices Surveillance Authority has general criteria which do not drag in large numbers of companies but can target key companies and key areas. In fact it will be encouraged to examine areas in which there is little competition. It will be looking at monopolistic or oligopolistic industries and organisations. The scope of the PJT did not cover statutory bodies. I am delighted to see that Commonwealth Government statutory bodies will be covered. The PJT did not cover partnerships or co-operatives. Eventually, however, it included imported goods and services. Regrettably, because of our Constitution, there will be nothing that this new Authority can do to look at State authorities, statutory bodies which come under the aegis of State governments.

I think is is fair to criticise the approach of the PJT. It initially squeezed profit margins at a time when profits were desperately needed in some areas for survival and recovery. I understand that, at one stage, former Prime Minister Whitlam intervened to lessen that squeeze. Nevertheless, there was that emphasis and it had a deleterious effect. The Prices Surveillance Authority will give regard to profitability, to investment and to employment. That is part of the guidelines written into this legislation. That is desirable. Profit is not a dirty word. Profitability is absolutely vital for the survival of the enterprise and for the continuity of jobs.

There are some similarities between the old Prices Justification Tribunal and this new Prices Surveillance Authority. I think that is probably because they start with the same massive handicap, which is that neither of them has the constitutional power to absolutely control prices or to penalise businesses. That power is denied this Government. The only power left is the power of odious publicity and the force of public opinion. I believe that that may well prove to be an adequate power. It depends on how enthusiastically the Treasurer and the media grasp the inequities which occur and which are drawn to the public's attention by the Prices Surveillance Authority. I think that the climate is ripe for the media to take some cognisance of the arrangement or accord, which was reached at the National Economic Summit Conference between all parties, that there should be a degree of control over both wages and prices.

The media will be endeavouring to keep all parties honest. They are working hard at keeping the wage earners honest and ensuring that there is no effective blowout of wages which would destroy the accord, and I think they will do the right thing on the other side of the ledger to try to keep the prices down as far as possible without interfering with the survival and base profitability of companies.

The other bases which may be different include the primary objective of each of these two bodies. I think it is fair to suggest that the major aim of the Prices Justification Tribunal was to restrain inflation. It was put in quite deliberately to hold down inflationary trends; to stop the blowout. Unfortunately it operated as a rather lonely instrument and not as part of a co- ordinated process; nevertheless, it was a reasonably effective instrument in holding down inflation to a degree.

This Prices Surveillance Authority does not have such an objective. It has a different aim; that is, to maintain the accord. It provides the second and complementary half of the process to balance wages restraint. I believe that the 15 million Australians out in the public arena, who are all very interested and concerned and certainly who will be affected by the public debate that took place at the National Economic Summit Conference, applauded the accord which was reached. So this legislation is absolutely vital to maintain that accord, and in turn that accord is vital to this country's economic survival and recovery.

I suppose it would be possible to achieve a form of economic recovery with draconian legislative measures. I do not categorise this Bill in that way. I do not believe that it is draconian. I believe that it is modest and, in fact, that it may be too moderate in its approach. The Australian Democrats have distributed an amendment to add to the powers of the Authority itself so that there is an additional channel of referrals rather than solely via the Treasurer .

I believe that the new authority will be good for Australia, that it will contribute to the maintenance of the accord and that it will provide a forum for the presentation of attitudes by various parties on what is happening in the prices area and, as a result, will act as a safe sounding board for the views, for the plans, for the disparate points of view of what is happening on that side of the formula for accord. I believe also that the Government probably sees it as a method by which it can influence, and to a degree direct, the business community of this country.

I therefore on behalf of the Australian Democrats applaud the Government for introducing the Bill. I ask the Government to accept the amendment we will be moving in the Committee stage which will provide for the Prices Surveillance Authority to take into itself matters for consideration without the necessity of having those matters referred to it by the Treasurer who, under the legislation as it exists at the moment, is the only possible referral authority. Given that modification, this legislation, once passed by this Parliament, will achieve the purposes which the Government has set for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Prices Surveillance Bill 1983. I am well reminded that, in 1973, the Whitlam Government introduced a prices justification tribunal as part of its prices and incomes policy in an attempt to control inflation. During those years, the Australian economy suffered historically high inflation rates. The 1974 inflation rate reached a record 16.9 per cent. Not only did the Prices Justification Tribunal fail in its stated objective but also undoubtedly it contributed to the gloomy economic climate that dried up investment in those years. This Government, by its attempt to introduce the Prices Surveillance Authority, wishes to repeat that disastrous experiment. It is quite clear that the Government's motive in doing so has little to do with economics; rather, it is a transparent attempt to buy the goodwill of the trade unions. If the strike record under the last Labor Government is anything to go by, there is no evidence to suggest that that attempt will succeed.

SPEECH.PARA: In introducing the Bill, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, announced:

The Government is firmly committed to restoring economic prosperity in Australia and bringing about the sustained high rates of economic growth that are necessary to reduce the present high levels of unemployment.

Yet the very prerequisite of high levels of economic growth is investment. People will not invest in business enterprises unless they receive a rate of return to compensate them for the risks they are taking. Whether a business can offer them an attractive return on their investment in turn depends upon its level of profitability. Company profits as a share of the gross domestic product have been steadily declining since 1970. In the financial year 1969-70, company profits represented 15.4 per cent of the gross domestic product. By the end of the last financial year, they had sunk to only 10.4 per cent of the gross domestic product. If anyone has any doubt where company profits have gone, they need only look at the share of the gross domestic product taken up by wages. In the financial year 1969-70, wages accounted for 52.6 per cent of the gross domestic product. The decline in profits is almost directly matched by the increase in wages. Their share of the gross domestic product in 1982-83 has risen by 4.2 per cent to 56.8 per cent. In the words of the Australian Industries Development Association; 'Wages growth has ripped into corporate returns'. When profits slide, so does investment. That is why we now have unemployment running at a rate in excess of 10 per cent.
