The loss of investment means that businesses are not only unable to expand and to create new jobs, but also forced to cut back their labour force and in some cases close down altogether. This Government has now proposed to tackle the problem by introducing a prices control body while leaving control of wages dependent upon the goodwill of the unions, a move which no doubt can only further reduce profitability. The Treasurer has told us that compliance with the decisions of the Prices Surveillance Authority will be voluntary. Its role will be one of price monitoring rather than price control. This may well be the Government's intent, but in practice under the proposals of this Bill the Authority will have the means to cause firms wishing to raise prices a great deal of inconvenience, to say the least, and make it very hard for a company not to abide by its decision.

The Authority will have the power to declare any supplier of goods and services subject to the Act. Once so declared, a supplier must notify the Authority of its intention to raise a price. Failure to do so will incur a penalty of $10,000 . If the Authority objects to the price increase, it may choose to hold an inquiry. During the inquiry, the Authority may require a company to freeze the price in question. Again, if the company does not comply with the requirement it will be penalised with a penalty of $10,000. Although the Treasurer said that inquiries will generally last no longer than three months, there is no time limit incorporated in the legislation. Therefore the Authority will have the power to impose what will amount to a fine on a company by forcing it to freeze the price in question. Even if the inquiry finds that the price increase was justified there will be no recompense for the firm's loss of revenue during the inquiry.

If the Authority finds that the price increase is not justified in its opinion it will be very difficult for a firm to ignore that decision. All the results of the Authority's work are to be made public and if a firm considered it necessary to increase a price despite an unfavourable decision by the Authority, it would have to contend not only with the weight of public opinion but also very likely it would have to face a threat of industrial action by unions who may come to see their role as the Authority's enforcement agency.
How then is the Authority to decide what constitutes a justified price increase ? The Bill sets out some loose guidelines on this matter. These include:
The need to maintain investment and employment including the influence of profitability upon investment and employment.

Yet we have already seen that profitability is at historically low levels. Investment will not increase until firms are allowed to recapture some of the ground they have lost over the last decade. Maintaining present levels of profit will simply ensure that we also maintain present unemployment rates. Furthermore , the Authority may require companies to prove that investment income could not be obtained from other sources, such as share issues, as did the previous Prices Justification Tribunal, thereby interfering in company management decisions where it has no qualifications to do so. The Authority will effectively be in a position to decide what the level of a firm's profitability will be. Its decisions will therefore have far-reaching effects on the long term resource allocation in the economy-a matter best left to the free market to decide, not a government bureaucracy whose decisions will inevitably be politically rather than economically dictated. Undoubtedly it will concentrate its energies on prices that are to be included in the consumer price index.

Of course, there are innumerable problems in deciding what constitutes a fair price and what level of profits a firm should be allowed to earn. How will the Authority judge factors such as varying degrees of managerial efficiency or the value of old assets? If a firm is able to cut costs by investing in new equipment, will it be allowed to reap the benefits of its investment? This Bill does not even attempt to begin to answer those questions. But one thing is certain, the very existence of such an Authority will create anxiety and uncertainty in the business community, and that alone will discourage investment .

Mr Acting Deputy President, I now turn to what I believe to be perhaps the worst aspect of this Bill, and that is that it demonstrates this Government's commitment to a totally one-sided prices and incomes policy. Firms are to have their prices surveyed by a statutory body but the only restraint upon wages is the Government's statement of accord with the trade unions which relies on their co-operation for its continuity. As I have already mentioned, such co-operation was far from forthcoming under the last Labor Government. During 1974 alone in excess of six million man-days were lost because of industrial disputes. That figure is almost three times higher than that of 1982 when two million man-days were lost due to industrial disputes.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going on with all of this gobbledegook for?

—Well, it is terribly relevant because I put it to Senator Button, with respect, that what the Government is doing now is repeating history. I am sure the Australian Labor Party is not about to learn from the facts of the past, to enlighten it for the future, but it is worth recording in the vain hope that there may be sombody listening who has the slightest concern for historic facts. Even under the terms of the accord unions will be allowed substantial wage increases. The Government agreed to protect the purchasing power of wages with full cost of living indexation. It has agreed that over- award payments will be maintained. It has said that unions will be allowed to bargain for shorter hours and pay increases in line with productivity increases, the only proviso being that the conditions so obtained are not in excess of community standards. In fact the only wage increase that is not allowed would seem to be an outright demand for more money, which is not offset by any increase in productivity. Where then do we find the legislative provision to prevent such wage claims? It is found in this Bill now before us which states in clause 17 (3):

SPEECH.PARA: In exercising its powers and performing its functions under this Act, the Authority shall . . . have particular regard to-
(c) the need to discourage cost increases arising from increases in wages and changes in conditions of employment inconsistent with principles established by relevant industrial tribunals.

This in effect will mean that if a union has sufficient industrial muscle to achieve a pay rise outside the accord the company involved will not be allowed to pass on the cost of the pay rise to the consumer in the form of increased prices. Mr Keating himself was obviously aware of the possibility of such a situation arising when in his second reading speech he stated:

. . . where a company has clearly and strongly resisted attempts at breaching the wage system, it should not be subject to a second possible penalty, and in these circumstances it is not intended that the Authority disallow cost increases.

It is not made clear, however, what the Authority will choose to regard as ' strong resistance'. It is left for the companies to toss up whether they would lose more money through a prolonged strike or by absorbing the cost of a wage increase themselves.

Already wages are protected by being linked to the cost of living index. There is nothing to stop wages outside the accord being demanded and such claims being backed by industrial action. Wages will be able to rise beyond the consumer price index and productivity agreements. Profits, on the other hand, will be strictly controlled through the operation of the Prices Surveillance Authority. The only increase that they will be allowed in real terms will be through the share of productivity increases that companies are allowed to retain. This will do nothing to redress the imbalance that now exists between the share of gross domestic product being directed towards wages and the share going to profits.

As I have already explained, the nexus between company profitability and the rate of unemployment is graphically illustrated by looking at the experience under the Whitlam Government which allowed a wage explosion while imposing controls on prices. Between 1973 and 1975 company profits fell by 2.7 per cent. In those same two years wages increased their share of the gross domestic product by 5 per cent. Unemployment in 1975 reached almost 5 per cent and continued to rise. Since that time, the only year that recorded a slight fall in the unemployment rate was 1980-81, the same year that saw a slight increase in company profitability.

Mr Keating has told us that inflationary pressures need to be reduced. However, experience in the Australian economy and the economies of comparable countries has shown that there is a direct correlation between wages growth and inflation. If we once more look back to the 1970s we can see that in 1975, when the average weekly wage rose by an enormous 25 per cent, inflation reached the historically high level of 16.9 per cent. Turning to overseas countries, during 1982 the United Kingdom had an inflation rate of 5.4 per cent and a wages growth of 5.4 per cent. Japan had an inflation rate of 1.8 per cent. Last year the wages growth in that country was 3.9 per cent. In the United States of America, inflation during 1982 was running at around 3.9 per cent and wages increased by 5.1 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the old chicken and the egg argument.

—With respect, it may be a chicken and egg argument to the honourable senator. But I think the honourable senator will agree that if we get wage demands down we will be able to get both inflation and interest rates down. In Australia, by comparison, wages increased by 14.5 per cent and the inflation rate was 10.7 per cent. As long as the Government allows wages to rise by linking them to the consumer price index and by allowing improvements in conditions such as shorter hours, all of which will have the effect of maintaining real wages; inflationary pressures will be built into the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: While our competitors on the international markets are having success in moderating wage growth and achieving lower inflation rates, inflation in Australia remains high and is now at a rate more than twice that of our major trading partners. As the 1982-83 Budget statement put it:
At present the Australian economy is not well positioned to improve its share of world trade.

The same statement saw one of the main risks to sustained recovery in the Australian economy as the rate of inflation. The Treasury also pointed out what it regarded as the central factor in reducing inflation-wage restraint. Again I quote from the Government's Budget statement:

The severity of the declines in both profitability and employment and the associated rise in unemployment during the downturn suggest that labour cost moderation must play a key role in any sustained reduction in inflation and any sustained improvement in competitiveness and in profitability investment and employment.

Yet this Government was relying on the co-operation of the unions to restrain wages whilst attempting to introduce a statutory price control body. Although it is calling for a Prices Surveillance Authority its effect will be to control prices and this can only have the effect of further damaging company profitability. There can be no justification on economic grounds for the introduction of a Prices Surveillance Authority. The complexities of pricing decisions alone will make it inevitable that such a body will make some bad decisions and, in doing so, will unfairly discriminate against some firms.

It has been estimated-I suspect by the Treasurer-that the yearly cost of such an authority will amount to something like $1.5m. Of course, that does not take into account the cost to firms of complying with its requirements and the diversion of company executives from their normal productive jobs into obeying notification procedures and dealing with inquiries. The effect of such a body on the economy will surely be to discourage investment and a further decline in company profitability and thus place at risk any recovery in the economy. The only way to ensure economic growth in my view is by encouraging investment. The last thing the economy needs is another government agency which will have exactly the opposite effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. I have not heard all the debate, anyway. Like Senator Jack Evans, I was a little disappointed with Senator Hill's contribution to the debate as Senator Hill is one of those few members on the Opposition side who, in my view, seriously address their minds to matters of national significance. I think his speech could be summed up as being critical on the grounds that the Prices Surveillance Authority was just a bit of window dressing or, if you like, appeasement for the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Even if that were correct-I do not accept that it is correct-I submit that that is not an unworthy object in itself. If the experience from around the world over the last decade is worth anything it should have taught us that the countries that have maintained satisfactory rates of economic growth, high enough to keep unemployment at low levels and low rates of inflation, are those countries in which there is a social consensus on prices and incomes. Even if Senator Hill's rather cynical assessment of this Authority and the Prices Surveillance Bill were correct, if it achieves that objective it is very worth while.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne, in somewhat more strident terms, attempted to make the same point. He said that this was an attempt to buy the goodwill of the ACTU. The same comments that I have made with respect to Senator Hill I think are relevant to Senator Crichton-Browne. But beyond that, Senator Crichton-Browne, of course, has been a prominent figure in the Western Australian Liberal Party for some time. I have been told-I find the story quite credible-that it is Senator Crichton-Browne's ambition to transform the Western Australian Liberal Party into a western version of the Queensland National Party. In one sense that has been achieved in that they both get about 39 per cent of the vote. The Western Australian Liberal Party used to get a percentage of the vote between the mid and high forties until it fell under the influence of people such as Senator Crichton-Browne. It is now down to the level of the National Party in Queensland; that is, a percentage level in the thirties instead of the forties. I do not think I need to say very much more about Senator Crichton-Browne or how the political views that he espouses are received in Western Australia.

I should indicate now that the amendments which have been foreshadowed by the Australian Democrats, which I think will be moved by Senator Evans, are not acceptable to the Government, insofar as they provide in our view, for an abdication or a surrender of government authority to a non-elected body. The view of the Government is that that is not a course of action with which we can concur. Therefore the Government will oppose Senator Evans's amendment. I understand that the Bill, with or without Senator Evans's amendment, will be passed by the Senate. I do not intend to delay the passage of the Bill any further.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 9, sub-section 17 (2), line 30, leave out '', with the approval of the Minister under section 18,''.
(2) Page 9, after sub-section 17 (2), insert the following new sub-section:

''(2A) The Authority may, where it considers it appropriate to do so, hold an inquiry into and submit a report on whether the price at which a person who supplies or proposes to supply goods or services which are declared to be notified goods or services under paragraph 21 (1) (a) is justified and if the authority is of the opinion that the price is nor justified, what lower price for the supply by that person of goods and services of that description would be justified.''.
(3) Page 10, paragraph 18 (1) (b), line 9, leave out the paragraph.
(4) Page 10, after sub-section 18 (1), insert the following new sub-sections:
''(1A) Where the Authority has given notice under paragraph 19 (1) (a) that it is to hold an inquiry under sub-section 17 (2A), the Minister may, by instrument in writing delivered to the Chairman-
(a) direct that the authority shall not proceed with that inquiry; or
(b) vary the terms of any such inquiry.
''(1B) Where an instrument is issued under sub-section (1A), the Minister shall -
(a) cause that instrument and the reasons for the decisions contained therein to be published in the Gazette; and
(b) give to any person or persons whose interests are directly affected by the decision notification in writing of the making of the decision.''.
(5) Page 11, sub-section 21 ()1, line 31, leave out ''with the approval of the Minister''.
(6) Page 11, sub-section 21 (2), line 40, leave out ''with the approval of the Minister''.

A lot of people will be disappointed at the last couple of sentences uttered by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) on behalf of the Government because his suggestion that these amendments provide for the abdication of responsibility by the Government runs counter to practically everything it has said up to this point. The Government has stressed since it came into power that it is trying to govern this country with consensus, with general accord across the community, and with input from the community at large. The Minister then said that to allow that sort of input into the Prices Surveillance Authority, which is about to be given the power to review prices in Australia, would be an abdication of responsibility. I find it very difficult to accept that statement.

I will quickly run through the one major shortcoming of this piece of legislation, that is, that consumers are ignored. With great respect, there has been very little recognition by this Government to date of the needs, of the desperate plight, of many consumers in this country. I do not know whether Government members are out in the market-place or at the food shops having a look at what is happening to prices, but if they have not done any shopping recently they should talk to their spouses. They would find out that prices are still sky-rocketing. Many consumer goods, apart from groceries, are going up at a very rapid rate despite a wage pause and a minimal wage increase as perceived by the unions. This is being exacerbated by massive increases in government charges.

All I am suggesting to the Government is that the people of Australia, seeing the Prices Surveillance Authority come into being, want to have some opportunity to go beyond the Government, beyond the responsible Minister, the Treasurer, and have some access to this Authority to register their complaints. That is all that these amendments do. They simply give to the Prices Surveillance Authority the same power that has been held, I remind the Minister, by the Prices Justification Tribunal since its inception. In case the Minister is unaware of it, section 16 of the Prices Justification Act 1973 states:
The functions of the Tribunal are to inquire and report to the Minister, in any case where the Tribunal is required to do so by the Minister-
that is the same as the provision in the Prices Surveillance Bill-
or the Tribunal considers that it is desirable to do so . . .
It has the power of self-referral.

All we are asking the Government to do is to give this new body the same power that the PJT had. That power, which would still be subject to veto by the Treasurer, would give the consumer, whether at the manufacturing level or the retail level, access to make representations to the Authority and to have those representations investigated by the Authority if it sees fit and if the Treasurer does not veto the referral. Under this amendment, if the Treasurer took it upon himself to veto the self-referral he would have to publish his reasons in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. Of course, that would make him maintain his honesty in the light of the publicity that he would get in the same way that the people who are manipulating prices will have to maintain their honesty as the result of the publicity which will be given to them if they misbehaved. That is all we are asking the Government to do. I appeal once more to the Minister to reconsider the Government's position and to allow this opportunity for self-referral so that the Authority will look after the interests of all parties, not just the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the employer groups but also those consumers who so frequently are ignored when it comes to making decisions which affect consumers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be supporting the amendments moved by the Australian Democrats. They would have the effect of freeing the proposed Prices Surveillance Authority from the need to obtain the approval of the Minister. In the Opposition's opinion that would not be a wise course to take. Senator Evans made some comment with regard to the Prices Justification Tribunal. I remind him that experience with the Prices Justification Tribunal led the previous Government, of which I was a member, to amend the Prices Justification Act in 1979 to provide that the Tribunal would conduct prices justification inquiries only at the direction of and with the approval of the Minister. The amendments would all have the same effect: This Authority would become a body that could have referrals without the approval or the direction of the Minister. The Opposition believes that would not be a wise course to take. Senator Evans described the matters that he thought could be referred to it under his proposed amendments. I am left with some horror at the thought of the effect on economic recovery if we had a body of the nature which he has just described. For those reasons there will be no support from the Opposition for Senator Evans's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to suggest that the Government would go to the barricades, so to speak, on the question that Senator Evans has raised. On balance, the Government's view was that it would be better if the proposal he has put forward was not accepted. I draw his attention--
—Can you give us an undertaking that it was considered in depth?

—The decision was made primarily by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and not by me. It is his Bill, but I certainly consulted with him about it. The point to which I draw attention is that the Authority, even without the amendment, has the power to initiate an inquiry provided the Treasurer's approval is secured. It is not bereft of any capacity to initiate inquiries. Senator Evans said correctly that in a much more formal and heavy-handed way the Treasurer could still quash an inquiry initiated by the Authority at a later stage. The Government's view is that it would, on balance, be more satisfactory if the Authority operates in the way in which the Bill provides; that is, that it can initiate inquiries; it can make suggestions to the Treasurer and, providing the Treasurer's approval is secured at that early stage, it can proceed with those inquiries. The amendments proposed by Senator Jack Evans on behalf of the Australian Democrats would provide for the inquiry to be initiated , and if the Treasurer believed that that was not compatible with the broad objectives of Government policy, require him to take much more heavy-handed action at a later stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a statement. I wish to put the record right.
—You do not have leave yet. What do you want to do?
—I have not been misrepresented but I wish to make a statement in response to some lies that were told by Senator Walsh a moment ago.
—To start with, Senator, you cannot use those words.
—I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne, before you start I am not sure whether the words that you used in reference to Senator Walsh are in the record, but I suggest that you withdraw them.

—I withdraw them, Mr Acting Deputy President. I sought leave in order to put right what was inaccurately put by Senator Walsh. Senator Walsh said, as I understand it-unfortunately, I do not take notice of what he says; it was only by accident that his remarks came wafting past my ears-that since I had taken control of the Liberal Party in Western Australia it had lost its traditional vote of 48 per cent, or whatever he said it was, that its vote was now down to 39 per cent and that that was as a result of my influence. I wish to put the record right. During the period that I was State President of the Liberal Party of Western Australia and had some modest influence on its direction, function and philosophical approach towards policy it had, on each occasion a Federal or State election was held, the highest vote ever recorded in that State. I further add--
—It took them a while to wake up to you. Do not get too cheeky or I will table a few more cheques.

—Senator Walsh says that if I get too cheeky he will table a few more cheques. I do not to want shock Senator Walsh but I have a couple of cheques that will entirely embarrass his Government very shortly. I intend not only to table them but also to have the Australian Federal Police investigate them, so Senator Walsh should stop blushing.
—More of your Christo Moll cheques?

—They are Christo Moll cheques, yes, and they will greatly embarrass your Government and cause the same problems to other people that have been caused by one of your colleagues so far. So you be very careful, my friend.
— Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, you should address your remarks through the Chair and confine your remarks to the area in which you say you have been misrepresented.

—I can understand why Senator Walsh needs your protection, Mr Acting Deputy President, and why I am to ignore his continuous pathetic, inaccurate interjections. To add to what I was saying previously, on the occasion I was elected to No. 3 on the Senate ticket Western Australia was the only State in Australia to elect three Liberal senators. I do not for a moment claim that to be a reflection on my capacity or my competence, but it is a reflection on the judgment of the people of Western Australia. I conclude by saying that on that occasion I was the only Liberal in Australia elected from No . 3 on the Senate ticket. Senator Walsh headed the Australian Labor Party ticket in Western Australia, and his Party had the worst vote in its history.

—by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation to correct an error which was made in the last sentence Senator Crichton-Browne uttered. He was a candidate for the Senate election in 1980. I was not a candidate for the Senate election in 1980. His assertions about that matter are about as reliable as his assertions about everything else.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 November 1983, on motion by Senator Ryan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Opposition will not oppose the second reading of the Postal and Telecommunications Amendment Bill but it has some amendments which it will pursue in the Committee stage. Postal services developed in Australia on a State by State basis until 1 March 1901 when the administration of all postal and telegraphic services passed to the Commonwealth . Amalgamation was found to be difficult, and the first royal commission into Australia's postal and telegraphic services was set up in 1908. There was a further committee of inquiry in 1961, and in 1974 the Vernon report was brought down. We then had the vesting of the two arms of the postal and telecommunications services-the formation of Australia Post and Telecom Australia in 1975. From that time on Australia Post has been out on its own.

SPEECH.PARA: It started as a very poor cousin of Telecom and developed to its present stage. On vesting day it was told that it owed a notional sum of $100m to the Commonwealth. To its credit, it has paid back a large amount of that sum and currently owes $39.9m to the Commonwealth. On top of that, Australia Post does not rely on money from the taxpayers to pay its way. This has not been done easily. There was quite a deal of trouble in regard to raising postal rates and curtailing services in order to stand on its own feet. That matter has worried me particularly in regard to Queensland-undoubtedly it was a problem in a lot of rural areas in other States when the shift of population to the cities meant that daily postal services were cut back to weekly and sometimes fortnightly services. I commend Australia Post. It has tried to get back to two weekly services. Once again it is trying to meet its obligation to provide services throughout Australia.

In 1982 the report of the Bradley Committee of Inquiry into the Monopoly Position of the Australian Postal Commission was brought down. This legislation is basically the result of the new Government coming to grips with the Bradly report and implementing some of its recommendations. As I will mention in the Committee stage, the Opposition believes that more of the recommendations should have been implemented and more notice should have been taken of them. Most of the committees of inquiry and royal commissions into Australia Post have examined the monopoly provisions governing its operation and I think there would be a broad agreement that it is entitled to them. If we expect it to provide mail services to all of Australia, including those parts that cannot be economically served, and can never be really, it is only fair that it should have an exclusive right to the services that are profitable. This allows cross- subsidisation so that, overall, it is able to meet all of its expenses and does not cost the taxpayer anything.

I repeat, all the committees of inquiry, including the Bradley inquiry, have considered the monopoly provisions. The legislation retains them. It seeks also to restore the courier service, about which I will be speaking at the Committee stage. Moreover, it gives Australia Post the power to operate electronic mail services and to enter into agency agreements with the private sector. I think that is a first. Australia Post has always had the power to enter into agency agreements with the public sector. As an example, we all know that for many years, wherever there was a post office one found an agency of the Commonwealth Savings Bank. Non-official post offices, of course, are allowed to operate such agencies as well. The Opposition will not oppose the second reading of the Bill but will move certain amendments at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Collard on his speech, which I feel encapsulated the essential points of the Opposition' s criticism of this legislation and, in passing, offered some thoughtful observations. The Government's view is largely as was expressed in the second reading speech and I need not add very much in that regard. The authorities in question have been through a long process of inquiry, from which much public discussion has arisen. The Government is concerned that some of the decisions arrived at as a result should be implemented as quickly as possible. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 and 2-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 3 to 5-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move the first three Opposition amendments together, Mr Temporary Chairman. If we handle them together it will save time. They all deal with the same subject.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, paragraph 3 (a), lines 4 and 5, leave out '', by courier service''.
(2) Page 2, paragraph 3 (b), definition of ''postal article'', paragraph (b), line 10, leave out the paragraph.
(3) Page 2, clause 5, proposed new section 10, lines 20 to 38, leave out the proposed section.

The Opposition opposes granting to the Australian Postal Commission the rights to a courier system, not that we want to see Australia Post not operate a courier system, providing it operates on a fair and equal basis with the rest of the community. I refer to page 27 of the Bradley report of the Committee of Inquiry into the Monopoly Position of the Australian Postal Commission. The last sentence of paragraph 4.2.4, referring to this courier service, states:

It is important, however, that in providing any competitive services the Commission should not have unfair advantage over its private sector competitors, and the Committee had careful regard to this consideration when developing recommendations for change to existing statutory provisions under which the Commission operates . . .
Mr Bradley then refers to chapter 6. On page 66, in paragraph 6.9.2, points (a) and (b), he states:
(a) that the Australian Postal Commission should include each year in its Annual Report separate accounts for:
the standard article service;
all other services . . .

(b) that the Australian Postal Commission should aim each year to achieve a trading surplus which would permit the payment after interest and income tax of a return on total assets employed in the provision of:
the standard article service;
all other services . . .

We believe that if Australia Post is to operate a courier service it should have the same restrictions, for want of a better term, as any other business which is operating-that is, it should have to provide a return on assets and to provide for the payment of tax. I think it would be acknowledged that Australia Post is operating under a fairly beneficial superannuation scheme which private operators cannot match. For those reasons I have moved the three amendments. We are basically opposing the courier service for the reasons I have outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats cannot support any of the amendments now moved or foreshadowed by the Opposition. Essentially we agree with the reasons given by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) in the House of Representatives debate on the Postal and Telecommunications Amendment Bill. The amendments moved and to be moved by the Opposition in the Senate, as I understand it, are identical to the amendments moved in the House of Representatives. We could well have a fascinating, interesting and long debate on those amendments and the reasons for them. I just wonder whether, at this time of year and with the condition in which the Committee finds itself, that would be appropriate. All I say is that the Democrats have carefully studied the arguments put forward by Mr Lloyd, the Opposition spokesman for communications in the House of Representatives, and the replies of the Minister, Mr Duffy, and we concur with the Government's view on these amendments. Therefore, we will not be able to support the Opposition's amendments on this or the other matters raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is not disposed to accept the amendments moved by Senator Collard. He raised one or two arguments about the operations of the Australian Postal Commission in support of the amendments which, in a sense, could have been canvassed in a much wider way. Senator Collard did not do that. Australia Post has certain advantages in terms of its competitive position with other organisations. It has certain other massive disadvantages too in terms of cross-subsidisation of its activities and things of that kind. As to the courier service specifically, Australia Post will be required to maintain accounting records of all revenue and expenditure items attributable to the courier service in order that its financial viability, standing on its own, as it were, may be monitored. This was done to some degree on a previous occasion when the courier service operated. However, it is being restored on the basis that it will be expected to pay its way and to make a positive return on its operations. It will not be cross-subsidised. If it does make a profitable return on its operations it ought to be highly welcomed by all concerned because it extends the capacity of the organisation generally in its financial arrangements to cross-subsidise where necessary. Those reasons have been advanced in greater detail in the House of Representatives, but I think that they represent a summation of why the Government will not accept these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Clauses agreed to.
Clause 6 (Commission may act as agent, et cetera).

TALK.START.PARA: — The Opposition opposes clause 6. Very briefly this clause allows Australia Post to take on agencies. We believe that if Australia Post has the time to take on agencies other than public agencies it is getting into a field which is not in its area of responsibility. That means it has a little fat that it should be able to pare off to help keep our postal charges at a reasonable level. For that very simple reason we are opposed to Australia Post branching out into agencies in the private sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats cannot agree that this clause should be opposed. We are disappointed in the reasons advanced by the Opposition for opposing it. We would commend a Public Service department for being aggressive, getting into the market-place and keeping the private sector honest. This is a tremendous advance in thinking on behalf of the Government. If I were a member of the Opposition, and particularly a member of the National Party of Australia, I would be concerned about this scenario, and I would like the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) to respond: A country town, not too big and not too small, has a post office which has an officer whose salary is paid by the Commonwealth. He is a public servant. In the same town a person runs the haberdashery shop, the newsagency, the hardware shop or whatever. There are thousands of towns like this around Australia. He supplements his income by agencies.

SPEECH.PARA: I will refer to two private companies in the insurance industry, say, the Australian Mutual Provident Society and the Norwich Union Life Insurance Society . Let us assume that this mythical town which I describe has a post office and Australia Post decides to enter into arrangements with a private principal. The private principal may be the AMP Society. It says to Australia Post: 'We would like to make an arrangement with you to extend the number of agencies of the AMP Society in Australia by using the post offices in country towns as our agents'. I think that that is terrific. It is good for the post office; it is good for taxpayers; it is good for Consolidated Revenue; it is good for private enterprise and the AMP Society. In that country town the person who runs the small real estate agency and who has the agency for the Norwich Union insurance company is immediately disadvantaged because everybody goes to the post office once a week, twice a week or whatever. They do not necessarily go into the real estate agency which has the Norwich Union agency. I mention that in passing, being a champion of private enterprise and, indeed, of small business.

I believe that this problem will level itself out. Some persons who own small real estate agencies or whatever in small country towns would be temporarily disadvantaged, but I believe that in the long run the national interest would be served in that Australia Post would have greater utilisation of its resources. Public revenue would be increased and private enterprise would be encouraged. So , while I sympathise with the thrust of the Opposition's proposal, I believe that it is argued for the wrong reasons. Therefore, the Australian Democrats cannot support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposal mentioned by Senator Collard is not acceptable to the Government. Senator Chipp asked me to respond to his view on why it should not be acceptable to the Government. His view, as I apprehend it and summarise it, is that in many country towns, for example, it might be desirable for Australia Post to provide agency services because, in a sense, they would be delivering services which might not otherwise be there. I just add that I think that in many communities a post office can become a very useful social focal point and that this process would encourage that. The other point that I think is important in terms of efficiency is that post offices by their very nature have to be staffed on the basis of the peaks of their business activity and their work in the provision of postal services. There are sometimes dead times, as it were, where, from the point of view of efficiency and the proper use of time, agency services can be provided, which are of benefit to the public and which are not to the detriment of Australia Post as an organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The sorts of agency services which Senator Chipp mentioned such as insurance agencies-Medibank, of course, is an obvious one-

TALK.START.PARA: —Lotteries.
—Senator Chipp mentions lotteries. I do not embrace that idea myself.
—But they are taking that on.

—Yes. Those sorts of things, I think, are potentially valuable services which will not intrude on genuine private enterprise activities in any way. They may indeed facilitate private enterprise activities in a particular community. I illustrate that in the following way. No one will establish agencies in particular areas in a community if they will not be profitable. But if they are part of an activity of an organisation such as Australia Post the question of profitability does not arise. It is a question of the delivery of services. So the Government does not accept the Opposition's proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 7 to 10-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 11 (Letters not to be carried for reward).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 6, clause 11, after proposed new paragraph 85 (ab), add the following paragraphs:

'(ac) the carriage or conveyance of a letter, regardless of the amount charged, in circumstances where the Minister determines that suspension of the monopoly is warranted because the Commission is unable to provide a service;
'(ad) the carriage or conveyance of a letter between branches of an organisation and between an organisation and its wholly-owned subsidiaries;
'(ae) the carriage or conveyance of a letter which forms the input to, or output from, electronic transmission facilities;'.
(5) Page 6, clause 11, at end of clause, add the following paragraph:
'(b) by omitting from paragraph (2) (c) ''the nearest'' and substituting ''any' ' '.

Clause 11 deals with exemptions. The Government has inserted two exemptions, in paragraphs (aa) and (ab). We want to add paragraphs (ac), (ad) and (ae). These are just picking up recommendations of the Bradley Committee of Inquiry into the Monopoly Position of the Australian Postal Commission about exemptions. We believe that they are logical and good exemptions. The suggested paragraph (ac) would mean exemption for:

the carriage or conveyance of a letter, regardless of the amount charged, in circumstances where the Minister determines that suspension of the monopoly is warranted because the Commission is unable to provide a service;

Briefly, in the case of a strike, particularly if it is prolonged, and there are others willing to provide services, the Minister should have the power on those occasions to allow an exemption so that the mail service, or some sort of mail service, can be got going again and the communications services of this country can be put back on the rails, albeit temporarily, so that the people can get letters of some sort, albeit for a higher price, delivered by private entrepeneurs.

As to the suggested paragraph (ad), we believe that there is an absurd restriction in not being able to carry letters between parts, branches or subsidiaries of a company where there is in-house mail and that that restriction should be lifted and people should be able to handle their own mail services. The third suggested amendment, paragraph (ae), relates to carriage or conveyance of a letter which forms the input to, or output from, electronic transmission facilities. Even though the term 'electronic transmission facilities' sounds really modern, such facilities are probably almost the oldest part of mail delivery in Australia; that is, the telegram service. Things have become far more sophisticated now, and the telegram service has largely disappeared with the advent of the telex and the facsimile machines. Telecom Australia, to its credit, operates a public telex and is also trying to operate a public facsimile service. Unfortunately, according to Bradley, until 1982 it was not getting that much of a reception from the public. We believe that if the carrying of mail to and from electronic centres could be opened up, it would provide a far greater service for the community and far greater usage of these electronic services.
The last amendment is a common-sense amendment:
(b) by omitting from paragraph (2) (c) 'the nearest' and substituting 'any'.

I was not aware of it, but apparently it is in contravention of the Bill if one takes a letter to just any post office and not to the nearest one. As I understand it, there could be a prosecution. I should imagine that there never has been a prosecution. But perhaps the legislation could be amended so that it meant any post office rather than the nearest one. One might inadvertently, or even deliberately for the sake of convenience, carry mail past one post office to another that is more convenient. I understand that the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy), when approached about this question, said that he would look into the matter. It is for those reasons that, on behalf of the Opposition, I have moved the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments are not acceptable to the Government. In relation to the postal service, it is the Government's view that in a situation of industrial dispute, the first proposed amendment moved by Senator Collard would suggest that there should be open slather, as it were, in relation to the provision of postal services. We take the view that it would derogate from the capacity of Australia Post to deal with and solve an industrial dispute if that sort of situation were allowed to develop. It would create all sorts of tensions and that situation is not desirably enshrined in legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the question of input and output of electronic mail, that would be an obvious way to avoid the monopoly. Of course, the Government has made its position clear that, like many other governments in many parts of the world, it is concerned to preserve the postal services monopoly. The suggestion made is a very obvious way of ensuring that. I think Senator Collard was incorrect in fact when he referred to the last amendment. He raised a point about the change from the 'nearest' post office to 'any' post office. The clause refers to the carriage of articles for reward. That amendment also is not acceptable although I might say that the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) gave some consideration to it after it was raised by the Opposition in the lower House.
Amendments negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the seventeenth report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills concerning the Bounty (High Alloy Steel Products) Bill 1983, the Bounty (Steel Mill Products) Bill 1983 and the Steel Industry Authority Bill 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT INCENTIVES AMENDMENT BILL 1983AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1983MANAGEMENT AND INVESTMENT COMPANIES BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 December 1983, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this package of three Bills-the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Amendment Bill 1983, the Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill 1983 and the Management and Investment Companies Bill 1983. The Opposition will not be opposing any part of the package. In fact, for part of it the Oppositioon offers enthusiastic support. I have spoken previously of the need to restructure Australian industry, of the concept of a dynamic economy-an economy ever changing, able to seize new opportunities and also able to discard the old way that may no longer show sufficient community benefit. I have recognised the responsibility of government to guide the nation in its post-industrialisation progress. I have identified the key to such economic development in upgrading Australia's level of technological innovation and adoption.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a lesson which should be learnt from those nations with the greatest increases in gross national product since the mid-1950s. Of developed Western societies, Switzerland, Sweden, Denmark and the Netherlands come to mind. Of the tremendous growth region of Asia, Japan, Taiwan, Singapore and now South Korea are examples. Certainly, lower labour costs may have helped them along the road but with wage increases they have been able to maintain their growth increases. No doubt the secret lies in the recognition that maximum competitiveness rests with the continual adoption of updated technology.

I have mentioned before that Professor Slatyer, President of the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Conference, had identified three areas contibuting to Australia's poor technological performance . The first was low levels of participation in education which raises the whole subject of skills development and an ever more sophisticated industrial environment. The second factor was low levels of industrial research and development, about which one of these Bills is concerned. The third factor was the lack of venture capital, about which another one of these Bills is concerned .

I will deal with the subject of venture capital first. In May of this year I remember specifically dealing with the subject. In that regard I made reference to the report of the Espie High Technology Financing Committee which had been brought down earlier this year. It is worth remembering that it was the previous Government that asked the then President of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences to inquire into ways of assisting particularly financing high technology industrial development. As a result, the High Technology Financing Committee of the Academy, headed by Sir Frank Espie, was given the task and it reported in April. As I then indicated, the Committee made recommendations in relation to the financial obstacles inhibiting the development of high technology industries in Australia. The one obstacle it recognised was that high technology enterprises have unreasonable difficulty in raising finance for the start up and the early growth phases of their enterprises. In the view of the Committee, government incentives were necessary to channel capital in such directions where the likelihood of reward is very difficult to assess. The Committee looked at a number of ways of doing this and recommended venture capital companies-small financial organisations which provided seed, start up and development capital and management guidance to new businesses. It took its example, of course, from experience in America. It recommended that incentives for funding the venture capital companies should be fully tax deductible for capital investments. It is worth noting in passing that the Espie recommendation was one of minimum government involvement in the decision making process. By this Bill, the Management Investment Companies Bill 1983, the Government is implementing in close detail the recommendations of Espie. The emphasis in the tests of the type of company that can benefit is good .

I am very restricted in time tonight; so I will not go any further into that. However, I mention that we are surprised that mining technology is not included in clause 29 (6) (a) of the Bill and no doubt the Government will be able to give us an explanation for that. But speaking generally, the Government is putting into effect what the Fraser Government put in train and this is to be commended. I only regret that the complementary taxation legislation has not been included and therefore we can anticipate further delay in implementation.

The second Bill I want to deal with is the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Amendment Bill 1983. As I indicated, Professor Slatyer also identified low levels of industrial research and development as contributing to our poor technological performance. Also included in this package is a Bill to amend the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act of 1976. The scheme of the current legislation is well known. It comprises three elements: Commencement grants, project grants and public interest project contracts. There can be no doubt as was stated in the Industries Assistance Commission's discussion paper 'New Technology Industry Assistance' of July of this year:
The development and implementation of new technology is one of the driving forces behind the process of economic growth.

This has been recognised by governments in the past. The Minister correctly stated in his speech that since 1967 successful Commonwealth Governments have sought to encourage Australian industry to reduce dependence on imported technology, to increase indigenous innovation and to undertake associated industrial research and development. Again, I do not have time to outline the list of methods by which a government has so encouraged industrial research and development. They can be found in the 1982 IAC report 'Certain Budgetary Assistance to Industry', but the major method is, of course, grants under the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act 1976. Regrettably, the results of that encouragement have been limited. The purpose of this Bill is to extend the scope and increase the effectiveness of the scheme, and it is intended to achieve that purpose in a number of ways. I suppose the most important are to give greater flexibility in grants to companies in the business of computer software development, to allow grants not only to manufacturers but also to agencies carrying out projects for corporate clients. It gives power to specify limits in the area of research and simplification of forward commitment provisions.

Because of the importance of industrial research and development to our economic growth, it is worth reviewing our record briefly. The incentives grants scheme can then be placed in a proper perspective. The Australian Science and Technology Council produced a report in June this year entitled 'Incentives for Innovation in Australian Industry'. Firstly, it expressed concern that the level of industrial research and development performed in Australia as a proportion of gross domestic product is low when compared with that of other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. It stated that only Greece, Italy, Turkey and Portugal were, in fact, lower. A perusal of the table to which it refers indicates that Canada might also be in that category. I think it would have been fairer to say that Australia is in the middle level of the table. Certainly, at approximately one per cent of gross national product it is much less than countries such as Switzerland with 2.4 per cent, the United States of America with 2.49 per cent, and Japan with 2.04 per cent. More dramatic, however , is that, in Australia, an unusually large part of national research expenditure is spent in government laboratories. The table of selected countries provided in the IAC's report 'Certain Budgetary Assistance to Industry' put only Portugal and Turkey ahead of Australia. In 1978-79, out of a total of 1.04 per cent of GNP spent on industrial research and development, industry provided only 0.22 per cent or, in other words, about a quarter of that of government. This is totally out of step with other OECD countries.

Thirdly, ASTEC also expressed concern that the level of industrial research and development expenditure carried on by business has been declining in real terms for a number of years. The low quantum of such development by business must be a major element of this debate. Perhaps a corollary of the fact that our industrial research and development is dominated by government is that we spend much more of our funds on basic research and less on experimental development than other like countries. We publish a lot of papers but the results are not applied in Australia's industry. In fact, it is reported that we publish 1.6 per cent of the world's research papers and yet produce only 0.3 per cent of the world's patents.

Another concern that one must have in looking at the Australian Industry Research and Development Incentives Board annual report 1980-81, is that there has been a decline in the number of those seeking grants with a significant export potential from 50 per cent in 1976-77 to 28 per cent in 1980-81. There are therefore a number of obvious concerns with respect to our industrial research and development performance. That leads to the question of how best government can encourage change for the better. As has been said by the IAC: ' What approach to government assistance is most consistent with the objective of facilitating growth and enhancing general community welfare?'. Despite what looks a reasonably disappointing record in relation to the incentives grants, the Government is clearly determined to continue in that direction, albeit with a slightly expanded scale and with an orientation towards sunrise industries. The IAC indicates that this in itself raises issues, such as whether there are gains to be made from assisting industries with good prospects, and in any case whether governments can identify those segments of industry with the greatest growth potential. Of course one who has been sceptical of the answer to that question is our shadow Minister, who has had the view that to produce indigenous new technology is important but it is more important, more practical, beneficial and effective certainly in the shorter term to adopt overseas state of the art technology in our manufacturing industries in order that they may be internationally competitive. That was the Japanese lesson, and still is to some extent.

However, it was clearly also expressed in the ASTEC report that the assessment and adaption of technology developed overseas which will be a principal source of new technology for Australian industry in many areas also requires that local enterprises maintain a considerable industrial research and development effort. Therefore, whether our industrial future is directed towards sunrise industries or the updating of existing industries, it still appears that there is a need for increased practically orientated industrial research and development. That gets back to the question of whether the grant system that we have at the moment is the best approach available. ASTEC concluded that it has not been established whether the incentives scheme has been an effective mechanism for raising the level of IR and D among business in Australia, and it seemed to be relying on the conclusions of the IAC in reaching that conclusion. The IAC said:
It is not clear to what extent the scheme has met its objectives of encouraging additional IR and D.

Mr Deputy President, this Government could have chosen a number of other alternative methods which I would have liked to have detailed but because of the time constraints cannot. Let me simply say that it could have looked to tax concessions or to repayable loans conditional on the successful outcome of the project. Such a system of repayable loans certainly has the difficulty of determining a successful outcome but it is worth noting that it was recommended by the Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia in 1980 and is also in use in the United Kingdom in the form of the National Research Development Corporation. I for one would like to know why it was discarded by this Government. Similarly, taxation concessions are in operation in Canada, Japan, Sweden and Germany. ASTEC recommended a taxation incentives scheme as an addition to our current Australian industrial research and development incentives scheme as a more effective means of stimulating industrial research and development activity. Again, I would like to know why that alternative has been rejected by the Government. But the Government has decided that selective intervention should continue. That raises the question that the IAC found difficult to answer; that is, selective intervention is helpful if it can be successfully implemented but the $64 question is whether it can be sufficiently successfully implemented.

There still seems to be considerable doubt as to whether the Government has chosen the best course, given the doubtful history of the effectiveness of grants and whether a further extension is an adequate response to the difficulties our country faces. Our past record has been to be import competitive rather than export oriented. That is another subject that must be looked at. In regard to tax incentives, perhaps we also ought to look at tax treatment for our investments which still does not facilitate rapid entry and departure from products and processes. Part of the answer might lie in the general macroeconomic climate in Australia to which the Government clearly must devote attention. All of these matters require Government attention. Our publication oriented rather than project oriented research has meant that although we might give away a lot of knowledge free of charge, in terms of receipts of payments for licences and patents we take in about ten times what we sell. That is clearly an unsatisfactory situation. We must therefore look to better integration between our research establishments and our industries. We must overcome what has become known as the research-innovation gap. There is obviously need for government encouragement in that regard.

The third Bill which I will touch upon but briefly is the Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill. It makes a number of changes to the current Australian Industry Development Corporation. It increases the resources available to the Corporation by increasing its capital and gearing ratio for borrowings. Provision is made for its borrowings to be guaranteed by the Commonwealth. Its capacity to provide equity finance will be increased by relaxing restrictions on the investment of its capital. Whilst it will be able to invest in any industry, priority will be given to manufacturing and internationally tradeable services, including tourism and the development of new technology industry.

It is worth noting that the Bill largely adopts the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. As I indicated, the Opposition will support the Bill. It is recognised by the Opposition that the Corporation is serving a worthwhile purpose, particularly in helping the development of new industry and restructuring existing industry in circumstances where funds are not otherwise available. There were some other comments I wished to make on that Bill but because of the time problems I mentioned earlier they will have to be left. However, in conclusion and in summary, the Opposition will not oppose any of the three Bills. Certainly, we enthusiastically support the Bill which deals with venture capital.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the hour, the date and the legislative program, as well as the support which has just been given by the Opposition to these three pieces of legislation, I will not take the time that I would normally have taken. We are debating cognately the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Amendment Bill, the Management and Investment Companies Bill and the Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill. I suppose that to the lay person what we are really talking about is sunrise legislation of legislation aimed at supporting and helping the development of new industry or the upgrading of existing industry in Australia. From that point of view it is exciting legislation because it looks to the future. All too often we have talked about how problems beset Australian industry. When we look at the manufacturing area, we talk about the lack of capital investment and the lack of research and development-two points that Senator Hill, in his address, which I found most interesting and absorbing, referred to in some detail, backed by statistical research. I do not want to go over that area.

SPEECH.PARA: But while there may be a few stunning examples of innovation and enterprise in the manufacturing industry area, generally I think it can be said of Australia that we languish behind the field and if we do not do something dramatic about it we are likely to fall further behind. These Bills address that question directly. What we look for as a consequence of the passage of this legislation is the enthusiastic support of industry and a quantum leap into the future which will enable the economic growth that Australia requires to be realised and enable increasing employment to be found. In talking about what is necessary for the future, a number of areas are not addresed by this legislation; nor should they properly be addressed under the heading of this legislation. But, of course , we need to direct our attention towards increasing skills in the Australian community so that we can take advantage of innovations that come along and provide the skilled base which is necessary for there not to be any blockages in an upward graph of industrial growth. We need to smooth out the difficulties that our economy faces in terms of structural change.

On other occasions I have spoken about Australia's resistance to structural change, mainly brought about, in my view, by the adversary system of industrial relations that we have in this country. I have argued for increasing industrial democracy in that area. We need to have aggressive development of new markets and to conduct greater research and development so that Australian ingenuity is properly realised. As in these Bills, we need to assist the business community to take risks, to be entrepreneurs, to grasp the nettle for the future development of the new industries that are necessary to provide an ongoing industrial base.

In my view of the economic problems of Australia, it is not just a matter of getting on top of what we currently are beset by. It is answering the question of where are the jobs going to come from, not just now but in the future. If one takes that as the measure of what is the central problem one can see that, looking at the world stage, Australia needs to develop industries which, although almost by their definition are likely to be capital intensive, will provide jobs in a dynamic and technological future. If we do not have those industries, we do not have any possibility of any jobs. The question may later become one of how we share the available jobs among all those who seek employment. But that question cannot even arise if we do not create an industrial base upon which there can be employment opportunities.

These three items of legislation that are before us tonight require some remarks. Firstly, the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Amendment Bill 1983 seeks to improve upon the previous legislation. The industrial research and development incentives scheme was introduced in 1976 in order to stimulate industrial research and development and so to increase the competitiveness of Australian industry in world markets. This Bill tonight extends the scope of the present Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act in order to increase the effectiveness of the original scheme. I could go into a great deal of detail about that, but I find that while that is an exciting piece of legislation, the more stimulating one of the package is perhaps the Management and Investment Companies Bill 1983 which seeks to enact the principal recommendations of the Espie report. This Bill is aimed at promoting the establishment and development of a private sector venture capital market in Australia. It supports the development and establishment of management and investment companies, which will be licensed by an independent management and investment companies licensing board. The aim is to improve access to equity finance for developing new industries. The investment is not limited to technology based enterprises but the scheme will provide critically needed funds for sunrise industries. The present problem is the unavailability of venture capital in Australia for those industries, and that unavailability is defined in the report as:
. . . . the provision of funds, unsupported by collateral, in an enterprise whose future is itself subject to a high degree of risk.

The Australian Government, pleasingly backed by the Opposition, tonight is prepared to provide those funds in order that the risk takers can do so, knowing that their endeavours are supported by the Government and the electorate. The Espie Committee, known by its proper title of the High Technology Financing Committee of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences, chaired by Sir Frank Espie, found that:

Australia is failing to generate new growth-oriented firms to replace those being lost in the older sectors. Australia is failing to grasp the opportunities offered by high technology industries for wealth creation and employment growth.
It is important to note also that it found:
No country has succeded in establishing a climate for investment in high-tech enterprises without the Government taking positive action.

Obviously that is important in the sense that the free market, left to itself, is not enough. It requires some stimulus and this is a proper measured and responsible level of government recognition of that. I could go on but since the legislation is being supported there is no purpose in arguing all the details that would have made up the rest of my speech on that Bill. The Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill 1983 is the one that of course completes the trinity of the items of legislation before us tonight. Hopefully the three taken together will have the effect that we seek. That Bill aims to extend the role of the Australian Industries Development Corporation to enable it to allocate additional finance for the restructuring and revitalisation of industry and for high technology and other growth industries. The major reports on industry policy have noted the shortage of finance, particularly in the form of equity, for the development of industry. That was not only mentioned in the Espie report but also in the Crawford report. The AIDC will further complement and supplement other sources of finance for high technology and other industry areas. This Bill enables the AIDC to fulfil that role and increases the statutory capital by $50m to take its capital to $150m. The Corporation will be able to call upon this capital in amounts of up to $12.5m per annum.

I commend the Bills to the Senate and I trust they will receive a smooth passage. I hope that we can start, by a combined approach and with the consensus that appears apparent in the chamber tonight, to help Australian industry develop to the end of this century and beyond so that jobs are available for Australians and Australia remains a competitive climate for new and sophisticated industries to compete with the world's best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is co-operating with the Government to ensure the smooth passage of these three pieces of legislation-the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Amendment Bill 1983, the Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill 1983 and the Management and Investment Companies Bill 1983. These three Bills share a common aim-to promote development in Australia of high, new or advanced technology industries, particularly the so-called sunrise industries and the high risk industries. While the level of expenditure upon industrial research and development in Australia is unfortunately low, we believe that we cannot pursue scientific and technological developments in isolation from other economic determinants in any society. I think if this Government has a fault it is a fault to view high technology in isolation from the other economic determinants in society.

SPEECH.PARA: Generally, the cost of the development of new products and processes in Australia has been very high. Combined with the relatively low profitability of business in Australia in the last few years this has contributed to the quite low level of industrial research and innovation that my colleague Senator Hill so vividly described earlier in this debate. I believe that attention, therefore , should be focused on real cost levels, the inflation rate, interest rates and other determinants and not just on computers and robots as I think the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Jones, is prone to do. Australia, if it is not careful, may not in fact be able to catch up in the area of high technology innovation; it is unfortunate. What do we have to do? We have to determine those areas of specialisation which are most appropriate for Australia. There has been no discernible high technology growth in Australia, and this is regrettable. Australia is a high cost nation. While manufacturing is crucial if we are to avoid increasing unemployment, Australia has a declining manufacturing base with a decrease in employment in the manufacturing sector from 34 per cent right down to 18 per cent in the last decade. So Australia needs more than ever a balanced export orientated economy.

The Government should be doing far more to aid existing industries such as mining and agriculture which provide the bulk of Australia's exports-some 85 per cent all told. There must be a recognition that, while promoting high technology as such, there tends to be a depreciation of the value of human participation and human motivation, and this is regrettable. There is involved in high technology a problem in the displacement of people. What are the social consequences of such a displacement? What research has been conducted by the Government in this area? Such research is lacking. It is a little like the Industries Assistance Commission making economic judgments without looking at the social consequences of those judgments. Previously there has been both application of capital and specialisation of labour. Modern high technology calls for and requires even higher degrees of specialisation with the resultant loss of jobs and greater levels of displacement of labour. The capability of high technology is such that people can be moved from jobs in a major way.

One has only to look at the information communication industry. High technology has touched only 15 per cent of that industry. So the potential for the displacement of labour in that area is quite horrific. It is about time that the Government did a little bit more positive research into this matter. In the September quarter new capital investment fell by 9 per cent in real terms. This is a tragedy for the nation. While tonight we passed legislation for prices surveillance activity, this is tending more and more to dampen company profits, which means less investment, less motivation to invest and, if investment is not taking place, there is a problem that one is tending to go down the hill with lower and lower employment opportunities.

This low level of capital investment tends to raise doubts in many people's minds about the long term strength of the so-called economic recovery that has been spoken about so freely by the Government in the last few days. Inflation in Australia is still far too high. I think the latest available figures indicate that it is about 9.2 per cent in Australia, compared with only 2.6 per cent in the United States of America, 2.9 per cent in West Germany and 4.6 per cent in the United Kingdom. Our competitiveness will not improve with the Government adopting a policy of full indexation of wages. It is often said that smaller businesses have a greater capability to adapt to change than have large corporations. I welcome the incentives and the initiatives in this legislation which are directed towards the small operation-the person with good ideas, with some get up and go and business acumen. Yet unfortunately it is the small businesses that are the more vulnerable of the two to cost increases.

The greatest contribution high technology will make to Australia's economic future does not lie solely in the creation of new sunrise industries; it lies also in helping existing industries to become more profitable and much more productive. I remind the Senate that, while many countries find themselves experiencing a tremendous growth in what is known as the microtechnological areas, imports of these sorts of products into Australia have had such a disrupting impact that the local microelectronic industry is decreasing alarmingly, despite what is being said by the Minister for Science and Technology.

It is regrettable that tonight we have not had presented to the Senate an integrated package of legislation. This legislation is a piecemeal approach, as has been adopted in the past. What is needed is a package of Bills.
