It is true that we have three Bills before us, but we need a package of, say, taxation Bills, complementary Bills, Bills covering bounty assistance, outlining government purchasing policies and preferences, and research and development. Let us look firstly at the need for simultaneous complementary taxation legislation, legislation that should have accompanied these Bills tonight. The consequences of the absence of such complementary legislation are that inevitably some smart people, aided by accountants and lawyers, will tend to exploit a concession, which must inevitably be given through the taxation Act later in the autumn Budget session, which will create a tax avoidance problem. It is unfortunate that we are not looking at this matter at the same time as we are looking at this legislation. Unfortunately, what will happen is that in the autumn session this Government will develop legislation-a taxation amendment Bill-to try to complement this legislation. It should have been brought into this chamber tonight. It should have been throught of as part of the package that has been presented tonight.

In the past the Commissioner of Taxation has often been left out of the initial negotiations in the drafting of legislation. I hope this will not occur in the autumn session when the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill is brought forward. The Taxation Commissioner is required to maximise the revenue from all sources. Unfortunately, this policy can lead to some unintended consequences. A few years ago when I was in the industry I witnessed a similar situation which covered export incentives when it was not intended for the rebate to be taxable. When the tax legislation came up and the assessments were issued, the Commissioner brought forward this incentive as a taxable receipt which was never intended in the initial deliberations when the incentive measures were discussed with industry. We have to be aware of these two problems. Some people will be astute enough to discover loopholes, will exploit this incentive and use it as a tax avoidance measure rather than use it for its true purpose and intent, as complementary legislation to the three Bills that are being discussed tonight.

I mention also the need for a package of measures involving taxation. So there is the question of complementary legislation and the problem of some people using the legislation as a tax avoidance measure. We also need an expression of attitude, manifested in a tax Bill, on the Government's approach to sales tax and sales tax rates. Will the Government encourage its depreciation policy on high technology industry by quick write-offs, discretionary depreciation rates, write-offs in the first year and accelerated rates over three years? What is the possibility? If the Government expects industry to make investment decisions now it has to have far more than what is presented to this Parliament tonight. The Government must be able to tell industry how it can write off its investment and how its revenue will be taxed. This will be critical if the Government is expecting industry to invest, otherwise it is developing a package in isolation which the manufacturing industry will not pick up because it cannot see the value for its dollar, the manner in which it will be taxed and the profitability , et cetera. There is a need for some firm policy on government purchasing.

As I have said before, all too often it is very much more comfortable for department heads to deal with large organisations. Last week I was with a high technology computer manufacturer and operator in Melbourne. He said: 'The big problem is that none of your departmental heads want to deal with us because we are too small'. Is that not an indictment of Australian society and Australian governments over the last few years? The Government prefers to deal with transnationals because they are large and the Government feels that they are dependable. We have some Australian innovators operating on the verge of new technological developments and they cannot get their share of business equipment sales to the Government. I think that there must be a reassessment of the Government's approach.

I have been urged to cut short my contribution. I think that it is unfortunate that debate on industry matters takes up so little time in this Parliament. We are prepared to spend hours and hours on sex discrimination legislation and freedom of information legislation, but our time seems to be cut short on industrial matters. We have to look into the question of protection and what is most appropriate for new technology. There is a need for some sort of assistance . I believe that bounty assistance is much more appropriate to high technology industry than the tariff which tends to be rather ineffective and costly. We have some legislation concerning research and industrial development. There is a problem of a lack of involvement and a low profile. One of the problems is the high level of overseas ownership in Australian operations which means that industrial research is essentially carried out in the overseas laboratory and exported to Australia for which we pay pretty high service fees. Somehow there must be legislation or inducement to encourage those sorts of industries to undertake their own research and development in Australia. Such legislation as there is has been very sparse and has worked adversely against small companies because many small companies have not been able to prove that they can provide one full time operative in research and development. Again this legislation tends to help some of the small operators and companies.

In this legislation there is a problem with regard to appropriate security. This is important. When working on the verge of high technology, one is sceptical when government inspectors snoop around, say 'Yes, it is very interesting', and then go on to the next factory. To what extent could a slip of the tongue be communicated and be of tremendous benefit to a competitor? We have to reassess our methods of auditing these high technology industries, because this problem of security of high technology details is important. There is a need for complementary legislation to give further encouragement to training and education. Our participation rates in higher education are deplorable. One of the reasons for the success of the Japanese is their very high retention rate of school leavers. Of course, there is a need for venture capital, which one of these Bills is providing in the form of 100 per cent tax write-off. I welcome that as well overdue.

The Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill proposes to extend the role of the AIDC. One could well ask why this is necessary. For example, the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System recommended selling the AIDC. Yet that recommendation has not been followed. We should very well ask the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), who is at the table, why it has not been followed. Secondly, this Bill allows the Australian Industry Development Corporation to invest in any industry but to give priority to financing manufacturing and services, including tourism and the development of high technology industries-a welcome goal. Thirdly, there is to be an increase in the Corporation's statutory capital. Fourthly, the Commonwealth will guarantee all AIDC borrowings. The AIDC is supposed to be a commercially competitive body; but, if the Commonwealth guarantees all its borrowings, a commercial advantage will be given to it. For example, it may very well be able to gain lower interest rates than competing bodies.

The AIDC is to pay the Commonwealth 50 per cent of its net profit after tax. But why does the AIDC not have to pay, for example, interest withholding tax? This is a real anomaly that should be examined. Other organisations in similar circumstances have to do this. In regard to its capital and reserves, the gearing ratio has been increased, yet the Campbell report recommended that the gearing ratio should not be a statutory imposition but should be established on individual cases within the AIDC. Restrictions on the investment of its capital will be relaxed and it is proposed that the AIDC be able to invest in any industry. If the AIDC is to operate as a commercial concern, why is it not required to earn a certain return on its investment, as any other private concern is? Finally, the Government can fund certain projects considered to be in the national interest. Such a term assumes that the national interest need not be purely a commercial interest. If this is so, why is there no provision for the two to be clearly separated in the AIDC accounts?

I wish to pay tribute to the work of the shadow Minister for Science and Technology in the House of Representatives, Dr Harry Edwards-the famous Professor Harry Edwards-who acknowledged the origins of some of this legislation , and to the former Minister for Science and Technology, the Hon. David Thomson. In March 1981 the then Minister approached Sir Ian McLennan, the former President of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences, asking him to institute steps to inquire into the ways of assisting, particularly financing high technology and industrial development. The High Technology Financing Committee of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences was appointed and headed by Sir Frank Espie of Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd. This measure implements in very close detail the recommendatoins of that report. I join with my colleague Dr Harry Edwards, in paying tribute to the former Minister, the Hon . David Thomson, who was a member of the previous Government. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not oppose the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Amendment Bill, the Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill or the Management and Investment Companies Bill, which I suppose reflect a laudable intention on the part of the Government to encourage new technology and sunrise industries. But as someone said at some time, the road to hell is paved with good intentions. These Bills are a fairly classic example of that. I wish to speak particularly to the two Bills emanating from the Department of Science and Technology. These Bills exhibit that same mild mediocrity that typifies the recent technology summit. The first one does things for software and provides better incentive systems for innovations. The second one has a very curious device which allows a new set of ill-defined organisations which are to get tax concessions in return for being a kind of ringmaster and father figure in a financial sense by providing risk capital in a surrogate fashion for select groups of enterprises. We are told that it is hoped that by their boldness and innovation these small groups of enterprises-or some of them-will establish viable new industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point I want to make is that the Australian Democrats are concerned that the Management and Investment Companies Bill seems to have that particular aspect. It gives tax rebates of 100 per cent for investment in licensed management and investment companies, which is what these new organisations are called. These will then provide venture capital for Australian businesses which utilise innovative technology. However, there is no facility in this Bill for any tax rebate for direct investment in the companies utilising this technology. We suggest that this is a mistake and that we would have had a far better motivation and sense of responsibility if this had been done directly. I cannot yet see quite why this has to be done by another stage of business.

It also seems a little sad that the Minster for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, like so many people, is fascinated with computers. When he talks about new technology and sunrise industries he often seems to have his mind on this one specialised area. Let us face it; computers collect information, classify it and regurgitate it, often in large quantities in a rapid, efficient and, indeed, fascinating way. They also can cause horrifying problems, bottlenecks and opportunities for crime, according to the ability of the programmers and users. The Australian Democrats feel that the Government ought to look beyond this area to new areas of technology, solid new industries which will provide wealth for the nation in the future and permanent job opportunities .

I know I started saying these things quite some months ago and that people such as Senator Button kept saying 'Yes, we will do this; give us time', but he has not done it yet. I see that he is getting flack from the Australian Council of Trade Unions too, because band-aid job opportunity measures that have been taken so far by the Government are no more than band-aids that provide three to six months work experience for some young people and then toss them on to the rubbish heap again after that. I suggest that this is not good enough. It is a basic view of the Australian Democrats that we must create a sustainable society in Australia, as indeed must be done and urgently everywhere else in the world. Eventually and inevitably everything we use must be renewable. It is high time governments, including the forward-looking, enterprising and future-orientated Labor Government, devoted themselves to that thought and not just paid lip service to it. It is in the energy field that a major opportunity exists for new industries to employ more people.

We feel it is imperative that more funding should be provided for research into renewable energy resources. This is a matter of urgency as our fossil fuels are being consumed. The present glut of oil products is perhaps reassuring but I suggest it is artificial and will be short lived. Probably within two years we will see the end of it. But an increase of funding is not the only necessity if our dependence on non-renewable energy resources is to be broken. We must actively encourage all consumers in the use of renewable resources. That is a matter of publicity and propaganda that could be carried out quite efficiently on a government level because the community is receptive of it. It expects these things of government and it is probably wondering why they are not happening. The SolarCal Council in California, a technology guidance body formed for the special purpose that I mentioned, expects that by the end of this year there will be 200,000 solar heaters and 150,000 solar space conditioning installations in California, which is a society roughly comparable with Australia. New government buildings in California which have floor space exceeding 10,000 square feet are required by law to use solar hot water heaters. Existing government buildings are being converted to solar heating. By 1985 this program is expected to save 15 per cent of the oil and gas California would otherwise have had to import. I suggest that is a vital and significant figure. It is a 15 per cent saving of non-renewable resources.

The other interesting point, and to us in Australia the vital one, is that by that time the industry will employ some 30,000 people at all levels of skill and experience, from skilled to unskilled, who would not otherwise have had jobs. Such a program could be introduced into Australia just as easily as in California if only the Government would get off its backside and make some inquiries. It does not even have to do any work; the situation is there; all the proof is available; all we have to do is go to California, seek its experience and bring it here. It will work in Australia just as it does there; there is no trouble about it at all. There is absolutely no risk and it will immediately put young people and others in Australia into employment. It would also have the valuable merit of starting the trend towards renewable energy which we know has to come.

What is the trigger? It is a very simple one. The California Utility Commission did its homework on this matter and found that it was cheaper to subsidise to the tune of 55 per cent through State and Federal income tax the installation of new established technology solar hot water heaters than to provide the power through building new fossil and nuclear power stations. All the figures are there. All the Government has to do is to ask for them. I have a copy of the figures if the Government wants them. That proof has been established. In fact I was told by somebody that the Commission could virtually have given solar hot water heaters to people and it still would have been cheaper than building new fossil and nuclear power stations.

According to the Petroleum Gazette, which is an industry paper, Australia's oil demand is predicted to be 120 million litres a day by 1990. Less than half that amount will come from known fields. By the year 2000 134 million litres a day will be used, on current projections, and only 27 million litres will be available from current fields. Self-sufficiency in oil will drop from 68 per cent now to 43 per cent in 1990, and to 20 per cent by the year 2000. We hope, of course, that major new finds of oil will be discovered, but it would be a foolish government which relied on that projection as a certainty. At some stage motor spirit will be a major problem to this country and we will have to look at alternative methods of producing it. Methanol and natural gas are obviously the best alternatives and should be investigated soon.

I think the Government also ought to encourage the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation to look at renewable energy resources in the solar and wind fields more extensively than it does. There has been some discussion of this matter in the Senate in recent weeks, and it has revealed the naked situation that the CSIRO is virtually doing nothing. The National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council is doing virtually nothing. We are unique in ignoring alternative energy resources. There again I think the Government will find it is running very much against community expectations.

Solar I in the Mojave Desert near Los Angeles, which any honourable senator can see for himself, produces 12 1/2 megawatts of electricity. In the daytime Solar I can provide enough power for some 6,000 households. This is not a small operation; it is a large operation. It is obviously a sensible type of installation for decentralised use in Australian circumstances. At night-the peak period after dark when the requirement for power is still there and is increasing-Solar I's thermal storage unit retains surplus heat attracted during the day and enables the power station to go on producing seven megawatts of power, more than half its daytime capacity, for four hours. Of course, by four hours after dark the demand for power starts to fall off again. It is of interest that a second, similar power station, which is being built nearby by a private enterprise corporation, is so confident of results that it has already contracted to supply solar power to California's major power supply authority at a lower price than for power generated by burning fossil fuels or from nuclear power stations. That technology has been backed by another completely new industry involving a huge factory that will do nothing but manufacture mirrors for solar power houses. Here again, of course, is a new area of employment.

I could continue to give dozens of examples and to edify the Senate in regard to many such matters-for example, wind energy and areas of solar technology- which I have no doubt would be informative to Senator Button. I will give him the benefit of knowing, or suspecting, that these things probably exist, that all the Government has to do is go out and find them.

My point is that these are ideas and developments which are not being actively considered or promoted by the Australian Government. So much for encouraging enterprise and new technology! It is a hollow claim, one that is not good enough . I believe that the fault is basically organisational and lies with the Department of Science and Technology itself. It is not good enough to expect Australian business and capital to go into new, high risk areas without responsible and informed Government guidelines on what is and what is not likely to be viable. If business burns its fingers over new technology, the lesson will be not to play with new techology in the future. But I imagine that that is not the lesson that the Government wants learned.

Therefore, the Government should get together, within the Department of Science and Technology, a task force consisting of businessmen of proven ability, academics and perhaps a few bureaucrats with a wide, freely ranging brief to search the world for a mix of sunrise industries that would suit Australia, doing so in constant consultation with Australian business and capital sources. It is becoming increasingly obvious that new high technology industries often complement and assist each other and that these need to be clearly identified and perceived. For instance, a modern, sophisticated solar power-house such as Solar I depends a great deal for its viability upon the most advanced computer technology, and probably also on robotisation in component manufacture. If we are to succeed in getting Australia into a competitive situation with the rest of the world the Government, and especially Mr Barry Jones, will have to get away from uttering mild abstractions and exhortations, and offering mild incentives of the kind we see in this Bill, which are unexceptionable but no better than that. The Government will have to do something about the problem. I ask, please, for Australia's sake, let that be as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the Senate for what I interpret, from listening to the debate both outside and inside the chamber, as general support for these Bills. It has been a very wide ranging and interesting debate. I would like to refer to one or two points raised in the course of it. In certain circumstances the venture capital provisions would apply to mining technology because it would presumably be manufactured technology. If that was not the case, the Management and Investment Companies Licensing Board would of course have certain discretions in relation to these matters; so I think the general answer to the question raised is yes. Senator Watson raised a couple of stroppy questions about the Australian Industry Development Corporation, first in relation to withholding tax. The Government acted in June of this year to remove the exemption enjoyed by the AIDC in respect of withholding tax; it is now in exactly the same situation as is everybody else.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson also raised a question relating to accounting in respect of the national interest provisions of the AIDC legislation. Of course, those provisions have not yet been used but it is expected that they may profitably be used by an AIDC with an expanded charter and a much greater availability of capital than that organisation has ever had before. I think the history of the AIDC has been somewhat sad because previous governments have not quite worked out their relationship with that organisation. I should like to think we have, or are in the process of doing so. A number of provisions in the existing legislation provide for separate accounting in many instances. The Bill extends the separate accounting procedures to the national interest provisions. I think these are the appropriate answers in respect of those matters.

The most stirring note of Senator Mason's speech was that the Government should get off its backside, and I leapt to my feet to reply to the second reading debate in response to his invitation. I do not want to remain on my feet for long. Senator Mason seemed to be promising a lot of overseas trips for members of the Department of Science and Technology. I will convey those views to the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), and he can make appropriate arrangements if he can persuade the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I thank the Senate for its brief but considered attention to these Bills. I commend the second reading of the Bills to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: STEEL INDUSTRY AUTHORITY BILL 1983BOUNTY (STEEL MILL PRODUCTS) BILL 1983BOUNTY (HIGH ALLOY STEEL PRODUCTS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 December 1983, on motion by Senator Ryan:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a series of Bills-the Steel Industry Authority Bill, the Bounty ( Steel Mill Products) Bill and the Bounty (High Alloy Steel Products) Bill-which relate to one of Australia's major basic industries. Our steel industry is, of course, based on Australia's great resources of both coal and iron ore. I preface what I want to say about these Bills by expressing my regret and the regret of the Opposition that Senator Peter Rae, who is the Opposition shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce and who is responsible for policy for the Opposition in this area, is not able to be in the Senate today because he is recuperating from an illness. For that reason I have the conduct of these Bills on his behalf.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will not oppose these Bills, but they raise a number of issues upon which I wish to touch. I do not suggest that at this stage of the session we will be able to have a full-blooded debate on the steel industry and the other issues which arise because time is too limited to permit that. Because the Opposition is not opposing these Bills I suppose that sort of debate is not absolutely necessary in any event. However, I wish to acknowledge the importance of the steel industry in the view of the Opposition.

It is important to us for defence reasons; it is important to us because of its effect on other areas of manufacturing industry. Indeed the Opposition would say that decisions taken to protect the steel industry and decisions which affect the access of Australian industry to the various types of steel that they need and at the price that they have to pay are very important to those other areas of industry. We cannot look, from an industry viewpoint, simply at the welfare and health of the basic iron and steel industry. It is important for employment reasons. It is a major employer although I think that employment has dropped by some 10,000 over recent years because of the decline in demand for steel in Australia and the declining opportunities we have had for exporting steel. Of course it is of major regional economic importance particularly in the three main areas of Newcastle, Wollongong and Whyalla.

I refer to the statement made by the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Senator Button) who is in the chamber at the moment. He announced the steel industry plan on 11 August and made some comments in the early part of that statement with which the Opposition would certainly agree. He said that to regain its internationally competitive position the industry would have to reduce its relative production costs significantly. The Government on its own could not ensure the necessary cost reductions. He went on to say that all interested parties, including the industry, the unions and relevant State governments, had a role to play in achieving these reductions. I think those comments are apt. The Government was correct in seeking to involve all of those parties-the Government, the industry, unions and relevant State governments-in trying to achieve reductions in costs which were necessary for the long term health of the steel industry in Australia.

I want to touch on the role which each of those areas has to play. I will mention some of the misgivings that the Opposition has about whether the package presents a complete solution to the problems which the steel industry has faced. I also want to touch on the question of fast track dealing with the possibility of dumping. I refer to it now because it is a discrete item in the package. Part of the steel industry package announced by the Minister for Industry and Commerce was that there would be fast track anti-dumping arrangements for the steel industry. Senator Peter Rae has on a number of occasions in questions and in debate raised with the Minister the precise arrangements which the Government has in mind. I refer to the answer which was recently provided by Senator Button to Senator Rae to question No. 340 where, in part, the Minister stated:

There is no intention to announce the new 'fast track' anti-dumping procedures in relation to the steel industry. They will be activated by the Steel Industry Authority when it is appointed and following the introduction of the steel industry plan on 1 January 1984.

There is some concern on the part of the Opposition that there is some cloudiness, some lack of detail available to us in what is involved in the fast track anti-dumping procedures. Obviously the whole question of anti-dumping activity is of some sensitivity and involves the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade anti-dumping code. I raise that matter with the Minister as I believe the Government could be more forthcoming in helping us to understand precisely what it is doing with respect to the totality of the steel packages.

I turn to the contributions which are being sought from the various participants under the steel package of the Government. I want to demonstrate why we think there are some elements of the package which lead us to say that it has some stop-gap elements about it. For example, it is apparent that the package does not guarantee that Australia would have an internationally competitive steel industry at the end of the plan. I say that because the plan includes some commitment for further investment with Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd being committed to a firm capital investment of $500m and a further likely investment of $300m. This total of $800m is about a quarter of what BHP told the Industries Assistance Commission was necessary between 1985 and 1995. I realise that the plan does not run over that full 10-year period, it runs for only half of it. I simply say that we are left in the situation that whilst there may well be some very welcome further investment by BHP, it does, on the company's own assessment, appear to fall short of what the company thought was necessary to guarantee the sort of steel industry which Australia needs.

As far as the unions are concerned, we find some real value in the package. Again, we do not in any sense argue with the Government's involving the trade unions in this very important area. I quote Senator Rae's initial response to the package. He said:
The best thing that can be said for it is that the productivity undertakings represent, potentially, a major breakthrough.
He went on to say:

Although there is virtually no sanction, there has been a recognition by the trade union movement that, without productivity, protection by way of bounties, quotas, tariffs, and the like, can create a dangerous illusion, leading to the destruction of competitiveness of industry, and thereby its long-term existence, and the jobs which it provides.
He went on to say:
It is most encouraging to see that the trade union movement is recognising that the quid pro quo for protection must be productivity increases.

I thoroughly adopt those words of Senator Rae and believe that that is a positive element of what the Government is seeking. The concern the Opposition has, however, is what is being offered by the unions and whether it is adequate. The Government has also put in the package a provision that the unions will receive wage increases in line with the community standard. It has sought to restrict the industry to that provision. But the fact is that that involves the 4.3 per cent wage increase for the first six months of this year and full wage indexation beyond. It appears to the Opposition that that has the potential to lock the steel industry into a current situation of unprofitability and lack of competitiveness. I understand the sort of reasons which have been argued by Senator Button often enough in this chamber as to why the Government believes that that is a minimum sort of arrangement which ought to be entered into. But the fact is that the world steel industry is in difficulty. In the United States , for example, steel workers have seen and accepted the need to accept a 9 per cent cut in wages because of the competitive position of their industry. I think that is fair enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty-five dollars a week.

—I simply raise that as a comparable response to a similar real difficulty in the industry in another country. Steel workers in the United States have made other concessions which are certainly more substantial than those made by unions in Australia. Again, I do not think this is the debate in which to canvass these issues at length. I raise them because I think that generally they go to the question of whether we have a long term arrangement which will enable the Australian industry to become fully competitive.

SPEECH.PARA: I touch now on the role of the States. We have heard some rather confusing statements in this chamber because the Government has suggested in its package that the States have an important role to play. The States are to make a contribution to the plan in relation to the containment of State charges and to otherwise ensure that they contribute to the health of this industry. On the information which is publicly available it appears that to date nothing has been forthcoming from either the New South Wales Government or the South Australian Government. The Minister is on record as saying that he considered the New South Wales contribution to be important yet in answer to a question in the Senate from Senator Peter Rae he said that the contribution was not significant. Indeed , I do not think that anything at all has been said about the contribution of South Australia. I think that during this debate we should ask in what sense are the States prepared to live up to their role in this arrangement and what contribution will they be making to the continued health of this industry when in fact they are imposing heavy charges on it. In the same way, this Government has increased its charges on the industry by increasing sales taxes and excises. Again, that seems rather inconsistent with the general thrust of the package.

So in each of these areas, in the contribution of the industry and the level of investment which is to be made and the contribution of the unions and of the States, we see problems. They give rise to some doubt in the collective mind of the Opposition about the efficacy of the total package. Having said that, we do not oppose the legislation. We think that there are very positive elements in it . We hope that it will restore the health of the industry. It is our judgment, however, that the success of the package is very dependent upon general economic growth in Australia and a general improvement in the economic situation. Should there be any faltering in that area we would have some doubts that the objectives of the Government will be achieved by the legislation it has laid down.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking issue an Interim Report No. 2 relating to passports in May 1982.
(2) Did the Commission make 40 recommendations in respect of passports.
(3) What is the current state of implementation of each of those recommendations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Senior Secondary Colleges

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 13 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: What was the average cost of educating a student in each of the following senior secondary colleges for each of the last three years: (a) Copland College; (b) Dickson College; (c) Erindale College; (d) Hawker College; (e) Narrabundah College; (f) Phillip College; (g) School Without Walls; and (h) Stirling College .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority does not maintain records of costs associated with the operation of each individual school in a format from which specified data such as per capita cost at each of the listed colleges could be easily extracted. However, as far as costs for all colleges in the Australian Capital Territory are concerned, the current average per capita figure is $3,084 at June 1983 prices.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 15 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Tasmanian iron ore pellet manufacturer, Savage River Mines, currently importing South African anthracite to be used in its iron ore pellet plant.

(2) Was Mr Barry Swan, spokesperson for the Australian Coal and Shale Employees ' Federation, correct in stating in the Australian Financial Review of 8 September 1983, that similar grade coals to South African anthracite are available from a number of Australian mines, including CSR Ltd's Yarrabee mine in Queensland and Bayswater Collieries Pty Ltd's Hunter Valley mine.
(3) Have 693 mineworkers lost their jobs in New South Wales since May 1982.
(4) Is the Australian coal industry in a severe state of overproduction and did stockpiles in all districts stand at record levels on 1 January 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that Savage River Mines has imported anthracite from South Africa for use in its iron ore pelletisation project in Tasmania. Imports of all types of coal from South Africa into Tasmania in 1982-83 amounted to 26,241 tonnes. The company has a requirement for about 30,000 tonnes of anthracite in 1984.

(2) I understand that for pollution abatement and metallurgical reasons the company requires anthracite or other low volatile coal of particular size and other physical specification. Savage River Mines have had discussions over a number of years with prospective Australian suppliers, including those referred to in the question, concerning their ability to provide a suitable product-so far without success. The company believes Australian sourcing of a technically suitable product should offer cost savings over imported anthracite and negotiations are continuing.
(3) According to the Joint Coal Board figures, employment in the New South Wales Coal Industry in May 1982 was 21,091. As at August 1983, the latest published figure, employment was 19,460 persons.

(4) Coal industry production is currently in excess of demand, particularly for coking coal. I am advised that the Queensland Coal Board does not publish data on stocks. Figures published by the Joint Coal Board indicate that New South Wales coal stocks reached record levels in January 1983, and have since increased to over 21 million tonnes in August.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

(3) Has Australia granted any aid, if not why not.

(4) Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs review applicable guidelines to ensure aid is provided as a matter of emergency if Australia has not granted any aid and in view of the urgency of the situation of the Palestinians.

(2) and (3) As of 30 June 1983, in response to the UNRWA appeal the following governments had contributed (US$):
In kind and
associated Contributor
Cash cash Total
(Source: Report of the Commissioner-General, United Nations Relief and Works Agency, 1982-83)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 5 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware that in the most recent environmental survey at the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories (Report AAEC/ E563), it was stated that traces of caesium 137 were found in milk, but that the source of this caesium could not be distinguished between weapons fallout and local caesium 137.
(2) Are monitored readings of caesium 137 and noble gases taken at other points in Australia if the origin of caesium 137 could be fallout from the testing of nuclear weapons; if not, why not.
(3) Where are these monitoring stations located, and do their readings compare with the findings obtained at Lucas Heights.
(4) Who is responsible for monitoring general levels of radioactivity arising from weapons test fallout.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the survey referred to in the honourable senator's question. However, as some of the matters raised involve activities of the Australian Radiation Laboratory ARL, I have obtained the following advice from the Minister for Health.

(1) In Report AAEC/E563, concentrations of caesium 137 in milk collected by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission in their environmental survey are reported as being below their minimum level for quantitative measurement, 3 x 10-4 Bq/g of fresh milk. In 1978, which was the last year in which caesium 137 was routinely measured in milk in ARL's national fallout monitoring program, concentrations of caesium 137 in milk being processed for consumption in the eastern States varied between 0.75 and 1.5 x 10-4 Bq/g of fresh milk.

(2) In the national fallout monitoring program carried out by ARL, caesium 137 is currently monitored in ground-level air only. It is collected on filters by large volume air samplers operating continuously at six locations throughout Australia, and the filters are forwarded to ARL every week for measurement. Monitoring for noble gases has never formed part of the national fallout monitoring program because health hazards associated with noble gases originating from atmospheric nuclear weapons tests up to the present time are negligible.
Measurements of caesium 137 in milk ceased to form part of the national fallout monitoring program at the end of 1978 because:
(a) concentrations had dropped to very low levels,

(b) from our knowledge of the behaviour of caesium 137 in the environment, it was predicted that there would be no general rise in concentrations of caesium 137 in milk unless there was a resumption of nuclear weapons testing in the atmosphere of such magnitude and so located as to produce considerable quantities of radioactive fallout over Australia,
(c) ground-level air would continue to be monitored for the presence of any radioactive fallout, and
(d) caesium 137 is considered to be much less hazardous to health than strontium 90 with which it is associated in radioactive fallout.

(3) Caesium 137 in ground-level air is continuously monitored at Perth Airport, Adelaide Airport, Laverton Air Base in Victoria, Richmond Air Base in New South Wales, Amberley Air Base in Queensland and Townsville Airport. The Australian Atomic Energy Commission publishes no data on caesium 137 in ground-level air with which comparison can be made.
(4) ARL is responsible for monitoring general levels of radioactivity arising from weapons test fallout.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Health aware of the health problems that have arisen from the prescription of diethylstilboestrol (DES) causing cancer, genital tract abnormalities and infertility in the effected offspring.
(2) Will the Minister investigate the problems suffered by those affected.
(3) Will the Government establish free medical treatment and screening in adequately staffed and equipped centres and establish an effective register and monitoring of patients.

(4) Will the Government provide: (a) legal and financial help for victims to obtain compensation from the drug companies which manufactured and marketed DES and related drugs as a treatment for miscarriage; and (b) funding for a nation- wide publicity campaign to alert DES victims to the problems they may be facing, the need for specialised tests, and embark on consultation with and funding assistance of DES ACTION as the resource organisation representing DES affected people.

(5) Will the Government investigate the effects of hormonal growth stimulants in animals and poultry which may exacerbate some DES-related conditions and thus further endanger the health of DES victims.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Although the problems of DES arose initially as an issue of drug safety, they are now primarily a matter of appropriate treatment of affected persons. When this problem was recognised in the early 1970's the matter was publicised by way of a statement issued to all doctors by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee in 1972 and again in 1975. These were followed up with an editorial in the Medical Journal of Australia in 1981. The National Health and Medical Research Council has undertaken to keep the problem under review.

(3) The provision of treatment facilities is primarily a State responsibility. In Victoria, largely as a result of the activities of DES ACTION, a conjoint project, organised in 1981 by the Victorian Government in collaboration with the Victorian Branch of the Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, led to the establishment of a referral clinic at the Royal Women 's Hospital, Melbourne. I understand that a similar clinic now operates at the King George V Memorial Hospital, Sydney. Action in other States has been less comprehensive. Colposcopic screening for women with a history of maternal exposure to oestrogen is included in the schedule of medical benefits.

(a) The question of whether or not the Government will provide legal and financial help for victims to obtain compensation from the drug companies which manufactured and marketed DES and related drugs is a difficult one to answer. The Government has no legal responsibilities in this regard and would need to be presented with much more information than it currently has before any decision could be taken.

(b) As part of the conjoint project in Victoria an excellent information booklet on this matter was issued to all Victorian medical practitioners. Following representations from DES ACTION consideration is being given to providing funds to that organisation as a national community health project. However, this needs to be examined in the light of other requests made to determine a level of priority for the provision of limited funds.

(5) It is understood that legislation was introduced in all States in the early 1960's prohibiting the use of DES as a growth stimulant in animals and poultry. There does not appear to be any evidence which indicates that the use of such stimulants may exacerbate some DES-related conditions. However my Department will continue to monitor the literature in this regard and take whatever action may be appropriate in the light of information which comes to hand.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 6 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the 1983 Australian Scholastic Aptitude Test (ASAT) checked for sex discimination by the Australian Council of Educational Research prior to its use in Canberra; if so, what was the result of such testing; and if not, on what grounds did the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority decide that the ASAT discriminated against female students.

(2) Is it possible that the test discriminates against most students (both male and female) who undertake studies in humanities subjects while advantaging most students in the science/mathematics areas.

(3) Is it possible that an imbalance between the male and female scores could be caused by many potential high scoring girls leaving school at the end of Year 10, for example, to undertake secretarial or other courses, while the boys who leave school at this time are usually low achievers.
(4) Does this imply that all girls are equally disadvantaged as female scores are to be raised uniformly.
(5) Is it possible that some females handle this type of testing as well as males; and equally, is it not possible that some males handle this type of testing poorly.
(6) Will students from predominantly male classes wishing to make careers in predominantly male occupations such as engineering, be disadvantaged when competing for places at interstate universities.
(7) Will male scores be raised if female students outscore males in the ASAT.

(8) Has any attempt be made to ascertain whether subsequent academic performance of Canberra students bears out the hypothesis that the ASAT test shows a bias against female students, and were tertiary and technical institutions contacted in this regard.

(9) What would have been the effect in an all male subject group on Tertiary Entrance Scores of 240, 280 and 320, assuming that this proposal had been in operation in 1982, and what would have been the effect in an all female subject group on Tertiary Entrance Scores of 240, 280 and 320.
(10) Would the Schools Authority proposal be legal under the proposed Sex Discrimination Bill in its present form.

(11) Are other students who may be disadvantaged under the existing system to have the opportunity to have their ASAT scores increased, for example: (a) those students who suffer from chronic or major illnesses; (b) those students who come from homes where English is not normally spoken; (c) those students who come from deprived socio-economic backgrounds; and (d) those students who may have had some physical or emotional impairment to learning in their earlier school days and who have not had sufficient remedial help since that time; if so, how may such children apply for a mark increase.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) All items for the 1983 test were subjected to analysis for sex bias. Panels including Australian Council for Educational Research (ACER) researchers examined the items and removed all detectable biased items.

The Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority was nonetheless concerned that there could be disadvantage to girls in Year 12 in 1983. It therefore established an independent panel to review the evidence available and to recommend an interim procedure for 1983.
That panel was comprised of:
Dr Beryl Rawson, Dean, Faculty of Arts, Australian National University.
Professor Don Spearritt, Department of Education, Sydney University.
Ms Helen Williams, Deputy Secretary, Commonwealth Department of Education and Youth Affairs.
Mr Ian Knight, Assistant Principal, Narrabundah College.
After considering all of the data the panel identified that there could be a number of possible causes for the difference including:
There is a higher retention rate for girls in Year 12 and thus a wider spread of ability level.
There are differences in subject choice patterns between boys and girls; more boys choose advanced maths and science subjects.
There could be an inherent bias against girls in the questions used in the test .

The panel concluded that there is a gender difference not related to retentivity that should be dealt with on an interim basis in 1983. It therefore recommended an adjustment of one third of the difference between the mean of the ASAT standardised total scores of females and males for 1983 only.
In presenting its report the panel made it clear that there was a need for extra research to examine policies for the longer term.

(2) Research conducted by the Australian Capital Territory Schools Accrediting Agency's Technical Advisory Committee suggested that such a subject choice, i.e. humanities subjects, accounted for 0.4 of the 6.8 difference in the 1982 ASAT mean scores.

(3) Both the Australian Capital Territory Schools Accrediting Agency and ACER have undertaken research into the retention rates of males and females from Year 10 to Year 12. There is no evidence to support the view that the imbalance between the male and female scores was caused by high scoring girls leaving school at Year 10.
(4) No. The standardising procedure to be employed will generate a tapering effect and thus the scores of the higher ranked girls will move less than the lower ranked.
(5) Yes. But on average, boys score consistently better.

(6) It is almost impossible to generalise on this point because one has not only to consider the mean ASAT of a group, but also the standard deviation. What can be said is that the TES scores are expected to go down slightly, on average, in single sex boys schools and stay approximately the same in co-educational schools.
(7) The procedures will apply to the male ASAT scores should the 1983 candidate show a reverse in the trend.
(8) There has been some work at the ANU, but the numbers involved have been statistically insignificant.
(9) As I have already indicated it is not possible to be specific because of the impact of the standard deviations.
(11) The Australian Capital Territory Schools Accrediting Agency has procedures to ensure that students are treated fairly, for example:
ASAT scores for students from a non-English speaking background are excluded from the calculation of the tertiary entrance score.
provisions within each college allow the awareness of status or credit because of illness or misadventure.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 8 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Resources and Energy's attention been drawn to reports by the United States Environmental Protection Agency and National Academy of Sciences that confirm the long-held belief that atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuels and compounded by the mass felling of forests is causing an alarming increase in temperatures around this planet, together with drastic alterations to weather patterns.
(2) Is the Government concerned about the threat of this 'greenhouse effect' on the earth's climate and the contribution to it by our fossil fuel exports and consumption.
(3) How much of the $14m that is expected to be spent on energy research and development projects in 1983-84 will be spent on coal and other fossil fuel sources of energy.
(4) How much will be spent on solar energy research and development projects.
(5) What alternative energy projects, other than solar, will be funded by the Government during 1983-84.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the two reports and that both conclude that a doubling of the pre-industrial carbon dioxide concentration resulting in a 2*C average increase in air temperature will probably occur by the third quarter of the 21st century.

The computer models used in these studies are complex and uncertainties arise from lack of knowledge both of the physical processes involved in the formation of weather systems and of carbon exchange between atmosphere, oceans and biosphere. It is therefore at present not possible to draw firm conclusions as to the wider consequences of the 'greenhouse effect' on future climate and weather. Both reports stress the need to carry out additional monitoring and research, but do not recommend that any precipitate action be taken to curtail fossil fuel use.
(2) The Government regards this as an important issue and will continue to monitor overseas information and, as considered necessary, will carry out relevant research in Australia.

The National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Program is currently supporting research by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Division of Atmospheric Research into both the carbon cycle and the climatological aspects of increased carbon dioxide. Measurements made at the Baseline Air Pollution Station, Cape Grim, Tasmania, which is operated by the Department of Science and Technology, are providing an essential input to this research.

In addition, from their own appropriation, the CSIRO Division of Water and Land Resources and the Division of Atmospheric Research are investigating the impact of possible climatological changes on crop productivity and the Division of Plant Industry is studying the direct response which plants and crops would have to changes in carbon dioxide concentration.

The CSIRO has advised that the contribution of Australia's fossil fuel exports and consumption to the 'greenhouse effect' would be relatively small. It is estimated that carbon dioxide resulting from the combustion of fossil fuels in Australia would amount to only one per cent of the world total.

(3) I refer to my press statement of 11 November 1983 in which I announced the approval of grants under the national energy research, development and demonstration program for 1983-84, totalling $16.3m. The total commitment from this amount for energy research, development and demonstration projects on coal and other fossil fuel sources of energy is $13.7m.

(4) Of the $16.3m mentioned in (3), $1.4m is committed on solar energy research , development and demonstration projects. In addition, further funds will be made available for a number of commissioned studies on solar energy.

(5) I will define alternative energy sources as any energy technology, based on renewable or non-renewable energy, which has not yet penetrated the market to any significant degree. Using this definition $4.0m of the $16.3m is committed to alternative energy projects. It should be noted that some of the non- renewable energy projects in this category, for example conversion of coal to oil, are also included under the category of coal and fossil fuel sources in (3) .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 9 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: 1. What are the steps necessary for a provincial city port to be given capital city status in benefiting that area in regard to steel pricing.
2. Why has Launceston acquired that status but Townsville has not merited such declaration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that the policy of the major local steel producer is to offer a uniform price in all capital cities except Darwin.
This price also applies in Newcastle, Port Kembla and Whyalla, the major steel producing centres.

Steel is shipped to Tasmania via Bell Bay and accordingly it costs no more, or even less, to deliver steel to Launceston than it does to Hobart. For this reason the capital city price is offered in Launceston.
Steel for Townsville is shipped to Brisbane and then sent on by rail.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for resources and Energy, upon notice, on 29 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware of recent studies of the cost of wind-generated electricity in suitable parts of Western Australia, South Australia and especially Tasmania by researchers at the University of New South Wales (Blakers and Outhred, School of Electrical Engineering), showing that the likely cost of this electricity would be approximately 2.5c/kWh, which is less than the cost of electricity generated by the Henty-Anthony hydro-scheme in Tasmania.

(2) Is the Minister aware that the employment potential of a wind energy scheme is between two and three times that of an equivalent hydro scheme in Tasmania, and that there are excellent prospects for the establishment of a major industry based in Tasmania exporting wind generators.
(3) Is the Minister aware that one utility in the United States of America alone, Pacific Gas and Electric, has contracted to install over 300 MW of wind energy generating capacity since 1980.
(4) Is the Minister aware that Australia has one of the longest windy coastlines in the world.
(5) Has wind energy enormous potential in the southern part of Australia as an electricity source in view of the above.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the 2.5c/kWh estimate made by researchers at the University of New South Wales, however it should be noted that this figure cannot be applied directly to other situations. The estimate is based on a comparison of the production of electricity from the Gordon-below-Franklin Hydro Scheme with electricity generated by wind energy. The 2.5c/kWh estimate also assumes a saving of oil of $193m that might have been needed to operate the Bell Bay Power Station while the Gordon-below-Franklin dam would have been under construction. This assumption, and its relevance is open to debate. More importantly, the estimate assumes a price for the wind generators which is substantially below current prices. A further factor that can very significantly affect the cost of wind generation is the average wind speed assumed in the calculations. For these reasons there is a danger in using specific estimates as an indication of what might be applicable in different situations and this is the case in comparing the likely cost of wind electricity generation in other Australian States.

As I have previously indicated, I have approved the allocation of $70,000 under the national energy research, development and demonstration, NERD and D, program to a study of the technical and economic feasibility of wind electricity generation in Tasmania. This study will aim to provide a definitive estimate of the cost of wind generated electricity in Tasmania.

To illustrate the dangers of applying an estimate from one State to another, I should mention that a recent preliminary study entitled 'Wind generation for Victoria', undertaken by the State Electricity Commission of Victoria, has indicated that the cost of wind generated electricity in that State would be in the region of 15-30c/kWh.

(2) It has been claimed that wind energy offers high employment potential in Tasmania, but I am not aware of any conclusive evidence to this effect. It is possible that this question will be examined during the Tasmanian wind energy feasibility study under the NERD and D program.
Prospects for the establishment of a wind energy industry in Tasmania will of course depend primarily on whether wind is an economically competitive option for power generation in that State.

I might add that during my recent visit to Denmark I had the opportunity to see small wind turbines being manufactured and to discuss the economics of wind generated electricity. Regarding Senator Mason's view that there are excellent prospects for the establishment of a major industry based in Tasmania exporting wind generators, I note that the market is already well supplied by a number of existing European manufacturers.
(3) Yes. Whilst overseas I observed that wind energy flourishes wherever good wind resources and generous tax concessions exist.

(4) A broad survey by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has indicated that Australia's wind energy resources are concentrated in coastal regions. Limited site-specific data have indicated that relatively high average windspeeds occur at several coastal locations in southern and western regions, but there can be large variations in average windspeeds even within a small area and the currently available data does not suggest that high windspeed sites are available in all coastal regions.

(5) The potential contribution of wind to electricity supply in Australia will very much depend on whether it can be produced at a cost which is comparable with the cost of electricity from conventional energy resources. This question will be clarified for Tasmania by the feasibility study under the NERD and D program, in Western Australia by the investigations being undertaken by its State Energy Commission, and in Victoria by a further study to be undertaken by the Victorian Solar Energy Council in cooperation with the State Electricity Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 2 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the present government of El Salvador's appalling human rights record been well documented by Amnesty International, the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights, and the Federation International de Droit de L'Homme.

(2) Will the Government be following the spineless lead of past Australian governments who in 1981 and 1982 abstained from the United Nations General Assembly resolutions reaffirming the right of the El Salvadorean people to freely determine their political, economic and social future without interference from outside and in an atmosphere free from intimidation and terror from all parties.

(3) Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs explain the reasons for the decision if Australia is not going to support this year's resolution, which will be sponsored by countries including France, Mexico and Sweden.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) and (3) On my instructions the Australian delegation voted in favour of the resolution on the human rights situation in El Salvador in the Third social and humanitarian committee of the United Nations General Assembly on 9 December. This vote will be repeated when the report of the Third Committee on the agenda item, The situation in Latin America, is considered in the plenary session of the General Assembly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 April 1983 (Hansard, page 57), Senator Foreman asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to recent Press items concerning private employment agencies which charge fees to job applicants. I refer particularly to two such employment agencies operating in South Australia, namely, Jobfinders and JAL. Can the Minister tell the Senate how many such private employment agencies are operating in Australia? Is the Minister aware that the two agencies I have just named are engaged in a massive rip-off of unemployed people and do not attempt actively to seek work for their clients? Is the Minister aware of any possible breaches of the Trade Practices Act concerning the operation of these agencies? What action can the Government take to stop these rather unscrupulous activities?
The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I have seen the references to alleged malpractices by certain private employment agencies not only in the South Australian Press but in the Press of other States. I am, naturally, most concerned about this matter.

In the case of the two agencies in South Australia cited by the honourable senator in his question, I am advised that they have been the subject of investigation by the South Australian Department of Labour under the provisions of the (South Australian) Employees' Registry Offices Act 1915-1973 and that a prosecution has been initiated against the agency Jobfinders. I am also advised that legal action has been instigated against this agency by the New South Wales Department of Industrial Relations under the provisions of the (New South Wales) Industrial Arbitration Act 1940 (as amended).
I am advised that the agency JAL has ceased operating.

As far as the (Commonwealth) Trade Practices Act 1974 is concerned, I am advised that complaints were made to the Trade Practices Commission concerning the activities of Jobfinders, and that the Commission was of the view that its activities were outside the constitutional reach of the Act.

As to what future action might be taken I can inform the honourable senator that the Government is currently reviewing the operations of the Trade Practices Act, including the possible strengthening of its provisions dealing with consumer protection, which apply, inter alia, to private employment agencies. In addition, Queensland has recently proclaimed its Private Employment Agencies Act 1983, while the Victorian Government recently introduced into State Parliament protective legislation dealing with the regulation of private employment agencies. I am also advised that the South Australian Government intends strengthening and widening the provisions of that State's Employees' Registry Offices Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 October 1983 (Hansard, page 1236), Senator Reynolds asked me, as the Acting Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the possible harmful effects of the drug diethylstilboestrol. I undertook to find out details from the Department of Health on the matters raised by Senator Reynolds.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The possible harmful effects of the drug diethylstilboestrol-DES-were publicised in 1972 and again in 1975 by way of statements issued to all doctors by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. The statement drew attention to the association between DES exposure in-utero and the subsequent development of adenocarcinoma of the vagina in adolescence and young adult life and warned against the use of the drug in pregnancy. These statements were followed up in 1981 with an editorial in the Medical Journal of Australia.
I can assure the honourable senator that the Government will monotor the situation and in fact the National Health and Medical Research Council has undertaken to keep the matter under review.

In Victoria, largely as a result of the activities of DES Action, a conjoint project, organised in 1981 by the Victorian Government in collaboration with the Victorian Branch of the Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, established a referral clinic at the Royal Women's Hospital, Melbourne, and issued an excellent information booklet to all Victorian medical practitioners. I understand that a similar clinic now operates at the King George V Memorial Hospital, Sydney.
